Copper pour with an off-white head. At opening, sourness hits you but it either goes away or I got used to it. Taste is sweetness from the candi sugar, initial sourness. I find this a wonderful beer experience. All the flavors meld together to form a refreshing and enjoyable beer.

12 oz. bottle. My first Faro! Im not sure what to expect here, but Ill give it a tick anyway. It pours a very nice clear copper color with an shrinking off white head. Lots of streaming bubbles. The aroma is strong with funky farmhouse and mildly sweet sugar syrup. Minor notes of blood orange and grapefruit. A little wet cardboard. Maybe some underlying baking spices? Anyway, the nose reminds me of a sweet, funky saison. The flavor is.wow.. VERY sweet but with just a hint of tart fruit to keep it from being too cloying. Kind of like those candied fruit slices. Also cinnamon and sugar. Yeah, the mild tart and funk shows up very lightly near the finish. I know its the style, but the overpowering sweetness kind of ruins this for me. Might be a nice alternative for people who dont like the sourness of the other lambic styles. It actually grows on me a little as my palate adjusts. Just a minor citric funky kick at the end. Very interesting beer and style.

Pours cloudy light brown to deep amber with small but stable white top. Aroma of acidulous home made wine and some malt, caramel tones more deeply. Taste is semi sweet and pure sour in vanguard, refreshing indeed, rich carbonation, light body. I couldnt catch any hop presence. Monolithic flavor. Definitely not mine but to broaden the horizon - its OK.

Bottle.  This sweet and sour brew is perfect for a warm January day. Great malt and wild yeast interaction.        

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

0,25l bottle from Csakajósör, Budapest. Hazy, deep amber color, small white head. Spicy, candy sugar and green apple odor. It remind me an old, mature, sour wine. Very interesting, indescribable aroma. Tart, a bit fruity, cola nut, smoot candy sugar with green apple flavour. Very special and unique. Medium sweet-sour taste. Light body, creamy texture, average carbonation. Sweet-sour, cola and green apple finish. Very interesting beer. Unique and delicious. First Faro Ive ever tried, and I love this style, from this moment...

This was really interesting. Pours a reddish hue with a small white head. Sweet aroma with notes of apple and pear. Sweet and tart with lots of fruity notes in it. Very refreshing and crisp. Really intriguing and a lot more complex than I thought it would be. I would be interested in trying other examples of this style of lambic.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2013 Bit hazy reddish amber with medium white to beige head.
Aroma.. hard to say as this is my first lambic - faro. .I would say acidic caramel, bit of peach, Bit malty, some yeast.
Harsh sweetness and ofc sourness. It reminds me fruity vitamin drinks =]
Well. .this definately isnt my top beer style add, thou for tasting it was quite interesting and good exp.
Bottle 0.25l from local market. Colour is light copper with small white head. Aromas and flavour are sweetness, berries and some sourness.
Cerveja refrescante e bem saborosa. Não é para toda hora, porém como aperitivo de um jantar, cai muito bem.
Light copper pour, thin white head.  Funky yeast in the nose.  SWEET.  Cherry cola like across the tongue.Finishes slightly drier.  Very interesting, but not for every occcasion.

Tap @ Taphouse. Clear cherry-amber pour with a medium, off-white, champers-like head leaving no lace. Nose is very fruit-juicy with a slight amount of tart promise. Light body with medium, coarse carbonation (again: champagne). Sucrose, undefined tropical fruit juice, a slight amount of aged, tart sour ale mixed in, but not nearly enough. Ive not had a Faro before, but Id hope the others are more interesting than this simple, sugary brew. Another Lindemans gateway ale, methinks.
Draft at avenue pub. Cherry copper colored pour. Sweet, sweet aroma and flavor. Light funk but candi sugar dominates everything. Way too sweet for me

Bottle.  Pours a clear light amber with quickly disappearing white head.  Nose of sweet and funky.  Taste is sweet candy sugar, mixed berry, light funk, mild sourish, apple, but a tad too sweet for me.  Not bad but by the end was getting harder to drink.

This pours a beautiful semi-clear, copper color with a bubbly, off-white head. The scent is yeasty combined with aged, sweet fruits. There is a sweetness of candied sugar that is like no other. Very smooth, tasty, and unique. Style points aside, this is quite a delicious desert beer that is best enjoyed by itself after dinner, in my opinion. By far the easiest Lambic-Faro to find on the market!

Brown/amber, small white head. Aroma: sour apples, lemon, yeast, grape juice. Taste: interesting - sweet, Shloer like grape-juice notes meet an acetic, lambic sourness. Medium bodied, zippy carbonation. A little one-dimensional, perhaps, but certainly worth a crack.

Pours dark brown with fizzy white head. Some sweet and sour aromas but the flavour is where this one really shines. Tastes like a sour soother. Sweet and sour...a touch of bitter. Interesting and good!

0.25l bottle. Dark orange/light brown body with floating yeast particles, very quickly disappearing off-white head. Sour apple aroma with a champage-like yeast character and a hint of caramel. Tastes like candi sugar, caramel and lemon. Very nice.

Bottle 375ml @ home
Pours slightly hazy golden with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of light sour apples and sugar. Taste is medium sweet and light sour with a sweet dry finish. Body is medium, texture is thin, carbonation is soft.
bottle. pours light orange with not much head. aroma of apple and funk. taste was like a sour apple cider semi sweet
Bottle.  Pours amber with a little white halo. Overall apple/cider aroma and taste.  Could use some more tartness. Very one note.
Bottle:  Pours a clear light copper with a thin white head, sour cherries in the aroma and taste, sharp carbonation, medium bodied.

beautiful brownish-red colour with minimal white head; sourish aroma of fruits, taste is dominated by fruity sour and sweetness with minimal bitter aftertaste; excellent lambic, may be perfect choice for people, who dont like typical beer taste 

update: during warming up, some herbal sweety bitterness appeared increasing further the experience; really great beer

Rich ruby coloured body with a copper glow and a nice, one centimetre tall tan head. Aroma of amazing sour notes, with grapes, yeast, alcohol, apples, pears and a bit of guava. Medium-bodied; Strong malty note at first with bunches of grapes and apple flavours with a lot of fig flavours at the back end with some herbal notes, a bit of grass and a lot of sour flavours. Aftertaste is complex, especially for the style with flavour ranging from super sweet to sour and a bunch of herbal notes to some yeast flavours. Overall, a very nice beer and one that should be sampled by everyone who loves beer - truly a great style. I sampled this 37,5 cL bottle purchased from Carrefour Express in Bruxelles, Belgium (Port de Namur location) on 30-June-2012 (my birthday) for 1,59 sampled at home in Upstate New York on 28-December-2012.

Bottle. Pours clear dark amber with plentiful but unstable off-white head. Dark, sweety, fruity and malty aroma. Pleasant, sour taste of malt, hop and grain. Sour finish with a sweety note. Decent stuff.

First impression is of wine, has some wine sourness in the flavor. Fruits are in both the aroma and taste, and lots of fine carbonation keep it fizzy. Color is orange , like dark ice tea. A little bit more body than a geueze, but similar.

375ml bottle. Pours a clear dark amber, with a large white head, which lasts fairly well, and leaves reasonable lacing. The aroma is a mix of sour, musty, woody and faint leathery notes. It opens with a nice, strong sourness, with perhaps some redcurrant flavour playing through it. The influence of the candy sugar can be felt moving into the mid-palate, which offers some sweetness along with some woody notes. The sour flavour and slight redcurrant notes reappear towards the finish, which is a deft balance between sour and sweet. This is the first non-fruit lambic I have been able to lay my hands on, and it is not disappointing - it certainly lives up to my expectations.

Pours a light brown. Aroma of biscuit and apples. Nice taste that is a little sour with a cider taste and a nice palate

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

pours light copper with small white head.  nose is very interesting - its all sour, tart fruits and acidity with hints of grain and funk.  theres a good amount of tartness when you first taste it, but that makes way for some sweeter fruit notes, including apple, grape, and cherry; quite like a cider at times.  finishes more sour than sweet with a bit of stickiness.

18.12.12
Uts: krystallklar, ravfarget, lite lyst beige skum, moderat kullsyre.
Duft: tydelig mild lambic, brett og syrlighet, hint av sødme.
Smak: uvant, først sødme fra kandis, tydelig lambicpreg og deretter rund syrlighet. Kort ettersmak.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle.  Copper pour with nice medium head that turns quickly into some lacing around the edge.  Sour candy, apple, brown sugar.  Pretty nice balance of sweetness, bubbles and body but slightly watery finish.

Thanks to rogueone for sharing a bottle. The beer pours a mostly clear reddish-brown color with some sediment, and a medium thick off-white head that recedes slowly. Partial rings of lacing on the glass. The aroma consists of yeast and apples. Light body with flavors of apple cider, yeast and a bit of brown sugar. The finish is mildly tart with a fruity aftertaste. Decent overall.

On tap at Brick Store. Dark amber color with a white head. Aroma contains some vinegar, sour apples,, cherries. Flavor is sour but also sweet with more apples, sweet cherries and a hint of citrus. A very drinkable lambic.

355ml bottle - a bit sceptical about this before I had it, especially as I was very underwhelmed by my last dip into the world of the Faro. The look is quite nice, a bronze/reddy-brown body, a white head that is still there. The nose is most definitely the sugar, a bit malty, and an acidic whiff of apples hidden in there. The taste is quite bitter sweet, a sugary ending following a fruity hit - very similar to Kinnie (Maltese soft drink). There is a mild carbonation making this go down quite well, with the sugary aftertaste the only big downer for me. Much better than the Girardin Faro.

Quite caramelised, a touch sour - more malic than citric acid, but very nice. Appearance a nice clear red-gold colour with a nice white head that lasts as it is continually replinished by the highly effervescent beer. Taste is caramel everywhere! toffee, a touch of carrot even, and maybe some strawberry notes, thats about it. Palate is not super interesting, sugary and sour bites and contrasts on the tongue, apart from that, its just good. Overall, really nice beer, a pretty good Faro.
Dark red colour. Aroma is sour and woody. The sourness in the taste is balanced by the extreme fruity, sugary, sweetness. Light dryness in the finish.

(Draught at Poechenellekelder, Brussels, 20 Oct 2012) Reddish brown colour with dense, off-white head. Sourish, fruity nose with notes of dark fruit, stable, brown sugar and a certain acidity. Fruity, malty taste with caramel, brown sugar, dried fruit and a certain acidity in a finish with a slightly burnt note. Medium body, a bit sweet and sour. Quite nice.

I really liked it, been seeking this style for awhile also. Yeasty, notes of cherry and strawberry... Sweet and sugary, also like a hef, and a bit sour as well though it should not make anybody pucker.

I enjoyed this right from the moment I picked it up, the complete package of nice bottle, corked and capped with foil.  Beautiful.
The Beer poured slightly red with minimal head but a modest amount of carbonation, flavour of tart fruit - very enjoyable.  Definitely would have this again.
Darker pale then expected white head. Very fruity aroma strawberry pineapple. Sweet sugar and malt. Sour finish. Good and very easy to drink. I want this in the summer.

Draft at Proof. Light amber pour with a frothy white head. Nose is slightly funky, sweet jolly rancher fruitiness with a touch of grain. Flavor is very honey crisp apple like, almost cider-y and some funk. Ending is weirdly sweet sour with some off alcohol. Definitely interesting.

12 oz bottle. Pours a translucent copper with lots of carbonation.  Thin white head. Aroma of bread malts and sweet Belgian yeast.  Floral hops, sour fruits, and sweet sugars dominate taste. Hints of rose water.  Sour soapy finish.
Pours a clear reddish brown on tap with thin white head. Aroma of sour fruit, even with no fruit, sweetness, and funk. Taste is sour sweet with a tart finish. Decent, weird.
25cl bottle @ home. No head. Sweet and sour taste. Aftertaste quickly dissapears.

Got the 0,25L bottle from a beer shop in Riga. Pours clear red-brown with a small white head. Aroma: Sour yeast, Hardanger apples, citrus. Taste: Sweet and fruity in the beginning with hints of grape and lots of sugar. Sour in the end. I enjoyed this lambic!

#567
Mit FARO habe ich nun definitiv mein Silvester-Bier gefunden: Es schäumt wie Sekt, sieht aus wie Prosecco und hat -zum Glück- eine ähnliche Süffigkeit. Zuerst öffnet man den üblichen Kronenkorken, um dann festzustellen, dass man noch den Korkenzieher bemühen muss...dann kommt ein sektähnliches-säuerliches Aroma zum Vorschein...ich denke unweigerlich an Sodbrennen, aber die Süße puffert dies gekonnt ab und läßt auch noch Hopfen zum vorschein kommen. Mein Söhnlein-Brilliant heißt FARO Lambic und ist miles better ;)
	
Test vom 5.10.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 10,10,9,9,10,10 - 9,70

Pours clear brown with a thick off white head. Aroma is lemons, seltzer, & slight barnyard funk. Initially the taste is sour and lemony then the sweet maple syrup & brown sugar flavors take over. If something can truly be sweet and sour at the same time this is it! Wow! This is a fun beer.

Pours a amber brown clear with a 2-3 finger pour with very heavy lacing. Sour apple and funk aroma. Medium sour and medium to heavy sweetness. Spices, slight cough drop. Long, sweet finish. Moderate carbonation. Perhaps floral hops.  This beer is way to sweet for my taste, but its not terrible.

Location: .5 L bottle, 11/10/12


Aroma: The nose is sour yeast, some tart/sweet fruit, and some sugary notes

Appearance: It pours a clear dark orange color with a small beige head and no lace at all

Flavor: It is rather sweet and fruity, less tart then the nose, but there is a light underlying tartness

Palate: The body is fairly light, it feels mildly sticky, has a soft carbonation, and has a fairly lengthy finish

Overall Impression: 
This is a solid one.  It gets a touch sticky, but not enough to kill the fairly pleasant drinkability.  Generally, Im not a huge fan of beers this sweet, but I thought this one worked pretty well.

Location/Date:Bottle split with Ben on November 10th, 2012.
Appearance: Pours a light reddish brown with some sediment.
Aroma: Aroma of grape, sugar.
Taste:Grape, sugar, some darker fruit.
Palate:Medium light body, slightly sticky mouthfeel.
Summary: Style rating 73 of 73!  First off thanks to Dave for finding it!

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2012  Pours a hazy light broen colour with a white head that quickly disappears. Aroma of strawberries, malt and maybe som citrus notes. Flavour is strong notes of strawberries, sugar and grass. A bit too sweet imo. Nice for two or three sips, but then it gets a bit too much.
Bottle. Slightly hazy reddish copper color with no head. Sweet and sour aroma of syrup and caramel. Sweet taste of sugar and caramel with notes of wheat. Sweet and slightly sour finish.

375ml bottle $6. This looked a little bit like cuvee rene in the glass but darker. The smell was odd, not what I would expect from lambic, sweet but almost artificially sweet. Same for the taste, just too damned sweet with no funk or sour. I have no clue why they would send this as opposed to the Cuvee Rene Kriek.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 07-10-2010 20:53:23

Flight draft at Fort Worth FS just because I wanted to try a faro lambic. Huge, sweet, perfumey aroma but oddly reminiscent of kids Motrin. Pretty pungent and sweet flavor. Holy crap, I like faro. Now where the heck can I find some this side of Belgium?
Bottle 25 cl. Pours clear bronze in color with a thin off-white head. Sour, vinegar and tart in aroma. Sweet, slightly metallic and sour in taste. Crisp. Nice aftertaste, semi-sour and some acidity.

12oz bottle from Binnys Lincoln Park. First Faro rating. Pours a clear, deeper copper colored body with an inch thick, dense and foamy, pinkish tinted off-white head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is wheat crackers with some cheesy hay, a mild funk and sourness, and a light sugar apple-pear note. Flavor is much sweeter than the aroma led me to believe. Very sugary with some honey-mead qualities, a dry and mild funk, cork, a bit of a cheesy hay, and a light cracker note. Finishes sugary sweet, but pretty dry with a light sourness and funk, apple-pear, and wood. Lengthy aftertaste following a light body and a fairly lively carbonation. Overall, this was definitely quite sweet, but it grew on me more as I drank it. Very dry with a mild mix of cheesy funk, hay, sour fruits, and wood. This was alright.

Bottle at home (Noel Cuvelier) - 20/10/12.
Clear dark golden with a thin off white head that soon clears to the edges and forms a small lake.
Nose has sour tones, peach, grapes, light caramel, burnt sugar, sour/tarte notes.
Taste follows, light fruit notes, orange pith, caramel, sugared candy, sour tones.
Medium bodied with moderate carbonation, leading to a sweet finihs,
A little to sweet overall!
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Looks kinda like iced tea. Smells a little like it, too - sweet, and some lemony aromas. Flavor pretty much keeps with the Iced Tea theme, with lemony, citrusy flavors and rather sweet. Ok, I guess, but I cant imagine buying this again.
Pours light amber with minimal head. Nose is sweet & sour sauce. Nice winey, cidery taste.
Ooh,ooh, this is very sweet but quite nice. Sweet and sour with a very strong apple juice or cider flavor with a slight kick. Good

Pours with a vivid foam that disappears quickly. Beautiful autumn colors; deep brownish red. Although the smell is quite appalling, the taste is far from that. Sweet and sour flavors alternate in the most pleasant way. 

As goes for most Lambic, you either love it or hate it. I have grown quite fond of the fresh, sour and wild flavors of natural fermentation.

12oz. Bottle. Clear amber pour with almost no head but what there is sticks around. Very sweet and sour sauce sort of nose with some fruit. Very muted funk in the back. Very easy on the palate and quite sweet right after the sour. This is the first faro Ive had and Im a fan. Sort of. Its a nice starter lambic.

Into a flute glass. Clear, peach color body. Finger of head lasted a few seconds. 
It smells like barnyard vinegar cherry. Interesting if nothing else.
A slight vinegar taste and sweet candy. Its like beer candy.
Higher carbonation and light body.
Its a sweet, light, high carbonated beer. The sparkling wine of beer. Worth trying at least once.

Red brown pour with thick beige dissipating head .yeasty green apple aroma .taste is sweet to start then a lovely acidic sourness follows with long aftertaste. Full carbonation with champagne like mouthfeel. Very interesting style and likeable

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
De olor suave, sabor dulce con notas acidas al final que recuerdan a un vino espumoso o a una sidra, ideal para postre o la sobremesa.

Aroma was wild and sweet. Color was a brown red with a decent head. The taste was bitter but sweet, with a sour that is usually found with a green apple, without the taste. Left a film in the mouth, assumably from sugar.

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2012 355mL bottle I brought back from France, shared with matt7215. Pours a nice clearish red-brown with a small beige head. The aroma is quite nice, some funk, some acidic lambic characters, fruit, and malt. The flavour I found to be very nice, striking a good balance between the sugar/malty sweetness and the tart, lambic acidity. Over-all I felt it achieved what the style was intended to, and this is the best example Ive had. Worth having picked up but not something I would drink all that often.

375ml bottle shared by jessem. deep amber with anoff white head. nice funky lambic nose. sweet upfront with a great lambic base. this is such a weird style, i find regular lambic to be so much more drinkable then this but this style was invented to improve the drinkability of great lambic. fun to try, thx jesse.

Ramata, limpida, schiuma bianca quasi assente. Naso intenso e complesso, con note di ciliegia, frutta candita e note acide.
Dolce, acidula, corpo snello.......mi è piaciuta.......

Pours a copper brown color with a finger of offwhite foam...aromas smells cheap and sugary, caramel, cream soda with a touch of vinous moscato... On the palate it is a lot of the same, ripe apples add to the mix but the caramel sweetness just over powers the sour funky notes making it more like a fruit juice spritzer.. curious to try other faro lambics to see how they compare.

Slightly hazy brown colour, cream head. Aroma of candy sugar, sink, overripe fruit, old sweetener, processed manure and some pediococcus. Light sweet flavour, sour notes. Sour apple juice, some lambic character. Pleasantly carbonated, finish apple juice, light caramel and sour notes.
Much better than I was anticipating. The aroma is not winning me over, but the flavour and palate are pleasing me. Nice.
(From 25cL bottle @ home. BB 12 Apr 2014)

250ml bottle (K Market, Kamppi) BB 2010-11, Drunk 2012-09
Very pleasant sweet aroma, like the golden nuggets breakfast cereal i had when I was a kid (that probably means theres some butterscotch). Clear bold rich orange, brief head. Full sweet palate, gentle carbonation. Sweat breakfast-cerealy honey-covered wheat-flake taste. Rather nice. Finish is mostly the sweetness, and to be honest, I shouldnt give this 4, but it was very nice in the mouth, so I have to. Overall, a remarkably drinkable modern faro, better than some of the more traditional ones Ive had, to be honest. However, thats because I think faro is intrinsically a modern sweet thing, not a traditional sour thing. If you want to stick sugars into your old lambics, then do them via the medium of young lambic, and give me a geueze. If, however, you want a luscious sweet drink, then make one of these.

Hmm... sickly sweet? No, thats not right. Sweet sick? Yep, thats it. Tastes like the spew of a 4 year old thats scoffed too many jelly tots and had a couple of swigs of his moms sherry at his birthday party while her attention is elsewhere as she tries to cop off with the hired clown in the airing cupboard. Does anyone even have an airing cupboard?

UPDATED: APR 19, 2013 haha , okay this is sort of the least ive expected !
wanted to try this style, expected something sour with a filthy sugar taste...
smells kinda sour..
tastes like.. appeljuice? WTF? its even kinda good? i thought i was gonna hate this ! its like drinking applejuice, with the carbonation of a right-carbonated beer, with a sour-kinda thing in it ( expecialy in the aftertaste ) that if the lambik, but reminds you of apples as well... very unexpected but this is not bad ! maybe rated to high but its just such a surprise to me that i dont hate it ! in fact, i might even buy more :)

355ml bottle (think from Knightly, but not sure).  Copper pour with a thinnish white head.  Aroma is earthy wet, mandarin oranges, floral, musty and vinegar.  Taste is wheat, honey, sweet/sour, sugar, caramel, oak.  Slightly syrupy thin to medium texture with a fair amount of carbonation.  Havent had enough of the style to place it, but on its own: ok, less sugar and more sour for my tastes.

250ml bottle @ vPBF
BBE 2009 - 
Pours clear reddish brown with a tiny head.
Aroma of sugar, syrup, hints of fruits.
Taste is sugary and sweetish with mild notes of tart fruits. 
Sweet and soda pop like finish with some carbonation. Too sweet for my taste.

25 cl bottle @ vPBF. BBE 02.04.2009.
Pours hazy orange color with minimal head. Aroma of some sugar, grass, mild yeast, fruits and grapes, some cellar notes too. Flavor of sugar, fruits, yeast and caramel. A bit sweet palate.
5331

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2013 25 cl bottle (4,2%) @ vPBF, BBE 02.04.2009. Thanks TBone!
Aroma is stale, it feels a bit oxidated with some brown sugar and mold. Flavour is sweet with lots of sugar, some raisins, hints of moldy and metallic feeling. Couldnt locate the gastric acid I usually find in every Lindemans beer (except the oversweet ones). Drinkable.
4+2+5+2+9=2.2

25 cl bottle @ home. Rated on 01.04.2009
Aroma is sourish and sweet with earthy notes, grapefruit, sugar and hints of gastric acid. Flavour has gastric acid, sweet sugar, some fruity notes and hints of grapefruit. The first association with the taste was my own vomit  the gastric acid aromas were a shock.
6+3+5+3+12 = 2.9

Bottle. Pours amber to brown somewhat clear color with lively white head that disappears in seconds. Aroma is sparkling wine (champagne), grapefruit, bit earthy. Taste is sugar and grapefruit. Start is very sweet, leading to sour ending. Really nice.
250ml bottle. Soggy, brownish red color. No head, flat. Sour, mouldy, earthy in aroma. Sweet, fruity, sour, earthy, apples in flavor.

375 ml bottle courtesy of tkrjukoff. Pours tiny hazy amber with a small frothy offwhite head that quickly dissipates without leaving much trace. Smell is sweet and funky with biscuits, rubber, brett, lemonade, orange zest, candi sugar, crackers, barnyard, hay and graham crackers. Taste is sweet and sour with biscuits, lemonade, brett, hay, lemon hard candy, barnyard, crackers and overripe apricots. Mouthfeel is smooth, round, tiny tart, sticky sweet and light to medium bodied. Finish is sweet and tiny sour with lemonade, wood, peaches, dry soil, hay and candi sugar.

(Bottle) Pours amber with a small head. The aroma holds dirty brett and candi sugar up front with undertones of cheese and citrus candy. The flavour is medium to heavily sweet and medium acidic with notes citrus candy, brett and malt. The mouthfeel is sticky with a light carbonation. Chinese sweet and sour souse on the finish. Near medium bodied.
Bottle @ MMP. Pours clear deep amber with a small ring of off white head. Aroma is astringent sweet cellar stable earthy. Flavor is sour sweet fruity tart bitter. Finishes sweet bitter tart.
Tastes much like wine.  Sweet.   Pear Cider.  No head.  Somewhat wild.  Awesome.  Sour.

Draft at Eulogy. Clear vibrant copper pour with a fizzy white head. Strong but delicate burnt sugar flavors. Complex caramel. Slight hint of malty red fruit undertones, but basically a one note sugared lambic. Still, I think Lindemans does a better job with the faro than with their sugary fruity varieties. This faro is pleasantly fuller than most without being sickeningly sweet.
Sampler at The Celt Irish Pub in Carcassonne France 8/11/12. Not bad, not my style.
This beer remindes me a russian champagne. Sour, fruit taste wit a light, but good bitter nute. White and thin foam disappearing very fast. Semi-drak colour. Overall - good to drink for sometime.
Pours amber with a small white head.  Aroma is sour apples and yeast.  Taste is sweet and sour with apples, malts, and yeast.
sour and sweet aroma. light brown in color with a nice head. sediment suspended in beer. taste is sour but wery sweet.

Bottle to oversized snifter. Looks okay; brown with thin white lacing. Smells sweet and lambic. Tastes artificially sweet along with cheap lambic. Mouthfeel is average (at best). This is my first faro, and Im not that impressed...but then again, its Lindemans.
Puckering, yet sticky sweet. Light syrup to the body. Prickly carbonation that doesnt let go. Nice feel.
Draught at Poechenellekelder, Brussels. Red amber beer with an offwhite head. Sweet and fruity aroma. Similar flavour with a sourish touch. Nice beer, a bit to sweet maybe.

0.25 bottle. Reddish-brown, clear with sediment. Nose is pretty amazing; red berries combined with tea flavors, caramel, toffee and some sour farmyard tones. Palate is crisp, and medium bodied. intense flavours of sweet & sour berries, with a dominating caramel toffee backbone. Refreshing. An excellent, easily drunk, sour ale. A bit softer, sweeter, than most, making it good for the times you only want a little of acidity in your beer.

Bottle. Pours hazy copper with little head and some sediment. Aroma is very much like a white wine with a lot of white grape. Taste is very sweet and has a mix of sir apples and white grapes. If you like apple cider, go for it. Its interesting.

On tap at Casanovas, thanks Ryan! Pours a reddish amber color with zero head. Has a super sweet scent of strawberries/cherries and some tea. Taste is similar to scent, a little too sweet though, has a little sour bite.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Clear brown, small off-white head. Like other Faros, sour and sweet with the sweetness gaining intensity way too much.

Draught at Poechenellekelder, Brussels. Reddish amber color with a small offwhite head. Sweet fruity aroma, cookie dough, rubber notes, a little tart. Sweet fruity flavor, rubber, apples, almond notes, sugary. A bit too sweet but still interesting.
This is a typical faro. Dark orange brown. Sweet beer (kandijsuiker) with sour notes. Refreshing and easy drinkable but too sweet.
A incredibly interesting lambic, general fruity scent that leads into a tart but smooth caramel body, bitter after flavor but agreeable with a little bite.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2014 Pours a medium red color with no head.  Aroma is berries, strawberries, and some light spices and funky sour notes.  Taste is moderately sweet and just a little tart.  A nice blend of fruit and berries.  This is easy drinking and it leaves a nice taste in the finish.

Bottle pours amber/red with a light cream head. Aromas are tart and vinegar like. Taste is sweet and sugar leith some light tartness o the back end. Not nearly as sour as the beer smelled.  Refill get sme light funkiness breaking through the sweetness.  Overall a nice beer and the only Faro I have had.

There was some earthy barnyard aromas under the caramelly sweet aroma.
Clear orange and sparkling in appearance with a pleasant frothy white head that subsided but lingered to the end.
 The taste was a deep sweet cut with lambic sourness but balanced very much towards the candi sugar sweetness. The palate was full without being cloying.

Im a fan of sour beers but this is my first faro and I enjoyed it.

Pours a clear redish amber with a bubbly offwhite head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is malty I can really smell the wheat and some sour fruit funk and a little wood. Flavor is fruity, sweet and sour lots of funk with some fruit like cherry. Overall this was a interesting beer my first lambic faro and I liked it altough I dont have much I compare it too.

Smells great.  Caramel and tart acidity.  The head is a little absent, which I disliked.  The flavor is great, sour and sweet.  Candy sugar plus hints of orange and cherry.  Clean mouthfeel.  Great beer, I will try it again.
Bottle from SIBF. Finally getting my Faro card with this. Sweet, sugary, mild aroma. Deepest orange. Sweet brown sugar. Light sweet tart, ice wine. cidery. wood, dry tart and coating.

Bottle - 375ml. Hazy, dark amber body with moderate carbonation and a thin off-white foamy head. Sharp, fresh hoppy aroma with citrusy and flowery hints. Its well balanced, sharp hoppy taste carries malty and fruity (cherries, grapes) notes. Ends with a long, robust bitter/sour finish. Very good Lambic.

Bottle at SIBF 2012. Orange pour, like an IPA. Balanced tartness on the nose -- sweet and tart citrus, mostly mandarin. Low carbonation, but that serves this one well. A sweet backbone has the mildest tart edge, like an ice wine or cider. Really, really tasty -- I enjoyed this one quite a bit.

Amber color with medium white head which quickly fades. Smell of wet grass, earth, leaves. Has nice sweetness combined with sourness. One of the few easy to buy Faros but enjoyed it very much. Nice in the summer period.

375 ml. bottle I have eyed but would have probably never bought.  A gift from my girlfriend.  Hazed, reddish amber pour with a medium off white head.  The head quickly dissipates into nothingness.  Aroma of funk, lactic acid, wet wool, oak and other tartness.  I also get a mild ginger-ale like sweetness.  Flavor is mild funk, mild sourness, fairly strong belgian candi sugar.  Light yogurt notes and medium acid.  This is quite nice, actually.  A bit of a surprise.  This is certainly not an every day beer but one that represents an interesting change up.

Bottle:  My first faro experience!  Translucent chestnut color with a modest sandy head.  Tart, oaky and vinous aroma is on par with most gueuze lambics Ive tried.  Flavor is light oak, grape skins, and a sweetness that must be from the candi sugar.  Gives it a pleasant taste.  Finishes with a snappy light sweet/sugary tart thing that really sits well on the palate.  Refreshing.
light brown with minimal head. very sweet and fruity. slightly tart. cherry and berry are main flavors.

Im really not one for sweet beers, but this one isnt bad. Has a slightly sweet smell and an even sweeter taste. But the sweetness doesnt overwhelm the beer to the point of being bad. Really interesting brew. My first into this style...
Cloudy, brown, bursting with effervescent fruity notes.Sparkling on the tongue and refreshing. Softly lingering sweet and slightly malty aftertaste.

my first Faro. not bad, but i wont rush back to the style.
heady sweet aroma, some fruit. flavour is quite sweet (i could feel it on my teeth!) lots of fruit, particularly cherry. tart finish.

bottle. beerritz. leeds

Pours a bubbly amber brown. Aroma of dark cherries and malt. Taste is intensely sweet followed by a warm sour note that finally ends with a bit of bitterness but just subtle. Refreshing but a tad sweet. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

375 ml bottle from Brewery Creek. Pours a clear coppery red with little head. Sour woody aroma with red berry notes. Interesting mix of sweet and sour. Nice carbonation. Flavors of strawberry and citrus.
Bottle:  Bought this to try a Faro.  Not the best beers, but none of the lambics are.

The aroma is slightly sour with a tiny hint of Belgian fruitiness.  The pour is a really cool looking deep maple with a thin white head that leaves lacing.  The taste is similar to a moderately sweet champagne.  A bit of sourness in there but at the same time, refreshing.  Quite drinkable and tasty.  Nicely done.

From bottle bought at Delhaize near the bourse in Brussels. Pours a hazy red with minimal head that dissipated quickly. Smells of berries. Taste id a good balance of sweet and tart. Finishes a bit to sweet. Nice drink a bit far from the beer family.
I wouldnt normally have been drawn to this style but was pleasantly surprised. Pours a light red color with a hint of sweetness but not overpowering. I think I will have another

This was very interesting brew. Clear reddish amber pour with decent carb. The aroma is sweet and musty with hints of berry. Slightly acetic as well. Flavor is very sweet, a little too for me. A nice tart bite to it, though. Glad I tried this style but not my favorite lambic.
A pretty sweet beer and also sour. Aroma is flowery. Color is light brown with a white head.

Clear red berry amber, small off white head fades quickly. Aroma of sweet and sour berries and yeast. Mmmm... delicious! Fruity sweet, tart ,silky berry  taste, some candy apple.  Lively carbonation, light bodied, very refreshing. Sweet acidic finish. Perfect for desert or a nightcap. LF (Lagerboy Friendly)

Brown 25cl bottle, best before 25th Jan 2009, drank 15th Feb 2009, so slightly older than recommended.

Poured into a Mort Subite flute (twice, it only holds 0.2 Litre.

No cork in my bottle, just a silver foil covering and a normal bottle cap.

Old marmalade orange in colour, with a huge cream coloured head (hence the two pours).

Vinegarous aroma, then farmyards, then marmalade with yeast and sour fruit.

Sweet and sour flavours, tart yet very drinkable. Drys in the mouth, strange and yet interesting qualities. Complexed and confusing. Sticky when spilt, I needed some water after the tasteing, just to cleanse my palate.

Is it too sweet? Most likely yes.

Is it too sour? Most likely yes.

The 25cl bottle was just about the right amount for me. Any more and Id have started to find fault, any less and I might have missed something.

Not sure if I agree with the brewers comments as this beer was a brick red and definitely not clear.  Taste wise this is an interesting beer that has an initial sweetness that transforms to a bitter finish and unfortunately leaves a metallic taste in my mouth.  This is why my palate and overall score was so low.  Thinking bad bottle.

Lovely reddish amber colour with a fine white head that quick vanishes. Acidic apple and light sweet fruity aroma. Flavour are about the same. Light acidic with a lovely mild sweetness in the background. Fresh and very enjoyable.[Bottle. Trade with Mr Grima. Thanxxx a lot man!]

Pours reddish brown with minimal white head. Smells of sour berries dust and a hint of sweetness. Tastes sweet and sour with notes of barely and berries. Maybe a bit too much carbonation but other than that pretty enjoyable.

Bottle.  Pours a clear light brown with a scattering of off-white foam.  Aroma is a wet cheesy funk with candied sugar.  Taste is artificial sweetness with light ligth tart and an off-flavor of funk but not in a good way.  Just an overall odd, disjointed, and artificial presentation.  Not a fan.

UPDATED: MAY 28, 2013 Bottle. Pours clear slightly reddish amber with a medium head that dissipates down to a small head quickly with no lacing. Highly carbonated. Aroma is primarily of sour apple and Belgian yeast, slightly sweet. Taste mimics nose, with definite sweetness mixed with sour apples, Belgian yeast and perhaps a bit of malt. Surprisingly crisp clean finish given the sweetness. A very tasty beer.

Bottle @ DØE meeting. Pours dark golden with a very small offwhite head. Aroma is light sour, light fruity, sugar, light oak. Taste is sweet sugary, sour / tart fruit, stomach acid. Thin body, lively carbonation. 160512

This one really works for me. Nose is pretty light, some sour apples maybe. Up front in the mouth I get grape, backed by sweet apples, and finish is mild tart. Pours amber with minimal head and no lacing. Light in the mouth with medium carbonation. I really, really like this one.

Backlog summer 2010 La Rochelle, France
Medium bodt & high complexity
Intense yeast
Very enjoyable

Aroma increible, penetrante. En primera instancia notas citricas y frutales. Ligeras notas a manzana.
En cuanto a la apariencia, color dorado con notas pajizas. Alta carbonatación y sedimentos en virtud del azucar añadido antes del embotellado. Espuma esponjosa de amplia duración.
Al primer sorbo, se percibe un intenso sabor dulce y gasificación alta.
Al paladar las sensaciones dulce predominan, sin embargo, posteriormente, las notas dulces ceden paso a un sabor ligeramente acido, caracteristico de este estilo de cervezas. El final de esta cerveza es amplio, y finalmente se deja sentir ciertos sabores frutales, principalmente a pera y manzana verde, aun que en ningún momento cede completamente el sabor dulce.
En general, una cerveza bastante buena y representativa del estilo.

Clear reddish brown pour, minimal head. Aroma of raw grain, parmesan, apples. Tastes of cedar, apples, and wild yeast. Very nice soft sourness, and well balanced. Notes of leather and funk, with a distant lite balsamic vinegar note on the finish
Smelled sour poured flat.and darker...tasted alot sweeter than i expected.but verry good decent beer one more style left

Bottle. Clear garnet with fizzy dissipating head. Smells interesting- a little musty, plus sour apple, plus cotton candy. Sweet and a little tart. Clean and tart and almost crisp. This is my first Faro and I like it overall.

From the bottle poured a lovely reddish brew with a white head that deflated rapidly. Aromas of sour and malt. Wonderful flavors of fruit with a little sweet/sour thingy going on. Medium bodied, complex, and tasty.

Bottle from Beers of Europe. It pours deep amber, with a thin off-white head. The nose is pretty damn sweet: stewed apple, sweet plum, raisin, white sugar and a hint of spice. The taste is also pretty damn sweet: stewed apple, pear, raisin, touch of lemon pith, hint of tanginess (reminiscent of vomit), caramel and white sugar, with a very sweet finish. Medium body and low carbonation. Far too sweet and not nearly enough tartness. I can barely get past a few mouth-fulls  drain pour.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2013 Alright I wont lie, this was the first and only faro Ive had. Hey weve got to start somewhere. One of the most extreme flavours to grace my mouth, and not just talking about beer here. The plums and belgian yeast went REALLY well with the candied sugar, and I will definitely continue buying this. Ill try as many faros as I can, and plan on updating this review in the future.
Una cerveza lampic sobrendende , dulce von sabor a toffe y toques de vino tinto ! Espuma ligera que desaparece pronto.

Bottle. Sweet tart malt vinegar aroma. Brown with a small head, dirty looking sediment suspended throughout. Sweet malty flavor with an underlying tartness and very slight bitterness. Medium body and carbonation.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2012 375ml bottle. Sweet and malty aromas. Pours light copper with thin white head, quickly disipating. Light body, average carbonation. Tastes sweet and some sourness, some cider hints,with malt flavors on the background. Short astrigent finish.
A belgian classic, easy to drink and really enjoyable.

37,5cl bottle.
A little sour aroma with some sweetness/candy as well.
Brown/amber colour with quickly fading head.
Tasted pleasantly sweet and less sour than I expected. Maybe a bit too sweet in the finish.

Pour red brown with a medium off-white head who quickly disappeared. Aroma: Sweet and funky with fruity esters. Taste: Acidic at first, then it suddenly become sugary. Weird sensation. Overall: Refreshing but too sugary.

375ml bottle. Initially it is a dirty light brown tea colour with an off white head. Sour aromas of vinegar are quite pleasant in a strange way. There is some eyebrow curling tartness in the first sip but it does get better and the flavour is better than you first think that it is.

A rich clear copper color with very short-lived tanish head. No lacing noted. The aroma is fruity and yeasty. The palat is all red fruit and a wonderful tartness verging in sour. Medium in body, this beer coats the tongue and leaves a long fruity aftertaste. Would buy and drink again!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Ale Yeah! in Decatur, GA. Initial Worcestershire aroma and
Flavor, then sour, sweet, heady.  Brown color.  Better the more it warms up. Meaty.

amber colored, eggshell white head with nice lacing. nose is a bit musty with a hint of lemon. flavor is initially tart with a strong sweetness coming through in the finish. probably a little sweeter than id like, but tasty nonetheless.

Medium head. Aroma is yeasty. Brown and hazy in color. Immediate rush of sweet with a light sour finish. An interesting and delicious beer.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Tomlinsons Beer Shop, Inverness
Golden brown, some haze, bubbly white head that dissipates to rim
Aroma - slightly sour soft tart, mainly sweet light fruits, light aroma
Taste - sweet sugars, sweet honey, some sour tartness, fruity, hint of grape
Palate - medium body, medium carb, sticky texture, sweet sour palte. Finish of sweet sour fruits, dryish, acidic tang, cleans off palate
Overall - Soft sweet lambic - its really quite nice
Brownish-orange colour with nice white head. Fruity aroma. Taste is sweet and a bit sour, perhaps a touch too sweet for my liking but quite nice. My first faro lambic; enjoyable.
Deep rich honey colour. Sweet fermented aroma. I really really liked this beverage.
A parte il fatto che ho un raffreddore micidiale, però volevo farmi una bevutina e questo mi ha appagato abbastanza...

Bottle 355mL from Warehouse Beverage, pour is a ruby ish beer perhaps a little lighter than ruby but still nice looking, nose is that sour beer smell that ive been craving, taste is surprising having never had a Faro I didnt kno wwhat to expect, the candy sugar taste was interesting, and first few sips were quite good and refreshing, however as the bottle dwindled the sugar was more and more distracting from the tartness, I had no real funk which was fine by me.

Bottle sample at the 3rd Israeli Sour Tasting. Thanks Lee. BBD 11/12. Clear, no head, dark golden. Champagne aroma and sweet, delicate taste with sour in the background. Oily, delicate fizz, long finish. Nice.

Bottle sample at the 3rd Israeli Sour Tasting. Thanks Lee. BBD 11/12. Hazy dark orange-golden. Somewhat funky aroma with a bit sugar. Sweet flavor with sugar, a bit of honey, caramel, a bit of wood, some funky sourness and light herbal bitterness. Medium-bodied. Decent.
Bottle. Dark amber, off-white head. Fairly highly carbonated. More base of a flavor than I expected, not enough tartness. Barely sour aroma, malty, leather. Dry finish.

UPDATED: APR 9, 2012 At the 3rd israeli sour tasting, thanks Lee, pours orange to brown hazy with a medium head, aroma of molasses, brown sugar, light sourness, flavor is slightly sour with lively carbonation, fruit sugar, green tea, medium bodied

Pours dark amber with a small amount of fizz. Smells a bit sour with a hint of funk. Taste is sour, with hints of funk and wheat. Light-bodied with a slick, oily texture and decent mouth-carbonation, Lindemans Faro finishes with some pleasant sourness.
Bottled. Amber color with small whitehead. Aroma is Sour fruited, hint of grapes. Balanced sweet/sour palate. Finish is Soar cherry fruited.

Pours a clear ruby brown with very thin quickly disappearing off-white head, no lacing.  Aroma of wheat, yeast, apple cider, dark dried tart fruits, and caramel.  Flavor matches well and is definitely dominated a bit more by caramel malt than I was expecting and quite sweet.  Taste is very long lasting and almost sticky.  Definitely a bit different.
a nice faro, Nice ruby colour.Foam head could be better. Excellent balance between the sour of the lambic and the sweet of the sugar added. Stays long in your mouth and tastes quite full

Bottle from Sicilianos in Grand Rapids, MI.  Gorgeous clear ruby colour with a thin white head.  Nice sour cherry aroma.  Sweet smooth candy taste compliments the underlying tartness, which comes through in the finish.  As a "Lambic newbie", this is more to my liking than the Lindemans Gueuze I tried earlier tonight.  Less carbonation than the Gueze too, and a nice full mouthfeel.  Very drinkable and enjoyable.
Pours a clear orange-red with a tan head and particulates floating in it.  Smells candy-ish, sweet and leathery.  Taste is sweet and a little sour, it has a candy quality - quite a superb specimen.

Bottle.  Pours deep, slightly hazy amber with thin, fizzy white head; extremely short retention and no lacing.  Aroma is sour fruit, bread and cereal malts, light floral hops, light yeast, and faint spice.  Flavor is sweet malt forward, faint hops, and heavy fruit esters; dry, sweet, wine finish.  Light body, carbonation, and warmth.

Picked this up at the Lebanon Health Food Store for $5.25. Poured into an Ommegang Glass at cellar temperature of 59 Degrees F.

A - The beer is a dark amber to brown color. Really beautiful. An easy pour generated 3-fingers of off white to leather colored head. It dissipated to a small line of bubbles after 5 minutes.

S - The standard Tart & Sour scent is what hits the nose first. This is followed by wheat and very bready yeast. It has a sort of ice cream scent like mint ice cream. Creamy and sugar along with cream. Very pleasant and not too over powering.

T - Yeah, its a very mild sweetness. The sweet and tart notes fade away almost instantly which is disappointing. The wheat taste is the dominant taste in this beer. Id prefer more sour from a Lindemans beer but its not terrible. 

M - 50/50 bubbles to liquid on a mouth swish. Lingering candy taste after swallowing. Light and drinkable.

O - This is a solid beer but not fantastic. The price wasnt too bad. As I finish this glass, the sweetness is starting to sit weird on the palate. If it was a bit more sour, the sweetness wouldnt be such a turn off.

Interesting and good. The nose is sweet and vinous with some notes of oak. The beer is a clear effervesant brown with a fizzy cream colored head. The taste is vinous with some caramel and like oak notes. The body is light to medium with a pinpoint carbonation. The palate is characterized by a nice tart sweetness.  Went great with a key lime pie in celebration of pi day.

Botella de 250ml.Copa flauta (Timmermans).Saboreada en mar´12. Color ambar con tintes marrones,rojiza a contraluz.Corona marfil con buena retención.Fragancias herbales y florales con aromas de malta caramelo y melazas.Entrada de acido agridulce con notas de mandarina.Sabor de moderado malteado enmascarada por una agradable sensación azucarada.Matices de miel.Cuerpo ligero y chispeante,carbonatación media-alta.Final dulce y afrutado (mandarina,melazas y albaricoque maduro).Agradable retrogusto tartárico con toques de piel de manzana.Sabores azucarados y cítricos increiblemente bien equilibrados permitiendo que no resulte,en absoluto, empalagosa.Refrescante con una excelente asimilación.Me gustan las lambicas pero siempre fui reticente a la llamada "lámbica azucarada".Ahora he cambiado de opinión y pienso beber muchas más como esta. 250ml bottle.Flute glass (Timmermans). Enjoyed on mar´12.Brownish amber color,reddish to the light.Off white crown.Good retention.Herbal & floral fragancy,caramel malt & molasse aromas.Sour-acidic sweet upfront,tangerine notes.Mildy malty flavor masked by a gentle sugary sensation.Honey hues.Sparkling light body,medium-high carbonation. Sweet finish (tangerine,molasses & ripe apricot).Pleasant tartar aftertaste with a subtle apple skin touch. Sugary & citric flavors are incredible well balanced making a beer not cloying at all.Refreshing with an excellent drinkability.I love lambics but I´d always been reticent about the so call "sugar lambic".Now I´ve changed my mind then I will have many more like this.

Bottle - average size foamy head, light copper color, sweet fruit aroma, sweet fruit (appleish) flavor with a mild sour finish - my first try of this style, reminds me of a cider with a little bit of a wine kind of mix

12oz bottle - pours caramel with off-white head and some lacing.  Nose is apple and champagne.  Flavor is sweet apple and candy.  taste is sweet all around.  Medium body with sticky texture.  I dont know enough about the style, but it reminds me greatly of cider, but not as sweet and more like champagne.  A good apéritif or desert wine.

Bottle 375 ml [2011]. Pour red brown with a medium off-white head who quickly disappeared. Aroma: Sweet and funky with fruity esters. Taste: Acidic at first (but much less than a gueuze), then it suddenly become sugary. Weird sensation. Overall: Refreshing but too sugary.

Bottle. Pours a dark orange color with an whiteish head. Aroma is champagne like, some citrus, subtle funk, cereal notes, caramel and sugar. Flavor is tart and again a little champagne like with some fruity notes of green apple, along with citrus, subtle funk, caramel and sugar notes. The body is light with a dry mouth feel. Overall a pretty interesting Lambic and not as sweet as some of Lindemans other Lambics.

0.375l bottle from CrackedKettle. This is a clear bronze-brown faro with a small bubbly and sidesticking off-white head. Tart, not sour aroma. Really woody with distinct tones of both fruity cherries and sweetness. Unlike anything Ive had before (and can remember). It just smells dry wood! Oh my! Thats sweeter than I could ever have imagined! Really really syrupy-sugar infused! Like drinking a sugar-syrup. Completely overwhelms everything else that sweetness. Guess you might say it ends kinda dry? Damn.. Definitely not something you want to be serving small hyperactive children.. 17.02.2012

Brownish-gold with off-white head....Slightly off-putting sour/sickly aroma.
Taste is sugary, honey, candied apple and berries.  A ner match for some champagnes....not a favourite.
Pouring light brown with a fade of light at the bottom and darker at the top it smells a little sour but tastes sweet with an abrupt finish.
botella de 25 Cl. Mas que aceptable cerveza tipo Lambic armotizada con ¿azucar?

Bottle. 375ml.

Pours clear brown, with almost no head. Aroma is sour, apples. The taste is first acidic, then evoluates to sweet, under the supervision of apples. A little bit of funk from lambic. Weird style. Nice balance. Maybe a little too heavy on the candy.

12 oz bottle. My first of the style, so cant do much comparisons here. This was actually rather as expected though, with it being mild on the funk, lighter on the body, and candy sugary sweet in flavor. It pours with a bright white layer of small bubble head, with a ring of retention, a transparent, honey-like golden-caramel color. The aroma is light and sugary with some unique qualities to it. Some olives, honey, caramel, cinnamon-like spice, and cheesy grass can be appreciated. The body starts out with a decent, sparkling carbonation with light oil and vinegar coming in to give a quite unique feel. Would definitely like more of the funk (which is quite minor) to take over and balance out the sugary sweetness that dominates. Honey and light sugary fig are prominent, giving it an almost mead-like quality. Cinnamon spice, caramel candy, green apples, tart pears, light vinegar, and minor toasty crackers in there as well as a light cheesiness. Overall, this was interesting, but there is no way I could drink more than one of these in a night.
From bottle. Pours orangey apple juice colour with bits floating and no head. Sweet lambic aroma, apple juice. Taste has hints of lambic. Too sweet, quite unpleasant. Didnt like this. Sink job
Bottle. Red. Fizzy with no head. Horrible funky aroma. Sweet and tangy. Any other beer gets criticised for wanton sugar addition. Sink job.
12oz bottle: Appearance is cloudy medium brown with minimal off white head. Aroma is sour with with some yeasty notes. Taste is initially sour with some apples and bananas.

Bottle. The pour was a pinkish orange brown with an average sized (1-2 finger) creamy white head that dissipated quickly down to a thin film and a small collar, but did produce some good streaky lacing.

The aroma was a funky sweet with a light touch of cereal malts and a sweet horse blanket yeast with noticeable notes of green apple, berries, caramel, candy sugar and a mild hint of wood.

The taste was extremely sweet and substantially malty with hints of berries, candy sugar and caramel at first and finished just as sweet and malty, but was a tad on the tart side with notes of green apple and a touch of wood at the end. The flavor lasted an average duration with the sweet-tart candy taste left to linger.

Mouthfeel was light in body with a dry syrupy texture and a prickly carbonation.

Overall a nice tart and extremely malty-sweet brew, with a berry-apple champagne taste.

Sorry for the german rating, but this is a lousy rating from my "newbie" time (2007-2009), and its not worth of being translated. I just added it for the statistics, and to complete my backlog!

Ins Glas ergießt sich ein rötlich braunes Bier mit feiner, langlebiger Krone. Geruchlich sehr Rotwein-lastig, etwas süßlich. Der Antrunk fällt sehr süß aus. Fruchtig, nach Erdbeeren. Der Abgang hingegen ist so säuerlich, dass ich das Gesicht verziehen muss, allerdings hält dieser Zustand nicht lange an. Nach jedem Schluck wird das Bier geschmacksintensiver. Eine neue, aber gute Erfahrung. War hoffentlich nicht mein letztes Faro!

Zurige geur maar erg zoete bruinesuikersmaak, nasmaak is zoet en zuur apart, maar niet gecombineerd. Weinig complex, ongetwijfeld een goed recept voor de oorspronkelijke bedoeling, maar in verhouding tot andere gueuzeproducten weinig complex.

Red-brown and hazy. Thin foam head that quickly disappears.
Aromas are not as fresh and clean as I expected: fruits, caramel, wood and some animal notes that remind the spontaneous fermentation and probably the Brettanomyces touch.
Its a sweet and sour attack in mouth, wooden chips notes (that is definitly not a barrel aging !) then dusty wood again that covers the fruit. Aftertaste is OK: syrup, candy .... I have been used to appreciate this for a while.  Tonight I am a bit disappointed.
Cheers though
UPDATED: OCT 9, 2012 160512 @ DØE Århus Syd Lambic tasting: Light brown beer without fragrance. sweet and a bit sickly. Sweet and sour taste as china sauce..
Pour was copper with a tan head. Aroma was sour champagne and some sweetness. Taste was a little too sweet for me but there was some nice sour apple to balance it a bit. Not too bad.
Dark amber colour. Medium sweet, maybe too sweet. Some sourness but not enough. Overall decent.
Sour vinegar aroma, would be a good sour if it wasnt for the sweetness. Kinda reminds me of a sweet apple cider vinegar.
I dont likey!! It tastes like Air Born or like a sour patch kid got dropped in a good beer.
Pours a dark copper with a sour sweet aroma and small white head. Taste is sour and sweet. Has a green apple flavor.
UPDATED: JAN 23, 2012 Bottle from beerboxer. Smells like vinigar. Slight taste of vinigar then a sweet finish. Color is amber.. Reminds me of dying easter eggs.

I think this is one of the better Faro i tried (after the Cantillion one). There is a sweetness coming from the Candico-sucre but also the typicaly Lambic flavor. Its very well ballanst. Nice head and very nice colour (caramel). The better ones witch you can get very easy.
Bottle. A light sour smell. The head is medium large, white and creamy. The body is dark red. The taste is sweet, later with a light sour finish. The body is light and dry with a lively carbonation.
floral, leaves, vanilla, caramel, orange, minimal head, tan foam, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, medium sourness, umami, lively, thin feel, medium body,

12 oz. bottle.  I finally tracked down a bottle of Lambic - Faro thereby completing all of the styles on Ratebeer.  This beer poured a pretty clear red with a thin-moderate, somewhat fizzy head that left streaky, spotty lace.  Pleasant aroma that was both tart and sweet with notes of berries, leather and sugar.  The flavor is similar with berries, a bit of leather, and sugar.  Bright and lively on the palate.  A bit on the sweet side, definitely more sweet than sour or tart, but I enjoy sweet beers so that was not an issue for me.  Overall, an enjoyable beer.

Pours slightly dark amber with small off white head, nice lacing. Aroma is funky sour sweet, fruity, apples, yeast. Lively carbonation, light body. very sweet/sour like candy first drink especially. Fruity taste, kind of like apple juice, small amount of spice. Very interesting and delicious.

375ml bottle with a cork and a cap. Hazy orange/amber body with a small head. Vinous aroma with some baked apples. Nice bubbly mouthfeel. Taste is sweet and sour, mostly remonds me of apples. Like a mix of champagne and apple juice. Finish is sweet.
A very complex drink, brown reddish color, good head retention, apricot, raisins, a little bit sour but candy sugar balance the beer. Its a pity, that is hard to find...

From the little Faro I had this was not my best.  A lot of sugar and barley. Looked nice, brown colour with no head.  Smelled like barley, tasted barley cereal and sugar. Average mouthfeel.  Drinkable with a good lunch.

Ive always passed up this brew in store but since I want try all styles finally bit the bullet. This beer stunk up entire apartment the begged me to pour down drain.  It pours clear amber withbwhite head.  Tastes of white grapes, grass, medicinal, and tons of rock candy.  Way too sweet for my tastes if I have another faro Ill hope to split with someone

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2012 Nose is winey, earthy with hints of raisin and wood.  Clear, light reddish brown in color.  It is briny, fruity, bittersweet with notes of apricots, pear, apples, and grapes.  It has fruit pit tones and mild caramel maltiness, but dry.  Tart, dry, and drinkable on the finish; nice bitterness.  Thin palate helps amilerate the sour notes aiding consumption.  Overall, pleasant sour character; strong but clean finish.  A fruity sour joy to drink, but not great for having more than one of.  Truly enjoyed the brew and it was far more complex than I was expecting, yet it didnt come together as well as I would have liked.
Bottle from cerveceria internacional, seville, spain. Red/orange/amber color. Very thni head. Medium to high sweetness. High carbonation as it was expected. Fruited and water aroma.

375ml.  Pours a thin light brown/dark amber with out much head.  Aroma of caramelized sugar, coffee, lemon, toffee and some crazy acidic tartness.  Light bodied, yet really sweet, this beer tastes like someone poured packets of sugar in the raw in a gueuze, which is what I guess what it practically is.   Super sweet, yet still slightly tart.  Interesting.

Bottle.  Clear, golden tan in color with a small white head.  Funky aroma with a bunch of yeast and wheat present as well.  First sip, and I have realized that faro is my least favorite of the lambic styles.  Shit is sweet!  Fruity, candy sugar is predominant in the flavor, and finishes nice and tart.  The tartness in the finish makes me want more, but the sweetness that comes before it is really tough to take.

Another first for the evening for me in the new year; a faro-style lambic!  LIndemans was again the brewery that benefited from my first taste of this style.  Their faro poured an amber color with rich and creamy beige head.  The head left some nice lacing at first, but not much after the first couple of sips.  The nose was really fruity and yeasty, with some cherries, blackberries, earth, leather and rye bread notes.  The mouthfeel was spritzy and well-carbonated.  The flavors were a nice combination of sweet, sour and tart, with some fruity notes of cherries and berries.  I also got some bitter and sour tones.  The beer finished very tart and a bit on the sour side.  This beer was very refreshing and enjoyable.

12oz bottle in a flute.  Pours amber with a fluffy, light beige head.  Aroma of spicy yeast, light fruit, some sweet tarts, the candy sugar, and light hops.  Flavor about the same, but its really sweet.  Bubbly.  A decent beer.
Clear amber coloured beer with small whtie head and no carbonation. Sour fruited aroma. Full sweet palate. Finish is cherry fruited ending slight sour sweet.
This is a beer for beginner. It is very light and not very tasty. A good beer to begin.
Bottle. Pours a medium brown with mild carbonation and a small head. The flavor is mildly sweet and sticky.  Decent overall.

Amber colored beneath a frothy white head. Musty cellar aroma, hints of sweet fruits. Sweet, but certainly not cloying. A little bit of green apple tartness with some faint peach and oak. Not much acidity to speak of. Not great, but a pleasant enough drink.
Bottled. Pours a dark amber with a thin 2 finger head. Aroma of wood and sweet peach. Starts almost syrupy sweet, but quickly goes to a lemon like tart finish. Interesting.

The aroma is not all that big. A tinge bit of fruitiness and maybe a little spice. It pours a clear plum color. There is no real lacing or head. Sticks to itself. It is much more sweet than sour. A bit too sweet for my liking.

This is the base recipe they use for their fruit lambics. Very cider like. More for cooking than drinking. Way too sweet and one dimensional. The sugar sticks to your lips like cough syrup. Gets better as it warms. Slight plum flavor. Nice color. I added freshly pressed apple juice to mine.

33cl botle. Brown colour with a beige head that at the beginning has good formation but quickly diminishes. Aroma is oakness, fruity and sweet. Flavour is fruity, where apples and cherries are present, with a final slightly bittery and dry. Carbonation is lively. Body is medium.

Sweet and sour aroma with maybe a little citrus.  Flavors starts very sweet with a little fruit and wood.  Sour and carbonation give balance and a nice mouthfeel.  First time Ive ever tried a Faro--will try again.

Clear amber body with thin white head. Aroma is floral and to me smells like candied cherries. Taste is sweet at first but finishes with a cranberry tartness. Sweet but not cloying. Nice beer to break up your normal beers. Lingers on your palate and has a fizzy mouthfeel. Some lacing. Very enjoyable to split with the wife.

375 ml dark green bottle with silver foil top, capped and corked. ABV is 4.2%. Soon available at Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. Golden brown colour, moderate to low white head. Aroma of malts, cellar, fruit and kandij sugar, hints of oak. The flavour is fruity, moderately acidic and quite sweet, sugary and oaky notes. Faro is maybe not my favourite beer style, but this is a nice "change of pace" beer.

This little 25cl bottle pours clear copper with white head. The aroma is on the sweet side with inviting notes of yeasty tartness backed by slightly funky to stale cherries and slightly moldy, sticky  and oozing plums and musty basement. The taste begins with a sweet/tart like cherry and sweet green apple candy note. Behind those notes are moderate layers of sour lemon / lime, tart yeastiness and then a big more sweet sugar like notes attempting to even this out. It ends on the dry side as the moderate tartness and sourness leave the palate fairly dry into the after taste with lingering notes of lemon, ripe sweet green apple and cherry.
sweet sour aroma,red golden,clear, white foam, medium sweetness, lightly sour, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, sweet finish.

Bottle 25cl.
Pours a clear bronze colour with almost no head.
Nice faro, bit too sweet for my taste.

AROMA: not very big, hints of fruit and spice; APPEARANCE: pours clear brown with decent head and effervescent; TASTE: sour and sweet and  strong bitterness; PALATE: smooth, medium body, slightly spiked tongue, longish bitter-sweet finish; OVERALL: it is a pleasant enough beer, not that distinctive.

375ml bottle, dark amber-copper, with a bubbly beige head, sweet and sour, wet oaky nose, with some caramelized candi sugar, ripe apple fruity accents, and some faint dust, funky, sweet lemon tea notes in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a nice ripe fruity apple, sweet and sour, caramelized candi sugar character with a big quenching effervescent carbonated mouthfeel, with some faint wheaty, caramel maltiness, woody, oak flavours, and a musty caramelized apple skin, funky yeastiness backbone, leading towards a sweet and sour, caramelized ripe apple, light wet oakiness finish.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2015 Tasted from bottle into tulip glass. Poured a clear, reddish-amber color with strong carbonation but slight head and some lace. Aromas of bread, toast, toffee, caramelized brown sugar, almost no hops. Nice malty-sweet flavor, fruity with slightly sour champagne bite. Light body, spritzy mouthfeel, long-lasting complex aftertaste. Delicious.

Draft, Beveridge Place Pub.  Cloudy brownish amber, small white head.  Smells like a sweet gueuze, a bit of funk, lemon,  sweet and sour apple.  More sugary sweet at the start than it smells, moving to sweet apple and berry flavors, tart lemon, some lambic funky earthiness in there.  Interesting and surprisingly drinkable, but I think I prefer other styles of lambic more.

bottle  poured a red brown color with a ring of tan head on the glass. aroma has light acidity, candy sugar, sweet fruit, and some basement funk. mouth feel is light but has some texture and the carbonation somewhat low. flavor has an acidic base but the sugar just cuts right through it. mild damp funk and some fruits mix in with it finishing drying but the sugar hangs on. has some soda qualities and although interesting is a bit on the sweet side for my liking.
Sampled at the Bayous Wild and Sour ale tasting. Vinegar was the most dominating trait of this beer. There was a spicy and sugary aroma. Not a fan of this beer.

A:Smells like sweet apple, delicious.
T: A complex balance of sweetness and sourness.  
O:Not for everyone but I absolutely love this beer.

375 ml purchased at Winooski Beverage Warehouse (Vermont), on August 2, 2011. Pale brown, medium head that disappeared quickly. Barley aroma of sweet fruit notes slightly sour. Taste of bittersweet fruis barley and, sweet notes of herbs, aftertaste of ripe fruit. A nice little sweet lambic!

Bottle 37,5 cl....it pours hazy reddish brown body with a big very creamy light red head.... the aroma is sweet, fruit and sour... the flavor is sweet, fruity, honey and sour.....medium body, medium carbonation... sweet fruity and sour finish....

Bottle.  Pours reddish amber with a medium-sized off-white head.  Aroma is sweet/sour.  Flavor is mildly fruity (peach?), fairly sour, some lemon peel, not much funk, quite sweet.  Dont have much experience with faros, but I like it.  Very refreshing -- almost drinks like a soda.  Highly carbonated.  Extra candy sugar makes for a full but not heavy mouthfeel.

Pours a dark, hazy plum color with amber edges and a fizzy half finger head and that quickly settles into a thin ring. Not much in the way of lacing.

Syrupy sweet aroma with some slight earthy funky. Lots of sweet artificial medicine and candy syrup with some pale malts and dark fruits.

On the lighter end of medium bodied and very sweet with lots of artificial sweetness. Lots of candy sugar and syrup with subtle tart funk and sweet dark fruit. Hints of cherry, grape and other dark berries produce an overwhelming sweetness that lingers into a slight dry finish.

Bottle. Greyish amber with a quickly dissipating head. Aroma is of dry white wine, apples, subtle vinegar and elderflower. Reminds me partly of dark rum, partly of port wine. Taste is a bit drier than the Lindemans fruit lambics, sourish, vinous, flowery and fruity. Also sweet but this side is matched by the sourness. A bit dry finish with an aftertaste of plums and port wine. Excellent!

Murky amber with a fluffy, small pinkish head. Nice sugary sour smell. Sticky sweet flavor at first, changing quite tart as the carbonation hits your mouth. Very enjoyable but extremely sugary. Sticky palate due to all of the sugar. Tartness coats the mouth. Very fruity.

pours a pale rose color with not head or lacing.  aroma is fresh berries and sugar.  taste is sour cherry, candy sugar, with a strong yeast presence.  there is a great deal of sweetness but just a bit of bitter to balance out the act, especially once the yeast is added.   finish is tart and sticky.

An orange-red pour with a small white head.  The aroma is fruity with some lemon and a winelike quality.  The medium body has a slick texture with average carbonation.  The taste is initially sweet, then tart.  It seems more like juice with a dry finish.  Not quite my style.

25 cL bottle from ABS Drinks in Winksele, poured into a Westmalle glass at home.  Amber/red beer with very little head.  Warm, sweet and slightly sour beer, with lots of candy and reasonable body.  The bottle I had stated the alcohol was 4.2%.  A very weak sweet aroma, 5/10 given as its hard to detect.  Quite nice for a change, but I couldnt imagine drinking more than one it a particular sitting as its so sweet.  Not as sour as I would expect for a lambic type beer - albeit faro.  None-the-less pleasant and different.

In bottle. Pours an amber colour with a beige head that dies away fairly quickly. Aroma is quite nice with lemon peel and horse-blanket geuze qualities. The flavour is sweeter than the nose lets on. A bit shocking at first but Im getting used to it. The flavours are sweet, sour and also a little bitter. The mouth-feel is foamy with mild carbonation and CO2 prickle and a lingering balsamic vinegar tartness. A good example of my least favourite lambic style.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2011 21/10/2011 25cl bottle @ home -  BB: 22/6/2013 (2011-573)
Clear amber to copper beer, small off-white head, unstable, non adhesive. Aroma: fruity, little lemony, bitter, oranges, basement. MF: little carbon, light to medium body. Taste: wow, this beer actually tastes like barf, fresh out of your stomach. Then theres sweet sugar, lemon, bitter chemical touches and bitter oranges. Aftertaste: still barf. Pretty nasty.

Faro?  I guess Ill give it a shot.  It pours a clear amber, with a very slight head that fades away to nothing very quickly.  It smells of sour fruit, slightly rotten with a funk that will put a boys high school locker room to shame.  When I taste it, it does not live up to its sour expectations.  It is sour yet sweet at the same time.  The addition of candi sugar smooths it out here.  In fact, this is sweeter than I would like it to be.  This almost tastes like McDonalds sweet and sour sauce.  And not in a good way.   This may be a faro, but it is not very good in my opinion.

Reviewed 08-20-2010.  Pour is light and coppery, with a thin foamy white head that rapidly dissipates. Smell is classic lambic, very similar to the Cuvee Rene -- slight citric tartness, grassy notes, a little peach/apricot in the finish. Taste starts off with lactic tartness, accented by the ample carbonation, and gives way to a sweet starchy fruit flavor and a slightly funky finish. High carbonation and thin body make this almost soda-like. Drinkability is much higher than expected -- Im not typically a fan of the sweeter lambics, but the sweet/sour balance in this is spot-on and the sugar is not at all cloying or saccharine. I know itll never happen... but it would be pretty great to get this in cans for the summer.

My first and likely only (for awhile) faro. My assumption is that Lindemans pasteurizes it like their fruit beers, which would be the only way of stopping the flora from consuming the sugar and blowing up the bottle. Not a true faro, but Im glad to have tried it.

12oz bottle from Pinch poured into a snifter...because I can. Pours a nut brown with a half finger of off-white head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is very sour. Sour cherries and sour apples. Taste is medium-heavy sweet and medium-heavy sour. Strong taste of cherry. Almost reminds me of a cherry Warheads candy from way back. Medium bodied with a thick yet slick texture. Also kinda sticky. Soft carbonation and a long sour finish. Overall, very good. Ive got to find more faro beers.

Pour copper with light beige head and good lace. Aroma sour, peppery, wood, cherry, funk, wine. Taste quite sweet, sour, cherry, candy sugar, wood, funk, fruity. MF light to medium body good carb. Good beer very sweet interesting style not my cup of beer.

Dark copper/red/orange, thin white head vanishes immediately. Nose is slightly dominated by the candy - toffee, ripe fruit, hint of peppery sourness. Similar flavours, nice sour hint and good carbonation. Good example of the style, but its not my favourite style.

Im always down to try a new style, so here is my first Faro. Shared with zep9865 during a mini tasting. This beer pours an orangish amber in color with a light cream colored lacing around the glass. It is very clear and translucent. It smells like it should be tasty. It smells of candied fruit and has some syrupy raspberry to it. The flavors are very sweet but not too sweet. As zep said, my girlfriend would love this. It is so flavorful and full of sweet fruits. Its almost like a fruity soda and reminds me of cherry Dr. Pepper. It is a little sticky on the palate but I guess I should expect that from such a sweet beer. This is a tasty beer and worthy trying to knock out a new style.

Dark cotton-candy pour with a razor thin white wad that leaves immediately.  Aroma of sour plum/cherry skin, completely opposite the flavor.  As with most Lindemans, this is likely a sugary example of the style.  Caramel, cane sugar, and honey dominate.  Dont get much else, unfortunately.  Quite syrupy.

amber pour with thin white head. some sour funk in the aroma. flavour was dominated by the sweetness, Belgium candy I assume. some sour funk hidden behind the candy. way way to sweet for me, cloying, couldnt even finish half the bottle.  did not like

The pour is amber with a lot of floaters, small lacing head. The aroma is fruity, wine like with cherry and a hint of funk. The flavor is similar, wine like with a bit of that funk in the back ground. Good one.

still not a big fan of the style, but this is a decent beer i guess. Pours a clear watery red with a tiny white head. Sweeter than I expected, still has that barn yard funk that Im not a big fan of. I like this better than a gueze but will not be making a major effort to try this style again.
Bottle. Light red color with a small creamy head. Fruity aroma. Sour slightly sweet taste.

355ml bottle, corked and capped. Pours a deep, dark amber color with an off white head. Aroma is sour, yeasty, tart cherry. Medium on the palate with soft carbonation. Flavor is a nice balance of sweet and sour, A little sour cherry, sugar, fruity. Interesting.

Bottle.  Pours a brown sugar brown with a one inch head.  Smells strongly of sour yeasts.  Taste is sweet.  Medium carbonation and light body.  Tastes a lot like Duchesse De Bourgenne without the malt vinegar intensity.

The pour is a bright yellowish - orange with a finger of the purest white head Ive ever seen on a beer. The head subsides to a thin cap slowly. The nose is sweet and mildly sour with a candied sugar note and light malts. Thorough sweetness with mild sourness and fruity finish. Medium bodied with a oil like moutyhfeel. Overall, a nice sour beer, but a bit too sweet perhaps.

My bottle (250ml) shared with HogTownHarry & garthicus. Pours a deep orange-amber with a small diminishing bubbly off-white head. Nice aroma, quite fruity and a bit sour along with some sugary sweetness. Flavour is surprisingly fruity and a bit sour along with a slightly tart finish -- lovely really. Average bodied. I really enjoyed this, quite nice on a warm Summer day.
Bottle, pours a nice a yellow, aroma is sweet, taste is very typical faro with a bit extra sweetness, good offering

375ml bottle at 4.2%.  Pours dark caramel with a small head.  Aroma is sweet vinegar and some woody notes.  Not over the top.  Taste has sour lemons to start, then strong candy sugars and a sweet vinegar finish.  Some Sharp lemon on the aftertaste.
Pours a medium brown with a small pale head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is toffee, apples, wood. Taste is sweet - apples, pears, candi sugar, and a touch of vinegar sourness.
