Pours a dark golden colour with a thin head. Aroma is sweet sugary almost pear notes. Taste is a nice balance of sweet sugar and sour aftertaste.
I quite liked this. Mildly hazy pale chestnut brown colour. Smells of candy. Sweet-sharp candy-floss flavours with hint of hazel or walnuts.

Clear and light brown with almost no head from the bubbly, soda like body. Raisin, sour green apple, bubblegum and grains. Sweet with only a light sourness in the middle. Short aftertaste. Easy to drink and quite enjoyable. (375ml bottle)

Golden amber pour clear to pale with thin off white head ... smells like a barnyard and tastes like belgian candi sugar very sweet and light sour funky apples some caramel qualities ... not very good sugary and dry with a dry sour/sweet finish meh

Clear copper colour, extremely lively, white head. Aroma is nicely balanced between acidic and sweet. Some wine and wood notes along with some berries. Flavour is nicely balanced as well, with the sour notes along with the sweetness. Grapes, berries and a subtle mustiness. Very refreshing and enjoyable.

Date: September 5, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Discount Liquor, Milwaukee, WI Appearance: Orangish brown, slight amount of head and some sediment. Aroma: Fruity, maybe apple. Flavor: Consistent with aroma but also some vinegar, slight carbonation but smooth, almost like a sparkling wine or champagne. Other: Thanks to BVery for sharing, this was a difficult style to find!

Bottle. Moderate notes of hay, flowers, perfume and mustiness fot the major component, with back ground note of cherry, red wine, vinegar, berries and an overall sangria essence. Head is average size, creamy/frothy, white with no lacing and is almost fully diminishing. Color is clear medium red. Flavor starts lightly to moderately sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes lightly to moderately sweet and moderately acidic and bitter. Palate is medium, watery with soft carbonation. Again, this is not one of my favorite styles, but this one definitely shows the craftsmanship it takes to making a quality Faro Lambic.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2014 Bottle from Discount Liquor in Milwaukee, WI. Semi hazy orange/amber pour with a smallish frothy white head. Sediment was noticeable. Nose of red apple and maybe a touch of vinegar. Medium palate with higher carbonation. Taste was white grape, apple, tart cherry - almost sparking wine like (good call Darcy Folty!). Little bit of astringency late. Good stuff, and.....my 73rd and last beer style rating! Whoo hoo!

Thanks to Blankboy. Appearance: Hazy copper, small off white head. Aroma: Slightly sour, good fruitiness, caramel & a little tart. Flavour: Nice apple/fruit flavour at first, quite sweet and candy like, some good maltiness there too with a long sweet finish.

250ml bottle shared by blankboy with me and garthicus.  Slightly hazy brownish-amber with an average frothy off-white diminishing head.  Aroma of raisin, brown sugar, lemon juice and yeast - fairly sweet and fruity, but appealing.  Taste is sweeter, a bit of vinegar tartness, almost like raisin and apple jack extra sour.  Syrupy and light, nice acidity and carbonation, quick finish, fruity tart aftertaste.  Nice one!!

An off-white head (that stayed present for a while) and a caramel red body.  The aroma is spicy, sweet, and yeasty.  The flavor is sugar-sweet without being overwhelming, and the yeast, malt, and spices are present too, almost giving the flavor a dessert bread-like quality.  I dont normally care for lambics, but this is one I could drink on occasion.  Very interesting.
Small bottle like the one pictured. Poured clear light brown with little head that retained. Light sweetness followed by sweet fruit notes. Very nice and enjoyable.

355ml bottle from 16th St. Liquor in West Vancouver. Pours a clear amber, high carbonation wipes out the head entirely right after the pour. Aroma is slightly reminiscent of ginger beer mixed with cider. Taste is both sweet and tart, a baked apple pie without the cinnamon quality. Slight spice note though hard to identify. Leaves a slight stickiness on the tongue in the finish. Tasty.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a slightly hazy copper color with a thin tan head. The aroma is apple juice, oranges, ginger ale, and a little biscuity yeast. The flavor is very sweet, tart, with just a slightly sour finish. The body is light to medium. The palate is sticky, and just a little astringent. Medium carbonation. Very little aftertaste. Overall, this is a smooth drinking, well balanced, and delicious beer.

I had pulled this one off the shelf a few weeks ago, removed the cap only to discover that I didnt have a corkscrew.  So I put it back on the shelf. Today I got the corkscrew out of the moving box and grabbed the Faro off the shelf. To my horror I discover that the cork had worked its way out at some point in the past few weeks!  But, I figured that this is a wild ale anyways, so what the heck.  

Pours a deep mahogany with light carbonation and a small fizzy head (!!!) Aroma is granny smith apples, mildly sour, other light fruits, and a touch of funk.  Flavor is quite sugary, with a slightly sour/tart finish.  Very sweet and appley, but still, very good!

Skunky up front, then turns into a fruity aroma.  The appearance is medium amber and clear.  The flavor is mildly sour, with apple juice and raspberry in there.  Good, very different from most other beers and ales, but the green bottle detracted from the score, would have been much better in a brown bottle.
Pours dark and clear golden with a low head. Aroma is apples. Flavor is sweet and sour apples with a hint of vinegar. Very interesting.

Pours an amber/lt. Ruby color with a medium lt. Tan head...nice retention.  Aroma hints of sour cherries and leather with underlying sweet candy sugar and funk.  Flavor is much sweeter than the aroma suggests...dominated by light candy sugar but not so sweet that its sticky...slight sour notes, hint of caramel and funk.  Mouthfeel is light with a sweet and sour finish that drys out into mild funk.  I like it!
This is not my style of lambic and this is not the best example of its style either. Too sweet for someone like me.

375ml bottle 2010. Light amber, small bubbles that disappear very quickly, off white head. Bit sweet, some funk, white sugar and tang. No carbonation, incredibly smooth and easy to drink, almost apple cider like - blend of sweet and tang, very refreshing with a good long finish. Worth trying.

Bottle. Pours clear amber with a short off-white head. Aroma was sweet and slightly sour with sugar, fruit, lemon, wild yeast, and funk. Taste was sweet and sour with apples, sugar, a bit of caramel and a touch of tartness with a dry finish.

(37.5 cl bottle from Carrefour Marché @ Saint-Cyprien) Pours a clear amber with medium, white head that lasts but doesnt leave any curtains. Aroma is metallic and tart with notes of stomach acid. Taste is very sour and unpleasant to me. Oily on the palate, medium carbonation with a full, sour body and a sour finish. I had to pour it but its most likely because I dont appreciate the style. Girlfriend says: "it tastes better than it smells but its not really very pleasant with this strong sweetness followed by a strong bitterness."

Amber pour with a bubbly off white head. Mildly sour finishing with a sticky sweetness. There is the lactobacillus sourness, but not much else in the way of funk. The underlying sweetness might be covering some of that up.

Clear amber with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and moderate sour. Flavor is quite sweet, moderate sour and moderate acidic. Dry and moderate acidic finish. Gets a little sugary, but all in all a nice faro. 100811

25 cl. btl.: Label said 4,2 %!?!? light head and very little carbonation semidark golden. Nose with apple, lemon curd and marzipan. medium body with some sweet length.Taste with sweet apple cider and a little sourness int aftertaste, orange confit.Not a typical lambic - but good! Especially after some time in the glass where the sweetnes withdraws a little.
Sweet fruity aroma. Clear dark orange color with a small white head. Sweet beginning that fades slightly but also quickly gets tart after the initial sweet.

Dieses Faro steckt in einer verkorkten 0,375l-Flasche. 
Ein weißweinartiger Geruch mit einer Ahnung nach Apfel macht sich breit. 
Der Geschmack süß-säuerlich, apfelwein-betont. Das Basis-Lambic kommt noch ganz gut zum Zuge. 
Ein schönes Faro, das prima über die Zunge geht.Test vom 14.1.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche

Disappointing.  Pours a shimmering amber-brown.  Aroma is tart barnyard, slight caramel.  Flavor is sweet like the other Lindemans, excepting the gueze.  A big sweet sour caramel that could almost be fruity.  Underneath it is a nice barnyard funk, tart and horsey.  I feel like Im missing out on my first example of this style.

On tap at Cheeky Monk in Denver on 7/30/11. Copper hued, with slight haze and a small creamy head. Smells like oak and light lemon citrus. Deep sour aroma. Not pungent, just complex and not easily figured out. Flavor of creamy vanilla yogurt over a sour apple, with a little extra sour at the finish, light fruit like apricot in the middle as well. Pretty sweet and creamy, with a delightful sour fruit twang.

clear amber with no head. aroma is sweet and fruity. some apricot pulp...like a sweetened flemish. flavor is similar and is also like a heavily sweetened flemish. big apple juice and over-ripe fruits...tastes a lot lot the melbourne bro beers..

Poured from 375mL bottle amber with short lived white head and no lacing.  Aromas of yeast and caramel.  Taste is quite sweet initially with a very mild hop bitterness at the finish.  Body is light and carbonation is lively.

Aroma brings some funky, sweet yeast notes with a little carmel apple.  Very clear with a tea-like red/brown color.  Very short-lived thin white head.  As intended, sweet but with a nice sour balance as the taste progresses.  Again some sense of a dry green apple behind the sweetness.  Despite the upfront  sugar, still manages to finish rather dry.  Rich prickly carbonation.  A fine dessert.
Amber with a white head. Smells fruity and tastes fruity like candy. It is overly sweet.

355ml bottle, my last unrelated style, hizzah! Pours a deep amber golden with a small frothy off white head. Aroma is sharp and fruity, a bit vinous, a touch of vinegar, a nice funk and dark fruitiness. Flavor starts great, sharp and funky, tart and dark fruits. Towards the finish the sweet sugar takes over and it still has some funk, but its like the dark fruits were just dumped with sugar and it makes for an easy but slightly boring finish. A slight grape sticky sweetness lingers. Medium body and a soft but prickly carbonation. Interesting beer, I enjoy a lot of the aspects of it
I expected this to be awful but it was far from that. Not great, but lets say pretty doable. Nice red / brown color, not the worst smell and taste, ok carbo and body.

My first and only Faro style that I tried, so I really dont have anything to compare it too.  I love the Lindemans line, and this one was no different.  Amber in color, fruity aroma, sweet taste.  I enjoy limbic style, has the right balance of sweetness and tart finish.  Overall, I enjoyed this brew, I would like a few more of this style to compare.  This brew is not as popular as the framboise and krieks.
Like sugarwater. Not the choice if you want a refreshing beer, but if you crave for candy, this might just do it.

Bottle split with mcberko. Pours a clear orange/mahogany with a fine white lacing. Aroma of soured fruits, funk, some apple, candied sugar. Flavour is lightly sour, some creamy cheese, apple, candied sugar, and some funk. A lot smoother texture than I was expecting - not as sour. Dry mouth feel, and quite a lot of sweetness, but not cloying, which moderates the sour. Nice.

Bottle, purchased from La Bodega in Anchorage, AK. Murky sediment-laden orange-brown body, thin off-white ring of carbonation. Rindy nose, with brie cheese, horse blanket, and sawdust, funky and tart, with modest appleskin. Dusty body but distinctly sweetened; tastes like apple juice with a bit of medicinal funk. Soft and flabby, barely sour.
Barnyardy tart lemon tea aromas.  Candy sugar blasts the palate initially which is followed iced tea with a touch of lemon.  Reminds me of sweet tea with lemon which I had in Alabama.

Appearance: rusty brown, small fizzy off-pink head, minimal lacing.   Aroma: malt, sweet-tart candies, hint of maraschino syrup.   Taste: a bit of fruit (raspberry, cherry, sour apple?), but mainly a kind of sweet malt character over a puckering sour tang with a bit of almost saison-like funk.  Finish: dry yet sticky, malty and puckeringly tart with a nice sweet balance.   Notes: 	A sweet and sour sauce of a beer.  I know Faros are generally light on fruit, but there was some definite fruit characteristics here; maybe from the wild yeast?  Either way, I really dug it in a weird kind of way.  Very sweet, but also very sour/tart, with a great level of carbonation to keep it quaffable.  Rating 4 for now, but Ill revisit with a jaundiced and suspicious eye.  Did I REALLY like this as much as I thought I did?

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2012 Refrigerated bottle poured into a white wine glass.  Pours clear amber with big off-white head that dissapates quickly.  Medium lacing, medium body, slightly sticky texture, and fruity aroma.  Taste is sweet fruit (mostly berry) to start, dark candy sugar, and slightly tart fruit in the finish.

Csak a jó Sör, Budapest. Ködös, vörösesbarna színe van, fehér habja gyorsan eltűnik, kicsit olyan pezsgős a megjelenése. Illata almás, de inkább almaboros, igencsak cukros, és már egy cider jutna eszembe, de a maláta egyértelmű aromája szintén jelen van. Íze szintén almaboros (azért egy jobbféle), malátás, illetve karamellás. Egyszerre fanyar és cukrosan édes, ami nekem nem feküdt túlzottan, de azért nem rossz.

Bottle. Clear nut brown body, with a small white head. Aroma:taste of leather, farmyard, wood, sour cherries, acid, with a sweet body. Full bodied. Leaves a "furry" fealing in you mouth at the end of the beer.
I didnt expect the sweetness, noting that more than the sourness behind it.  Color was nice, a good red/brown, and the palate was like a bizarre lemonade.  A good intro lambic.

Pours ruby red from bottle with an inch of light brown head that rapidly disapates. Lots of carbonation on the tongue. The nose is pungent with an undertone of sweetness. On the tongue theres some sourness but also a touch of sugar as well. This one lingers for a long time. Nice change of pace from the fruit lambics.

Draft @ Sunset Grill and Tap, Alston, MA. Clear yellow with thin white head.  Aroma is sweet. Taste is also sweet but with a hint of corn and cough syrup. Not bad but wouldnt drink again. Shared with AirForceHops.

Draft @ Sunset Grill and Tap, Alston, MA.  Served in a flute. Poured a deep amber-red, almost brown with head that had good retention and nice lace. Slightly carbonated. Aroma was a mix of wild yeast, esters and sugar. Initial flavor was slightly tart with some sweetness. Sweetness seemed to come though much more as it got room temperature. Lots of a berry flavor. I like it and will seek out a few more of this style since this was my 1 st.
Transparent light amber color with thin layer of white head. Sour aroma of champagne and cork. Sweet cotton candy like malty flavor with nice cherry tartness. Could use some additional carbonation.

In my search to get the award for all styles, i had to try this lambic as i am not a huge fan. I bought a bottle to share with a couple friends who all enjoyed it. I thought it was very sweet with a good flavor of sugar and candy.

Pours clear amber  color with a very fizzy and quickly disappearing off-white head.  Aroma is very sweet with some fruity, almost raisin-y funk.  As I anticipated, the funk is pretty mild compared to a lot of lambics.  Flavor is malty with a sort of apply cider character to it.  A little sour bite, but pretty mild.  A slight spritz to it.  Has an interesting finish to it.  Not necessarily dry, but something like it?  A very faint bitterness too.  Im actually pleasantly surprised, as I havent been a huge fan of a lot of the Faros Ive tried.

Poured a mostly clear amber-red color with a nice white head that had good retention and nice lace.  A slight carbonated appearance.  Aroma was a mix of wild yeast, esters and sugar.   Initial flavor was slightly tart with some sweetness.  Sweetness seemed to grow slightly strong not enough to dominate the tartness but enough to give the beer some edge.   Beer seemed to have a thin mouth feel, but actually coated the palate.  Nice.

I dont know why, but I associate the colors on the label with the color of the beer for the Lindemans beers.  So this did not pour black, but rather brown-red with a whitish cover.  Aroma is lightly tart, but largely sweet, caramelized malt.  Taste is light liquid sugar.  Lots of sugar, there is a light acidity trying to fight through, but it fails.  Not bad, but largely devoid of any depth.
Pours an amber-copper body with a lasting beige head.  Aromas and flavors of a Red Delicious Apple, some bereft notes.  Slightly sour.  Finish has a tea note.

Looks innocuous enough, pouring a lovely clear copper with a thin white head that subsides quickly. Where it differs is the antiseptic sting on the nostrils upon opening, even before nosing properly. (This is my first faro lambic, can you tell?). Has that lovely distinctive lambic tang of berryfruit juice and a hint of armpit.
Tastes juicy, tangy and almost as if it has cherries and raspberries in it. While the sourness isnt mouth puckering and doesnt turn your mouth inside out, this is inviting and tasty. Thoroughly enjoyable.
Expected this one to be a lot more sour than it is. This one tastes pretty nice and is easy to drink for almost everyone.

Dark golden/amber with a small white head that goes away fast - aroma is of sweets, but olso with a sour note in the back - taste is of a very good combination of sweet and sour - this was very good and very drikable

12 ounce bottle.  Pours a orange amber with a small white head.  Aroma of tart fruit, balsamic vinegar, malt and yeast.  Taste is a complex mix of cherries, malt, citrus and sugar.  Starts sweet and ends tart.  Not sure what to make of this style.  Interesting for sure.

Poured from bottle into my Founder snifter glass. Dark brown color with a thin head and what seemed to be good carbonation. Fruity aroma, hints of sugar and candy. Flavor wasnt as sweet as I was expecting. Fruity mostly. A  pleasant and relaxing beer.

Bottle. Pours a dark amber color with small head that is quick to fade. Aroma was green apples, and an acidic vinegar note. Flavor was green apples, sugar, candies, and acid. There was a slight tartness but it was out done by the sweetness. Drinkable but too sweet for me to truly enjoy.

12 oz bottle.  Pours clear amber with a very slightly off-white head.  Somewhat sour and funky aroma with lemon, brown sugar, and cherry.  Flavor is sugary and somewhat sour, tart cherry, lemon, brown sugar, a little herbal, and a little dusty.  Kind of alternates between slightly strange and pleasant, but it spends more time on the pleasant side.  Not bad.  (And now I just need to rate a malt liquor to finish all current beer styles.)
Poured from a bottle. This is just an odd beer. A bit sour, but the foot influence is too much for me. I cant say I would want to try this again.

Etwas süßer Antrunk, der Unterton ist minimal sauer. Der Geuze-Grundton ist anfänglich noch vorhanden, verschwimmt aber nach und nach. Im Mittelteil ist die Süße nun deutlich führend, dadurch wird das Faro etwas künstlicher. Dieser Eindruck verstärkt sich im Abgang deutlich, hier wird das Bier süßer, künstlicher und muffig. 	 
Test vom 8.12.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 9,8,10,9,10,9 - 9,05
Nice brown colour with small head. Medium carbonation. Aromas of apple and pear. Taste is heavy sweet with hints of apple. Some dryness. Refreshing

Bottle pours deep red-amber with a khaki colored head.  Aroma is sweet/tart with notes of caramel, candi sugar, wood, and a touch of funk.  Flavor shows the same with additional notes of apple, cherry, and overripe peach.  Overall body is moderate with fairly heavy sweetness. A little too sweet for my liking, but still pretty good nonetheless.
25cl bottle at home. Pours attractive orange copper with a thin cream head. Nose is sweet and fruity, as is the flavor. Not too sweet though, with a delicate mouthfeel and decent dry finish.

bottle.  Pours a clear red rust color with nice orange tinted head.  Aroma not as sweet as expected, there are some vinous, funky tones here, soft balsamic, but also present is a candy like sweetness, which combined give a sensation of candied tart apples.  Flavor is sweet / sour, starting with the sweet, a sugary candy like flavor, reminding me of hard candy, i.e. the outside candy part of M&Ms.  Then on the finish there are light tart notes, leaving a soft, acidic puckering sensation in the mouth, with notes of cherry.  Reminded me alot of liefmans cuvee brut.  Overall I actually really enjoyed this, very nice.

Sweet and sour on the nose, mild acidic tartness with sugar notes.  Pours a golden amber with a very thin white head.  Tart upfront with a nice acidity followed by sugary sweetness.  Not nearly as sweet as I thought it would be, there is some tartness and acidity.  The finish starts out dry but a last bit of sweetness kicks in.  Not bad compared to the other faro Ive tried.
Kind of red and not much head.  Aroma is fruity and the taste is like raspberries, but not as light.  Its sweet and the finish is more fruit flavor.

Pours a slightly hazy reddish orange color with a smallish bone white head that slowly dissipates to a cap. Smell is sweet with candied cherries and darker pitted fruits but with a sourish funk in there as well. Taste is sweet with dark fruits, hints of caramel, some mild gym socks. Sweet turns to a slight tartness about mid way through, then leaves a long lingering candy sweetness. Light to medium level of carbonation, sweet sticky mouthfeel, medium body. This one is pretty good although I thought it a little on the sweet side. If this were a bit funkier it would be better.

355 ml. bottle. shared with Gabe. Pours a thin off white head of short duration, over a clear, amber (SRM 10) body....nose is light funk, light grape, hint of raisin, slightly musty....taste is light sweet to start, becoming, lightly sour, bit of tartness, finishing with a musty sweetness, reminiscent of raisin...mouth feel light of medium, carbonation low. This meets its style and is, although sweet, is nicely complex. BJCP 7/3/14/4/7

Bottle 375ml. Great aromas, a bit too sweet for me. Aromas of grapes, apple, honey, and cheese. Taste is sweet, with light bitterness, and long length. Palate is velvety, with a medium body, and high carbonation. Amber, bubbly, with a thin head.

So adding sugar to a sour beer turns it into a completely different monster.  I hate to say it, but, with a sweet Lambic like Faro, the beverage ends up tasting remarkably like a wine cooler.  Im sure this declaration sounds like heresy to many a soul, but Lambics whose only trait is that theyve been sweetened to soft drink levels are not my cup of tea.  Smells great, looks decent, very thin mouthfeel, even for a sub 5% beer.  Glad I can tick this style off the chart and move on.

First theres foil, then theres a cap, then a cork. What are they taking such pains to protect? It starts out similar to other lambics in its sourness. The finish is what varies, with some sweetness, some caramel. Lots of flavor, and its a bit like jamming your mouth wit a random mix of hard candy (at least one a green apple jolly rancher). I think the mouthfeel is just right for a refreshing, warm weather drink.
Bottle. Clear amber with small off-white head. Flavour is malt, sweet, little sour, little tart, fruit and syrup.

07.07.2011. 0,25l bottle in Paris. Aroma is sour with very fruity flavours. Very refreshing beer with good flavours! This beer has a lot off the same flavours as a white vine. There is also maltyness, malt sweetness and there is this vinous flavour from the yeast. Very very very good beer!
Sugary sour beer.  A very nice, for me, alternative to a summer beer -- the lack of added flavoring (aside from the sugar), takes advantage of the refreshing qualities of the style.

Un buon inizio per entrare nel mondo dei lambic.
Il gusto dolce tagli bene lacido classico delle lambic.
Da consigliare a chi vuole approcciarsi ai lambic senza traumatizzarlo con qualcosa che può sconvolgere.

It poured a hazy orangish color with a decent white head. The aroma brings out some citrus, grapes, apples, and some maltiness. The taste was somewhat sour, but mostly a refreshing finish.  A very decent faro lambic beer.

Interesting beer. It poured out a light brown/red color with a light tan head, very carbonated. Smell is a mix of candy sugar and a light zesty citrus aroma. Taste is very interesting sweet of maple syrup and dark fruit with then a slight tartness at the end. Carbonation is heavy and dances in your mouth. Very interesting style. More refreshing than I thought it would be. Good.

37.5cl bottle picked up in Delhaize, Ostend. Pours a slightly hazy orange brown with a fast-disappearing white head, tart lemony lambic aromas, crisp and lemony on the palate to start and with a brief but pleasing tartness, but then becoming very sweet and sugary, and leaving an unpleasant sugary residue in the mouth.

On draught at Poechenellekelder on 30 March 2011. Orangey colour with a very slight spritz. Theres some tart acidity here - apples and lemon - and an edge of sourness but its overlaid by a rather sticky sweetness. Which is, of course, what is intended (maybe not the stickiness) but its not really for me. This draught version is more palatable to me than the bottled but its still not really my thing. I just dont find that sweetness and lambic character sit easily together on my palate.
Bright copper color.  Taste is of a good ale with overtones of tart citrus, particularly lemon.  Refreshing, easy drinking.

Bottle. Rating #632. Big copper dark amber pour with a quickly fading white head. Fruity aroma, kind of like an underripe apple, a little bitter. Dry and puckering, apple juice, light tartness mixed with the sweet, pretty interesting. (1608)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Bottle from Beers of Europe. Mixed fruit / cough mixture aroma. Medium brown colour with a reasonable head. Strong fruity flavour. Sweet aftertaste. Strong alcoholic mixed fruit juice.

Clear dark copper with a thin receding beige head.  Aroma is very wine like with oak, wild yeast, green apple, notes of light candi sugar and light funk.  Taste is a nice blend of sugar and funk with the wild yeast ringing true.  Notes of apple, a bit of earth and oak, very tangy and mildly carbonated.  Sweet and funky, a nice dessert beer with a bit of an attitude and tart to boot.

Lindemans Faro is a crystal clear amber brew thats topped with a white film that leaves excellent lacing.  It has a very sweet, tangy candy aroma.  Its light bodied and lively with a dry finish.  It tastes very sweet and tangy.  Theres almost a hint of green apple.  Its the Lindemans flavor without the fruit.  This is funky candy juice.  Its a very unique beverage thats fun to drink.
Very sweet lambic, the extreme tartness in the finish is smoothened out with sweet candy flavor. Tasty style.

The beer pours a light clear brown with small head, but good retention and lacing.

The aroma is sour with horse blanket dominating. Lots of strong funkyness.

The taste is much lighter than the smell, but tart none-the-les. This reminds me of an american wild ale, just not as funky or complex. Its still something enjoyable to drink and very drinkable despite its funk.

Aroma is strong, fruity, yeasty and tangy. It pours a clear, slightly hazy mahogany with a thick white head that sticks around for a bit. Flavor is very fruity and sweet, more like a cider, with a bitter, woody undertone. Still, it is a bit on the sweet side for me. Texture is silky-smooth and fairly tingly, leaving a finish that is fizzy, fruity-sweet and just a little bit bitter. Im glad that I finally got to sample a Faro Lambic!

355ml bottle. Pours a golden amber with only wisps of lacy head.  Aroma is sweet like candy, with a small amount of wheat character.  Very attractive.  Flavors are lightly spicy sweetness, almost like mead, but without being cloying at all.  Actually this is pretty refreshing for being so sweet and uncarbonated.  Im really enjoying it.

First Faro.....pours out a nice copper color with a small lacing off white head. Aroma is of some funk, sugar and cough syrup. Taste is of over-sweetened iced tea, some funky tart notes, earth and more sugar. Odd style that didnt really hit the spot.
Enjoyable and as usual its hard to think of these Lambics as beers. This taste like the wine of beer. No head and light red. Taste of grapes with lots of carbonation.

A very pleasant let down after a hard day. Red brown with thin fast dissipating white head.  Aroma is sugar, caramel and apples.  Light bodied but not too light.  Flavour began sweet apples and ended tart.  Tart finish.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text:
UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 A: Amber-orange body. Nice clarity. Small, quickly dissipating dirty ivory head.

S: Caramel, apples, musty wood, citric sourness.

T: Unfortunately the taste is out of proportion. The caramel sweetness completely dominates that citric/woodsy lambic flavors unlike the better examples of the style. the presence of the apple flavors also didnt work for me.

M: Medium body and moderate carbonation were both appropriate. The sweetness became cloying after getting a fifth of the way in.

O: Not the most stellar example of the style. Unfortunately its the only one that comes to the states, giving the style a bad rep.

Presentation: It was poured from a green capped and corked 355ml bottle into a Lindemans fluted glass. The label has a description of the beer but there is no freshness date or abv%.

Appearance: Its dark in the glass with a bronzy amber colored body held up to light. It has good clarity and some visible carbonation. A good two finger head caps of the beer. Its off white in color and tightly packed. On the glass it leaves some spotty lace.

Smell: There are notes of white bread, raw grain and wheat malt with a hint of sweetened whiskey or sweet brandy.

Taste/Palate: It is candy sweet up front with notes of white bread, sweet caramel, and nougat. Some tangy wheat and yeast tartness just tries to sneak in as some fruit notes like sweet apple peach and pear lead into a stick sweet finish. The palate is medium bodied, smooth and slick. On the lips it feels sticky.

Notes: Im not quite sure what to think of this beer. My palate is confused, is it a tart beer trying to be sweet or a sweet beer trying to be tart/sour. It is interesting if nothing else.

Poured from 12oz bottle, pours a clear copper/red with a quick diminishing head, aroma has notes of skunk, barnyard but also has a touch of sweet fruit mixed in, pretty odd, flavor has a lot of funk mixed in with skunk notes, vinegar and some caramel in the finish, different.

aroma is grainey and sour at first,a little tart apple comes in,stays like that, taste is like the back end of a mild sweet tart, sugary,slightly appley ,tart at first ,but that disappears in the sugary foam, firm body,more so then say a wine cooler,plesasant enough

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */: layer upon layer of sugar, that is similar to rock candy, there is also candy sugar in there, overall almost liquid sugar, minor caramel & yeast, very fun

35.5 cl bottle thanks to Dean. Poured a decent looking clear brown thinner bodied with a smaller slightly off white head. Aroma is sugary sweet up front then some barnyard funk along with zest. Flavor of sweet sugars, low key balsamic vinegar, slight yeast, breads, more sweetness and a hint of  funk. Not bad and actually although super sweet it seems watered down somewhat.

Pours a murky amber. Aroma is a little stinky cheese. Flavor is smooth and malty. A little more body than I was expecting. Decent sweetness and almost fruity on its own. On the front of the palate you get a touch of tanginess. That goes into the thick mouth coating sweetness. My first foray into this style. I was expecting a little more sourness but was pleasantly surprised by the malty full bodied aspects.

My "first" faro, im trying it side-by-side with chapeau. 12.7 oz capped and corked green bottle. Im trying these two both the same temp, same bottle type, same glass, so i hope to find which one is better.

The Chapeau has this one beat in looks, just slightly, the actual beer here looks better it is a clear brownish red, they head is a bit weaker though.

Take the funk of the chapeau and throw it out the window with this one, I like this one better too. It is slightly tart smelling with a nice lemon smell to it, very much like a lighter version of the gueuze, there is some barnyard but it lingers waaay, waay in the background.

This one is much crisper than the other, it is overly sweet, but Im assuming that the sweetness is somewhat par for the course. The lambic flavors are there, but simply with a dose of straight up sugar.

Id say colder is better to enjoy this one, it isnt bad, but it is really really sweet.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-09-2010 03:49:38

Poured reddish amber and transparent with very little head. Aroma is very subtle to me, perhaps a bit of dark cherry and some yeast. Flavor is quite nice...definitely sweet but balanced very well by sour. No hops to speak of. Finish is clean and leaves a bit of pucker sourness on the tongue. Excellent.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2012 Courtesy of Mane Liquor
Odd colour, a wild reddy amber with a small beige head. Big blend of sweet and sour. Lots of candy notes. Cherries, oak. Very dry finish. Odd but good brew

Amber colour with no head. Very sweet though not cloyingly, slight sourness, cherries, amaretto liqueur, pear juice concentrate and a very slight funkiness. Great to enjoy in small amounts with a dessert or just on its own.
Enjoyable faro beer. As sweet as one might expect from a liquid flavoured with candy sugar.

A funky brownish red pour with a one finger odd tan head.  The nose is sweet dark cherries with a bit of funk from wild yeast.  The flavor is also quite sweet and is interesting.  It reminds me of a sweet version of a sour.  Those cherries, malt, wood.  An odd dry bitter finish.

Bottle from myBerwerytap.com.
Sweet and sour blend. Fruit, lemonade, rhubarb finish. A tad too sweet. Little or no carbonation.

Amber in the glass.  Aroma smells of sweet malt, fruit, wood, and a trace of a lambic funkiness.  Pretty sweet on the palate but does have a nice acidic twang to cut some of the sweetness on the finish.  I could see this being a good option for people who like gueuze but want something sweeter and less sour.

Gold to murky straw color pour, decent carbonation, sprtizy. The aroma was horse blankets, grapes, lemons, apples. The flavor followed along with earth and dough elements, sweet sugars assertively present, finishing with a light sour touch, but perhaps too sweet (Lindemans, nah?). The mouthfeel was moderate in body and carbonation. Not bad, not all that, though. At 2 faros, guess that makes me a pro.

Deep golden color, virtually no head.  Strong aroma of vinegar.  The flavor wasnt nearly as funky/horseblanketty as other lambics Ive had.  Really sweet and the sugary aspect was dominant.  Enough vinegary sourness to keep it from being cloying.  My first faro lambic...not bad.

Pours a dark gold/brown with minimal fine foam. Smells sweet and slightly sour. Tastes very sweet and lightly sour of cherries and tangerines. Would pair well with fruit ice cream/ice and Belgian waffles.
This was my first Faro Lambic. It still has the characteristic lambic sourness, but is tempered by the added sugar so its a balanced sourness.  I liked it for its uniqueness.

Pours with a short lived, white foam.  The beer is a crystal clear brown and quite effervescent.  Nose is mouthwateringly tart with sour apples and toffees.  The flavor is a mixture of sugary, sweet tea-like notes with a metallic twang in the finish.

355 mL bottle poured into Duvel tulip. 
APPEARANCE: Pours deep orange amber. White head is about 1 finger with medium duration. When head settles, it leaves nice layer of film on surface. 
AROMA: Lambic, molasses, tart fruit, grain, hay. Faint hint of chalk on nose as well. 
TASTE: Brown sugar throughout. 
Front of palate is brown sugar, molasses, some candy-like apple.
Mid palate is abundance of tart taste. In particular, notes of tart green apple and tart cherry.
Back of palate is tart with faint grainy dryness. 
Finish is complex interplay of sweet, somewhat dry, and tart; with most emphasis on the tart character. 
MOUTH FEEL: Lively carbonation. Crisp. Semi-dry. Highly quaffable. 
OVERALL: My first faro. Interesting. Complex interplay of sweet and tart. Starts sweet and progresses towards tart. Better suited as a session ale sipped during the daytime, ideally at a cafe. Molasses notes would allow this faro to pair well with bacon (i.e., during brunch, etc.). Another reason this beer would be suitable for brunch is that it could substitute for a mimosa during the meal because of its slightly acidic yet sweet nature. In fact, if I were to exaggerate, would say this faro is like a mimosa with a little maple syrup mixed throughout - though in a very delightful way.
Bottle at Beer Academy in Paris. Cloudy amber with a large rocky head. Aroma is sour brett and citrus. Taste is fruity, not sour at all, cherry, candy.

Poured into a flute.

3.5 A: Lightly hazed light orange color. Two and a half fingers of frothy yellowish white head with near average retention and moderate amounts of lacing.

4.0 S: Strange, but nice. Lots and lots of candi sugar. Huge sweetness. However, theres a good bit of saison-like barnyard funkiness to balance. Wild apple fruitiness. A touch of tart acidity.

3.5 T: Good taste, but the candi sugar is present in far too high a level. I can deal with this amount of sweetness in some of Lindemans other brews because there is usually a strong enough sourness to balance. This, however, is a couple level of tartness lower, than say, the Kriek. Barnyard funkiness is there again as well as the wild apple, but everything plays second fiddle to the sweetness.

4.0 M: Lighter medium body. Good spritzy carbonation. Fairly creamy. Not all that smooth due to the massive amounts of sugar.

3.5 D: Even with the oversweetening, I did enjoy this brew. Its not something Id like to drink all the time, but one every couple months would be fine. Interested to say the least.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-29-2010 04:29:53

Bottle 16 Tons. Copper colored pour with no head and almost no carbonation. Smelled of sugars, a little dark fruit. Tasted pretty much exclusively of sugar, with a little bit of fruit in it. The single sweetest beer Ive ever tasted, and not something I need to try again.

Pours reddish brown with a white head. Aroma is Has hints of funk and sour. There is also some hints of candy sugar. Taste is very sweet. a little tart, but not much. Much sweeter than I thought from the aroma. Could probably only drink one of these.

Has the color of whiskey and a small white head that does not last. Aroma is like a tame gueuze with subdued notes of sour funk and hay. Taste is sweeter than the aroma lets on, a bit cloying. Basically tastes like a sweet tart with a slightly sour finish. Sticky mouthfeel that coats the tongue, carbonation is lower than expected - slight fizz but not much. Alcohal is undetectable. Perhaps a hint of smoke in the aftertaste. Very smooth - no bitterness or aciditity. Drinkable and enjoyable, but a bit too sweet.

Pours hazy reddish brown with white head, aroma has notes of funk, sour, some sweet caramel.  Taste, however, severely disappoints.  Notes of caramel, sugar, some slight tart, sweet sugary finish.  Basically, taste is andre champagne with some lemon in it.

Pale, clear watery amber colored. Tiny head. Aroma of caramel, bread, dough, leather, earth and butterscotch. Taste is very sweet, like candy, caramel and soft drinks with a touch of tartness. Overall, VERY candylike.

Bottle:
Small white head on top of a clear orange brown colored beer.
Smell sour, yeast, wood, piss and spices.
Taste is sweet, a bit lighter sour, spices, yeast, wood, brown sugars, light malty and a hint of hops.
Aftertaste of (brown) sugars light sour and light spicy.
Low carbo, mid body and soft mouthfeel.
Actually pretty well balanced with sweets and sour.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Hazy amber/cider color; Medium body; Aroma of sweet malt, yeast, tart fruit, & spice; Flavor of rich sweet malt, yeast, fruit, some caramel, and syrup; Finish is dry and slightly tart/sour; Nicely balanced; Overall, sweet as expected - quite good for the style.

Bottle. Pours a clear, slightly glowing dark orange with a moderate, fizzy off-white head. Aroma is similar to a cheap wine with sugar added to it. Some pleasant notes of cranberry and cherry offset with white sugar. Flavor is similar: some cranberry and blackberry notes, but it ultimately tastes like a wine soda. Its an honor bar red wine loaded with sugar and sierra mist. The sugary sweetness outdoes the tart flavors, and theres an odd dry wine aftertaste. I actually dont mind this all that much for a wine soda, no way in hell would I pay $6.50 for another taste.

12 oz. Bottle.  Pours orange-amber with a small, short lived, off-white head and Champaign like carbonation.  
Aroma is of yeast, malt, brown sugar and barnyard.  Full, tangy body.  Taste is sweet malt, brown sugar and sour grapes.  This brew could be a good substitute for Champaign.

Bottle sample thanks to skinnyguy!  Light brown pour, little carbonation and an aroma of slightly sweetened vinegar.  Flavor is super sweet brown sugar, slick and lingering sweet malt on the aftertaste.  Finally got the faro style rating, but I think its safe to say this isnt a style Id try to go back to again.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2011 Bottle. Pour is amber in color and clear with a thin head that disapears quickly. Aroma comes off bitter sweet with some caramel and sour fruit. Taste was sweet and sour, but finished wanting more. Palate is thin and fizzy with a creamy dry finish.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2016 Sampled at the Richmond Gather XIII.  Clear golden pour with no head. Backsweetned and somewhat tart.  But not what i expected at all.  Definitely not a geueze. Sampled again in Japan.  Crazy backsweetend.  Aroma is the only good thing.  Flavor is absurdly sweet apple juice.  Really not that good.

(Sample Date: 1/15/2011   Source:Other)   Earthy sugary aroma. Very clear dark golden with little head. Very sweet and earthy with a light sourness. Fruity but not really a specific fruit. Finish is quite sweet and earthy.

Bottle courtesy of MaltDawg or Kinz or Butters. Thanks whoever you are? Pours a clear copper with nearly no head. Aroma of tart notes with a lot of herbal earthy fungus going on. The taste is tart up front with a earthy, sugar finish. Medium bodied.

New Beer Distributors, NY 12oz ($5.50): Pours a reddish color with a white head. Tart, fruity aroma. Taste is really sour, especially towards the finish. Pretty sweet, definitely sweeter than the last lambic that I had.Very pleasant mouthfeel contracts your mouth, because of the intense sour taste. I like it, but I guess I like all lambics...
amber brown coloured body with a off white head a sweet fruity little sour aroma a sweet fruity little sour candy taste with a little sour bitter finish

Bottle: Pours a clear copper color with a nice "small creamy head". The nose is nicely cobbwebby with some light tart notes but quite a bit sweet and malty. Big sweet cloying flavor with some nice chewy caramel notes. Subtle yeast and light tart notes in the finish. A little too straight laced for my tastes.

Yay, my 2nd Faro!!  Bottle.  Pours a clear light dirty orange with a thick off-white head and plenty of carbonation.  Aroma of sweet sugars and sweet barley malt (basically it smells like the other Lindemans but without a particular fruit preponderance).  Flavor is similar with sweet brown sugar and some crackery malt.  Nice, sweet, and tasty.  I just cant get enough Faro!
7/4/8/4/15 [3.8/5]
Bottle. Aroma a little funky with light fruits and some pale malt. Flavor very sweet with tart edges. I have no basis for comparison, but on its own, a simple, refreshing drink for me.
Pours light brown lots of head which dissipates quickly. Nice sharp tart and sweet taste. Impressive beer from this trusted brewery.

375 ml bottle.  Pours a clear amber color with a medium sized fizzy white head.  The aroma is very sweet up front, some fruit notes, tart notes come through, not really what I was expecting.  The flavor opens with a big sweetness, adds a combination of fruits (peach, apple), slight cherry tartness and a strange finish (creamed corn?).  This was strange and apparently not my thing.

375 ml cork bottle in Germany. This is not really my type of beer at all but it was good. Pour is a ruby color. Some cherry funkiness going on, but I know the sweet will dominate from what I expect in a faro. Slightly tart up front, lots of sweetness midway through and finishes that way.

Poured from a 355ml bottle an orange reddish beer with very little head at all.. aroma is of green apple,sour cherry and dark fruits..very tart. Flavor is just as the aroma suggests of sour fruits and sweetness.. not a bad beer, actually rather good but could only drink one as it is so sweet.

Bottle. Pours clear amber/orange with a very small off white head. Aroma of acidic sourness, sugar, oak and light apple.The flavor is mostly sweet sugary apple with a very faint sour edge. Medium body with average carbonation and a sweet finish. Pretty good beer but very sweet, the aroma makes you think there might be some funk in here but the taste is all sugar.

Given how high I rated this, I probably shouldnt think it could be easily confused with a cider.  That being said, its an enjoyable beer.  The burnt copper color was nice.  The flavor was a nicely tart apple.  The only negative thing that came to mind was it felt like it had a little to much carbonation.

Found this at GE Market District-certainly the easiest to find brew of the style and my first.

A- Body is a completely transparent slightly dark caramel hue. Pours with <1/2 finger foamy white head that eventually fades to a thin collar with no lacing left behind in the glass.

S- Nose is of moderate strength and offers a good bit of funk-cheesecloth, a hint of vinegar, and a sugary sweetness-that seems to be more of regular sweetness than belgian candi sugar

T-Taste is much stronger than the smell. The initial flavor of of juicy white grapes, a very mild accent of vinegar, and a hint of cheese. The finish adds a lot of sweetness-almost cloyingly so- to the flavors already described. What lingers is a mild combination of everything described.

M- medium to high clarbonation and a medium weight quite juicy body initially with a slightly dry finish.

D- This is an interesting brew overall. My first of the style-and I dont really depend on Lindemans to demonstrate the best example-but I have a good idea of what its about. The flavor profile is slightly gueze-like but has a much lighter character and is much sweeter.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-07-2010 22:53:15

Clear amber with a small, weak head that doesnt last. The aroma has familiar lambic funk, with overripe fruit, and sour apple. The flavor is mellow and enjoyable, with sweetness and tartness balancing each other well. Little bit of dark fruit mixed in. Light bodied with little carbonation. Clean finish.

Bottle courtesy of llcooldave. Pours amber with fluffy head. Aroma is allspice/cinnamon and apple juice with a little skunky weirdness. Lightly carbonated, Very sweet and reminds me of sparkling apple juice or very sweet champagne. Tangy apple candy. Dry finish, Leaves lips sticky.

375ml bottle pours a totally clear, copper amber with a creamy, white head.  Honestly, the nose is like smelling a batch of Coors Light with brett.  Nose is also apples, cooked corn, vegetables, grass, pilsner malt.  Flavor is sweet, apple juice, barbeque sauce, apple juice, grass, light lemon peel.  Medium bodied.  I didnt get this at all.  Too sweet, no funk, no faro.  Weird.

Finally knocking off this stylle with a 355mL botttle, and I didnt have to make a detour in Dayton or wherever to get it.  Nose is dusty and sour and very tart - high expectations!  Looks are a little hard to determine in this light, but certainly clear orange leaning toward red with pink highlights, firm and persistent carbonation, and an extremely active and noisy head that both far outstrips and outlasts non-alcoholic carbonated beverages.  Seriously, the duration and volume of head activity are impressive.  Taste is sweet, almost cloyingly so, dries out only slightly (enough to be drinkable) and lets some wheat leech through.  Has a nice little bit of grainy grit, but really not all that sour or tart, those qualities are doubtless more than tempered by the sweetness.  No alcohol coming through, and just a hint of bitterness and yeast.  This is an enormously drinkable lambic, moreso than most lambics Ive had, which tend to fit that bill for me.  After a  few ounces, downright smooth and creamy.  Wouldnt mind trying another brand to see how variable sugar levels are, but on the whole, very happy with this.
A sugary malty beer.  Small head like drinking simple syrup spiked beer.  Great for an after dinner drink instead of desert.  Almost too sweet to drink in any quantity.
Bottle. Dark amber colour with a small white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, hops, yeast and sweet fruits.

I poured this into an oversized wine glass and I got a big white billowy head sitting on top of a ruby colored body. The head fades away to a nice lace but you still get a ton of carbonation coming from the glass.
Big old funk nose on this brew that I couldnt get past. Now the flavor was really sweet which threw me for a loop with the amount of funk in the nose. It was big on the candy sugar and fruit. It had a medium feel to it with more than ample carbonation to it.
I drank about half the bottle then it became a little to sweet for me. So I sparked a big ass cigar and dam if it didnt work well with it

Bottle, poured into a flute.  Pours a light clear reddish in color with a pure white head.  The aroma is light and fruity, light notes of spice.  The flavor is clean, crisp, slightly yeasty with lots of malty sweetness.  The finish is almost clean, lightly cloying.

From 25cl  bottle. Dark amber clear body with a small white head, almost no lacing. Gingerbread, clove, caramel, raisin in the nose. Heavy cloying sweetness, medium sourness, almost no bitterness. Medium body, creamy, lively, with a long syrupy finish and a back sourness. The Faro is a quite unique beer, some may dont like it, but I do like it. Give it a try!

12 oz. bottle served in tumbler- poured a transparent brazen copper color, lively medium carbonation, a thin broken white whisp for a head.  Aroma of a wet barrel, yeast, wheat, and some sour apples- perhaps I should have put a little age on it... hits the mouth with light body, malt faint but to be expected, very smooth sugary sensation in the middle with vanilla in the background, finish is tart and smacks you upside your head if you even think about putting it down.  Yummy yummy says the tummy!

THOUGHTS: My first Faro. Smell of a sour burp when opened. Fairly champagne like. A bit dusty, too. I think I will get another one to age.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Corked and capped. Poured a medium to dark, orangey copper with a large, off-white head that mostly diminished and left left excellent lacing. The aroma had apple cider; moderate barnyard, cheese, cobwebs and dusty yeast; grape, apple and champagne. The initial flavor was sweet, slightly sour and ever so slightly acidic; while the finish was slightly sweet, sour and slightly acidic. There was apple, grape, champagne, sugar water, dusty yeast and sour fruit. The light to medium body was very dry with fairly soft carbonation and a chalky finish.
Faro purchased at Olive Tree Market in OB. Last one. Sweet aroma and taste. Not very sour which was only what I expected. Havent had many in this style. Still it was good and I enjoyed it.

Pours a light amber color with a white head.  Aroma is sweet of candied sugar, yeast, and some slight barnyard aroma.  Flavor is sour up front with the tart fruits, barnyard and the candied sugar.  Sourness lingers for awhile.  Overall not bad but there are much better lambics out there.

Bottle thanks to llcooldave.  Diabetics----Watch out for this beer!!!!  Poured a clear, glowing light copper body with a bit of head that left some lacing.  Aromas of tartness, citric, white wine, sour, fruity and sour apples.  Flavors of sour apples, lightly acetic, medium+ sweetness that overpowers the tart/citric aspect.  Active, soft carbonation with a medium mouthfeel.  Sweet and tart.

Best before Sept. 2012. 4.2% on the label. Nice carbonation in the pour. Looks nice, smells clean and fresh, with some fruit skin and slight oxidation. Tastes moderately sweet, fruity, very slightly sour. Better than I thought it would be - and surprisingly as good as the Lindemans Guezue.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Bottle.  Slightly different label than that in the picture.  A clear amber/ruby pour with a thick antique white head.  A strong aroma of balsamic vinegar, Brettanomyces, red wine, sour apples, some candied sugar, and a little wheat in the background.  Thin and sparkling on the way down.  Much sweeter in the taste than I had anticipated.  Lots of apple juice, candied sugar, and caramel upfront.  A little wheat and vanilla in the middle.  Very tart/sour at the end with a greater presence of Brett and vinegar qualities along with plenty of McIntosh apples, raspberries, and lemons.  The finish is slightly dry.
Clear Copper pour, some citrus and apple aroma, not quite as sweet as I expected, very dry and crisp finish. Quite enjoyable, even if the style is nearly impossible to find.

Pours a hazy orange with a large white head. Lots of lacing as it goes down. The smell brings out some citrus, tart grapes and apples, and some malty sweetness. The taste is somewhat sour, but mostly refreshing sweetness. A little bit of earthiness. The body is medium and creamy; overall, this one was quite drinkable, and makes faro a style Id like to seek out more of.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-04-2009

Amber apple juice colored pour with a thin white head and lots of carbonation.  Aroma is beyond funky, tart, sour like a punch in the nose, but in a good way.  Flavor was unexpectedly sweet after that nose.  Candi-sugar and malt with some tart funky background.  You really get a sense of why this is a young unblended Lambic.  I wanted to age it.

Bottle from Lone Hill Liquors.  Clear amber appearance with a lasting one plus finger whitish head.  The aroma is dominated by apple and vinegar with slight funk and a little sweetness.  Sweet caramel malt, really not much tartness although it is very acetic.  Big on apple and red wine vinegar, maybe a little oak.  Cidery.  Medium bodied with an interesting mouthfeel from the vinegar notes.  Overall this is the lesser of the two faros Ive had, but a fine beer still I guess.

Pours a clear copper in the glass.  Funky ripe apple aroma which was somewhat pleasurable.  Flavor was not as sweet as I expected. Some pear flavor followed by a citrus tang & a dry finish.  Overall, its drinkable.  Its nice to have tried but not my style.

Bottle  Pours a clear amber with a bubbly white head. The head leaves quickly and leaves spotty lacing at best.  Aroma is strong hints of acid, some sweet candy, fruits, and malts.  Has a light carbonation.  The flavor is pretty good. A little too sweet for me but really drinkable.  has a medium body.  The finish is good and the aftertaste lingers for some time.  Not really my style but good.
Very clear beer with a medium to large head. Taste is a sweet apple with a hint of cherries. Long-lingering aftertaste.

Tasted from a 355 mL (12 oz) bottle purchased in Boulder, Colorado.  Light head with copper/caramel colored body.  Big nose thats a lot like a red wine- acidic and alcoholic.  Creamy mouthfeel with a sweet , creamy body initially.  Acidic, berry-like flavor (blackberry?) thats sour but not overwhelmingly sour.

Bottle.  Pours a clear ruby hued brown with a thin white head.  Funky barnyard up front, bretty and woody.  Quite sweet, soda like really, but not overly cloying.  Really just like a slightly sour soda, with lemony acid, a good amount of sweet malt, and a touch of funk.  Interesting, and a good deal better than I was expecting.  Finishes up with some gentle lingering acid, and residual sugar.
UPDATED: JAN 16, 2016 Pours great amber with a small tan head. Nose is fruity. Armas are caramel, candi sugar and fruits. Low carbonation, medium body. Long sweet finish.

Thanks Bill.  The beer pours to a really hazy deep brassy body with a thicker white head.  The aroma is sweet and sour funky star fruit and jack fruit.  The flavor is sweet, but not overly so.  Some sweet candi sugar and fruity base of slightly funky acidic fruits.  Generic fruitiness but good flavor overall.  The palate is pretty sweet but has a good texture.
Pours clear amber. Nose and taste of light wood, candi sugar, sweet tart fruit and strawberry. A bit of cream too.

Bottle. Copper beer with a cream colored head. Sweet aroma with light woodsiness. Sugary sweet flavor with tart/sour notes and light earth. Medium bodied. Sugary sweetness lingers with tart/sour notes and light woodsiness.

Served from a 355 mL bottle from OTM. The appearance is a crystal clear deep apple juice hue with a small white head. The aromas are apple cider light yeast. The flavors have a nice sweetness, apple, apple cider, malty, cinnamon sugar. A certain deeper sourness comes through on some sips. The mouth is medium to fuller bodied with a low carbonation. An interesting style. Seems like a cider with a touch of vinegar. Im glad I got to try the style.

Bottle at Brewforia.  Deep amber with a thin light tan head.   Aromas of rasins and dark pitted fruit flavors of cider and oak and vinnegar.  Sweetened a bit much.
Tasty though.
small bottle.  Pours a clear, dark amber with a white head.  Nose is musty, sour fruit.  Taste tart fruit.  Mouthfeel is thin, spritzy and sweet.
Pours a clear dark orange with a very thin white head. Aroma of fruit and vinegar. Flavor is very sweet and of apples, sugar, and tart berries. Quite easy to drink.

capped & corked bottle.  pours a deep orange / red with a 1+ finger white head which falls to nothing.  vinegar nose with some light fruit notes in the background.  big round body with tons of sugar along with honey, cherry, green apples and white grapes.  sweet grape juice finish with a dry body and a touch of tartness.

POurs reddish brown with quickly receding white head.  Aroma is vinegar, caramel and honey.  Taste is sweet with the caramel coming through nicely with a tart citrus.  It has a sweet tangyness, refreshing.  Iced tea flavor comes through.
Pours an amber color with a white foam head.  Has an aroma of fruit, funk, and tart.  Has a sweet fruity taste with a tart layer that is subdued.  Candy apple notes.

Bottle. Poured a darker amber color with a small head that went quick. Aroma was fruits, acidic, and vinegar. Flavor was very sweet, apples, sugar, candies, and acid. Tart, metallic aftertaste. Not my favorite out there, but drinkable

Bottle/12oz - This is the last of the "styles" of beer on my list... I have now had *every* style of beer that exists!!!! - Pours a clear dark amber in color with a small, almost non-existent head and very little carbonation.  Aroma is  fruity... apples cherries, pears...  barnyard funk with citrus and vinegar sourness... with plenty of the candy sugar to fill in the gaps. Finish is surprisingly sweet, given the sour style, and lingering.  This might not be the "best" faro out there, but I like it!!
Pours a moslty translucent orange copper with little to no head.  Aroma of fresh red apples, sweet and lightly tart.  Flavor was kind of sweet and cereal like, red apples and a light tartness.

Aroma of sour apple, candi sugar and considerable musty leather in the nose. Appearance is cola like with thin white head. Flavor matches the nose, with the leather tones subdued, appearing mostly in the finish.  Palate is creamy and bubbly. My first faro, and enjoyable.

Pours dark amber with a rocky head.  Aroma is fruit, primarily cherry.  Taste is tart, with a sweet edge, mostly balanced but a bit towards sweet.  Refreshing, pleasing, quite a nice beer.  I dont get a lot of Bret in there but it is present.

12 oz capped and corked bottle purchased at The Wine and Cheese Place in St Louis, Missouri. L C09 JFA on the label.  Served straight from the wine celler at 55 degrees. Opens with a small pop of the cork. Pour is mostly clear amber copper with a bubbly two inch off white head that settles down with some light lacing. Aroma is mild/light funk, cilantro, amd some cherry sweetness along with additional candi sugar sweetness. Taste is the candi sugar sweetness right away, yielding a touch to cherry fruit and finally displaying a very minimal amount of yeast and funk. Pretty sweet, but a natural sweetness. Palate is medium to light bodied, sparkly carbonation and a lingering sweet finish.

Intial aroma is that of Malted hops, with an almost funky stale smell. It pours a  golden amber color, with a thin retaining white head. Initially a cirtus sugar blend but is quickly followed by a smooth honey finish with hints of cider and apple. The after taste leaves you with  a mouthfull of cider and sweets.  Overall this is a refreshing lambic. It is smooth sweet beer not to be overpowered by the citrus taste. Would deffinatly try again.
31st December 2005  Early amateur rating warning! Fantastic fruity beer, generic fruit flavours, sweet but sourish as well. Yum!

Serving: 375 ml. bottle from State Line Liquors. 
Aroma: I know this is going to sound odd, but it smells like the inside of someones shoe mixed with candy sugar. 
Appearance: It pours an amber-brown color with a thin white head. Lesser head retention. 
Taste: The best way I can describe this one is to say it tastes like a packet of the sweet and sour sauce you get with your Chinese takeout.  There is a little apple cider, perhaps a touch of orange peel, and a definite sweetness. 
Palate: Light to medium body with average carbonation leading to a lingering sweet finish. 
Overall: Well, I can say I have this category ticked off, but I cant say this brew is one I would go back too.  Its not bad, its just not my style.  If you havent had a Faro, this may be your only shot if you live in the states.  Go get it you ticker.

A-pours a hazed dark cider color with a dark tan colored thin bubbly head.

S-the nose has some earthy tones to it as the sweetness takes over, a slightly artificial cherry dominates with touches of sugar and honey.

T-the taste is even more singular, very light earthy tones an almost all sweetness with a slightly artificial taste.  nothing offesnsive, loads of red cherries with touches of sugary honey and notes of cider.

M-medium syrupy body that doesnt have the carbonation to back it up, extremely juicy throughout but no driness what-so-ever.

D-extremely simple and straightforward, very sweet and somewhat artificial.  exactly what was expected, would be enjoyable by anyone that likes lindemans.
Bottle. Pours amber/orange, with a white head. Aroma is sugar, funk, and fruit. Flavor is sugar, fruit, funk and cider. Fairly heavy body. Didnt know what to expect form the, and it is rather good.

The aroma is that of the light flavors of the Belgian candi sugar. It wouldbe cruel to compare the appearance to Cantillons Faro, this is clear red amber with a small head. The flavor is light-bodied with light sweet Belgian candi on the palate, a bit of fruity syrupy sweetness to end.
Aroma is sweet, a lot of muscovado sugar, fruit with peaches. Taste is similar  as taste but with a very dry finnish.

Pours bright deep copper into a tumbler. White head with excellent retention leaves sheet lacing as it slowly recedes to coat surface. Sour orange, grapefruit, pineapple and apricot aromas. Viscous with upfront sweet and sour sauce turning to a sourpatch middle before the bitter ground pith in the lasting finish.

Sweet citrus aroma. Clear orange brown sock water. Glassy frothy head dissipates to thin ring around the glass edge. Light body, sweet and sour combo. Fizzy mouthfeel with sweet tart tang that makes you gleek. First opportunity to taste this style, not the last.
Finally get a Faro rating.  Bottle.  Amber pour, white head.  Sweet artificial sugar, grain, light tartness, and fruit.  Not very good, but I would expect anything better from Lindemans.
pours copper hue with a huge fluffy white head that quickly dissipates.  fairly sweet and tart, medium bodied.

Bottle from Als in Harrisburg.  Aroma is sour and yeasty.  Amber body with thin lacing head.  Flavor begins sweet and candied and turns to a sour finish.  Lingering sour aftertaste.  Very unique, a nice treat

330 ml bottle corked and capped. This past weekend  I went to an estate sale in town where a woman donated her house and belongings to her church.  I got there a bit after it had started, but it was still a gold mine.  In addition to the fine books on botanical gardens, orchids etc I picked up, I found a lovely old blown glass decanter and six etched wine trumpet glasses from the early 1900s.  I am drinking a toast to this woman now out of her wine glass.  Hope she enjoyed the angels share as much as I did.   Intriguing acrid nose lingers slowly from glass and makes one initially wonder..."what the heck is this stuff?...Oh yes...wild yeast"   Pours a dark amber with a steady yet thin central column of carbonation. I wonder if it is past its prime since the description states a "red". First taste is sweet...as much of the Lindemans line tends to be...nearly over sweet. Yet this turns the corner from the lightly caustic nose  and ends up to be quite lovely in a sweet then tart viscous body manner.

Bottle. Clear golden amber pour with a small off-white head that quickly disappears. Aroma is malty and tart with notes of caramel, apples, wood and vinegar. The flavour is quite tart also but with a fair amount of sweetness, with notes of toffee, apples, pears, grapes, vinegar and wood. Dry mouthfeel with moderate carbonation and a lingering tart, mildly bitter finish. This being my first Faro I dont have much to compare it to, but overall this is quite nice; however the sweetness would probably get to be a bit much in large quantities.

Enjoyed from a 12oz bottle in a whiskey snifter.  The beer pours a translucent medium to medium-dark amber color with essentially no head.  The aroma gives a sour character, along with Belgian/German character malts.  The palate shows both of the items, with a propensity toward sourness in the approach and mid-palate, and some residual sweetness toward the finish.  Carbonation is surprisingly assertive, but exactly what the flavors seem to want.  Hops are not detectable.  The finish is lightly sour and subtly malty.  Overall, extremely enjoyable and well-crafted; a refined Oud Bruin.  A shame that it seems fairly difficult to find.

Bottle. Pours a deep ruby color with no real head. Aroma is acidic and bitter, makes me think of red berries. Raspberry and tangerine maybe? Taste is sweet and bitter, acidic and full of strawberry/raspberry and tangerine flavors. Quite good, but as with most lambics, I find it to be too sweet and acidic to have more than one bottle.

12 oz. bottle from Grape & Gourmet.  Dark orange pour with a thin and quickly fading head.  Aroma of lemon and a hint of Belgian candi sugar.  The candi sugar is certainly more present in the flavor.  This comes off as fruit cocktail of flavors both sweet and sour.  This is my first experience with this style and I didnt know what to expect but its really a pretty good beer.

Pours a nice golden amber color. The palate and drinkability is very good. The finish is a little sharp and only a small amount of dryness. The texture is caramel; tarts, toffee and some fruits. I am enjoying this. A good beer for a night cap.

Poured from the bottle into a Duvel tulip. Clear amber-brown with a large fizzy white head. The head resembles that of soda - fast audible bubbles that quickly recedes to nothingness. Smells lightly of traditional lambic barnyard with some vinegar and sweetness. The flavor is mildly sour masked by sweetness with a fruitiness, slightly earthy/funky , some wheat, and a touch of vinegar as well. Medium-low carbonation cleanses the sweetness from the palate. Even though I would call the body medium it is much fuller than every other lambic I have had. I was fully prepared to hate this just because it was from Lindemans but I was pleasantly surprised. Would make a nice starter sour as well.

355ml Bottle:  Sweet aroma of malt, candi sugar, honey, light barnyard, light funk, and lambic.  Poured amber in color with a small, fizzy, off-white head that disappeared immediately.  Clear.  Sparkling.  A few small and medium-sized particles throughout.  Flavor is heavily sweet.  Tastes of malt, candi sugar, slight banana, slight bile, honey, and light funk.  Medium body.  Average texture.  Average carbonation.  Heavily sweet, malt, candi sugar, light funk, and slight bile/vomit finish.  Way too sweet.  Where does that bile/vomit flavor come from?

Bottle. Amber pour with thick off- white head. A nose of candy, fruit, and syrup. A sour taste with a tart / tin finish.

I dont like lambics , but this is ok.
Pours a light brown (WTF?). The aroma is sickeningly sweet and fruity. The flavor is super sweet and extremely off-putting. Luckily we split this 5 ways. Nasty.

(bottle from BMan1113VR, sampled 3/9/10). Copper color with light cloudiness. Medium off white head. Moderate sour aroma with light sweetness. Moderate sour flavor, with light candy and light red licorice. Avg duration. Smooth finish w/ light tartness. Thin/slick texture. Soft to moderate carbonation. Spare lacing.

Savannah, Ga - Habersham Beverages, 12 oz corked bottle.Copper colored pour, not much of a head. Earthy aroma, some sourness to it with a hint of vinegar. Solid sour flavor with out any fruitiness - nice and basic. Earthy and basic. Solidly thick mouthfeel - hint of spritziness.  Woo-hoo - finally rated a Lambic-Faro!

Pours deep amber/copper with an off-white head.  The aroma has lots of sugary sweetness, some underlying lambic sourness, light caramel and light brown sugar.  Medium slick sticky body with lots of flowing sharp carbonation.  The flavor starts with almost a toastiness to the malt, good amount of sugary syrup, some spice and a hint of sharp lambic hiding below.  The finish gets a bit on the medicinal side.  Okay beer.
A clear light amber color with fine bubbly carbonation. Tart aroma. Flavor is sweet and sour with some hints of malts. Finish is sweet but on the dry side. Interesting beverage.

(250 ml bottle. Rated @ 14.8.2010.)
Brown colour with a small head. Nose is sweet, a bit sour with a hint of brown sugar. The taste is sweet to with notes of caramel and apple. Slick mouthfeel and soft carbonation. Sweet finish. Well-balanced faro.

Pours a nice light brown, weak head.  Nose has dark cherries, plums, caramel and a nice lactic funk.  Taste has some funk and sourness to it but is well  balanced by the sweet, fruity malts.  Reminds me of a Flanders sour.  Medium body is well carbonated.  Drinks quite well.

Sour caramel and dusty nose.  Very slight haze, warm orangey brown color, smallish head.  Cola flavored gummies sweetness, orange pith bitterness, slight sour undertone.  Lighter carbonation, somewhat syrupy body, finish is sweet, almost cloying, slight sour tang, maybe more tart?  Never had the style, a little too sweet for my tastes, but interesting.

Bottle.  Pours a light amber with an off-white head.  Nose is quite sweet with some sourness, slight yeast and light malt.  Taste is very sweet with some caramel, apple cider, and a growing though moderate sourness.  Lingering sweet finish with some apple, wood, and slight sourness.  Nice dessert beer, although the sweetness is enough that its hard to drink a whole bottle of this.  It would be great to share amongst 3 or 4 people with dessert.

Bottle. Pours a reddish copper color with a very slight head. The smell is pretty interesting; tart  but sweet fruits as well. The taste comes as quite a surprise. Brett funk flavors up front that quickly transitions to a very sweet fruit flavor almost like maraschino cherries. Light mouthfeel. An interesting beer and style. Too sweet for me but I could see how this could be a good after dinner sipper or for people that like sweet cocktails. Would love to try the Cantillon version to see if it is as sweet.

12oz. corked and capped bottle served in a Tank 7 tulip. Bottle conditioned. Poured a dark copper with a finger of off white head. Fruity aroma with some dark sugar. On the sweet side. More fruit, cherries. Light bodied with plenty of carbonation. As it warmed, I got a hint of something like vomit in the aroma, which obviously was not pleasant. Beer is very drinkable none the less. Definitely on the sweet side. Would make a good dessert on its own.
From a bottle poured an amber color with a small amount of head.  Light tart flavor with a slightly sweet finish.

37,5 cl bottle. Pours a cloudy copper color with a medium off-white head. Fizzy foam. Aroma is lamibc-like: acid, vinegar, barnyard and little sweetness. Taste is similar but more complex, on the sweet side: sugar and wine aromas come out, some wood notes too. Palate is medium with high carbonation. Overall, very refreshing and interesting brew.

Bottle, 37,5 cl. Amberbrown, lots of co2, no head. First a malty hoppy aroma, later some fruit. Alzo somewhat sweety. Smooth taste, sweetish, also fruity, slithgly bitter. Somewhat dry finish. Fresh thirstquenching beer.

Pours a reddish color with a rotten fruit like smell to it. Has a really sweet cherry like taste it. Really unpleasant after taste that I cant really put my finger on. Damn Ive been getting a lot of bad beers lately

This is my first lambic that I am rating on this site.  It is also one of the rarest lambic styles I have been told.  Had a pop up cap with a cork as well.  Silly to be sealed twice I think.   Label on bottle is fairly fancy.  I like it.  Pours an orangeish brown color with a medium sized off white head.  Is pretty fizzy.  Smells of sugary goodness mixed with some sort of fruit (pear? cherry?).  Has a nice look to it.  Taste is very sweet, almost like sugar.  Little bit of carbonation in their with some plums in the taste.  Wasnt sure what to expect with the lambic.  A little sweeter than I expected but not a bad drink.  Oh and purchased by my boy scotty bo botty.  Holler.

Capped & corked bottle from Binnys beverage Depot in Orland Park, IL:  This poured a slightly hazed amber body with a modest head that rapidly dwindled to a film.  The aroma has a cherry candy sweetness with a light lemony tartness and a soft touch of funk.  The flavor was more balanced than the nose led me to expect, although the sweetness did dominate.  The finish was surprizingly dry with a lemon drop tartness.

Finally got a hold of this elusive style, albeit a common brand. Earthy nose is sweet and enticing. Texture is tingly and full up front, dryish in the middle, sticky in the finish and cloying in the aftertaste. Unfermented Belgian candi sugar really comes through. Rich rock candy in the malts, with a distinct, honey-like and mead-like aspect that dominates from start to finish. Some flowers in the aromas, along with sweet petals and sugar-coated perfume-like essences. Has a curious nip of sourness that surfaces here and there, but it is washed away with sweetness. Extremely mild, almost non-existent hop bitterness. Interesting beer, especially for its mead-like qualities, but too sweet for me. I wont, however, rule out the style after just this one sample, especially due to the fact that its Lindemans, which brews a lot of sweet beers.

The aroma is funk, barnyard, and some vague sweeetness struggling to get out.  The appearance is dark chestnut brown/red, translucent, off-white head, decent lacing.  The flavor is sweet, almost cloying, candi sugar, earthy, barnyard, funk.  The finish is tart fruit, sugary, sour, acidic.  Medium in body, sort of oily.  I jumped at the chance to add another Lambic faro to my collection (this style is usually a bitch to find.)  This was ok, but not especially enjoyable.

Pours a pretty amber-brown and what head you can muster by pouring aggressively ducks back into the suds almost before you can put the bottle down. Brett, Funk and Rubber on the nose initially. There is some light cherryish tartness there too. First drink: this is a fairly sweet beer, sugar is right up front, like kool-aid up front. It has a nice mouthfeel, Ill give it that. It has enough sour balance that I dont hate it, but this would take some getting used to. Glad I got a Girardin Black Label coming up next.
Thanks AgentSteve.  Poured clear golden amber, smooth, sweet berries, candied sugars, little yeasty, dry finish.

Bottle. Im not a Lambic-fan. But had this one at home, so had to taste it... Pours out orange, amber coloured, a small head, wont hold good. Smell of ripe fruits, some spices, something unpleasant comes up. Very oily, almost sirupy mouthfeel. Very, very tastefull, almost pure sugar it seems. Lots and lots of sweetness, some caramel, some spices, some fruits. A bit sourness comes up also. Its drinkeable, but its no beer for me. An unpleasant siropy thing.

I finally found a Faro lambic!  Poured a clear honey color with a white foamy head.  Aroma is very similar to a gueuze, with some sour notes and yeast.  Taste is sweet with fruity notes, mainly grapes and cherries.  Taste is closer to a fruit lambic than to a gueuze.  A good amount of flavor, but not many yeast or sour tastes.  Finish is a little bit more dry than the beginning.  An interesting style, but I think i prefer gueuze and fruit lambics.
