brownish copper colored beer with a offwhite head who lets a nice rim in the glass when dissapearing
smells sourish-sweetish ,fruity, spicy
tasts sourish-sweetish, of fruits and some spices, a hint of lagered champagne 
aftertaste sourish-sweetish ,fruity, spicy
a special experience

A 0.25L bottle from local K-Supermarket. Pale head. Fruity nose with hints of raisins. Hazy pale orange brown colour. Sweet slightly sour an bitter taste with some hints of apple. Also some slight peach aromas.
250 ml bottle. Clear reddish orange colour, very small white head. Sweet aroma of malts and fermented fruit. Sweet but acidic flavour of apple and berries. Slightly watery. Not very pleasant.

Bottle from the bier palace in Belgium.  Clear, reddish color with mall white head.  Aroma is super sweet candy with a mild tartness.  Sweet cherry and red apple come out in the flavor with a tad bit dirtiness, soft tang as well. Watery with slight acidity and light carb.  Drinkable but undesirable at the same time, way too sweet for my palate.

250 ml bottle. Amber color, low off-white head. Sweet-sour aroma. Initially sweet taste that picks up some sour tang along the way as well as some oaky notes. Sugary finish. Medium body, high carbonation. A bit too sweet for my palate.

Bottle shared by oldstylecubsfan. Todd, thanks a lot!  Pours a sorta hazy amber with not much a head. Nose has some sweetness and some mild tartness. Flavor is a bit sweeter overall. Faro is pretty good, but id rather drink gueuze or fruit-lambic.

Medium head decent carbonation in a clear amber pour aroma perfumed floral hop malt mild cider apple horse stable effect flavour candy strong yeah like eating a horse stable effect  taste overpowering it destroyed the beer for me finish was too much.

Thanks OldStyleCubFan for sharing. The pour is copper amber with a thin fizzy white head. The nose is herbal, leafy, sweet, corn, no tartness, very sweet and sugary. The flavor is sweet, caramely, earhty and herbal as opposed to tart and acidic, mild tartness, tastes more like an oud bruin than a lambic.

Bottle shared at the Carolina Crew tasting by OldStyleCubFan, the Belgian Food Lion beer ninja - thanks, Todd! I agree with my homies that this one wasn’t up to the level of the earlier Faros and sours, but I still found it enjoyable. It was drier and more metallic than earlier entries, and was more one-dimensionally sugary. Decent.

Similar to Lindemans Gueze (not the Cuvee Rene), this has weird flavors that don’t do it for me.  Odd sweetness and a flavor that makes me think of paper and paste. But as this is a faro, add sweet caramel to that taste.  I just don’t like this.
Once again thanks to Todd for sharing this one!  Cloudy dark gold pour with a green apple aroma.  Nice flavor consisting of apples and ginger.  Dry, slightly acidic finish

Hazy dark golden, small firm pale head. Mildly sour aroma, with old apples, little funk, wood and sugar. Flavor starts with lambic sourness, wood and dried fruitiness. Finishes candi sugary sweet. Quite pleasant actually, most of its lambic characters are still there. Sweet, but not overly so.
bottle, Auchan Illkirch-Graffenstaden. Hazy amber colour, small fluffy head. Sweet and sour very fruity nose. Fruity flavours dominate this beer, not as sweet as I had expected. Very nice.

(Bottle, 0.25 l) Amber and slightly hazy. Small white fizzy head. Sourness and sweetness in nose. Sugary, medium bodied palate with high carbonation. Candy sugar, sourness, sweetness, some malts and light bitterness in taste. Sweet and sour aftertaste. Quite good actually.

Bottle 0,25 l. Darkish hazy amber or copper, good white head. Nose is malty, sweet berryish, some syrup and candy. Flavor is sweetish, slightly sour with a beefy malty backbone. Some berries and sour fruits maybe in there, but very sweet altho in a nice way. Good pleasant mouthfeel, pretty rich texture for the abv.
Bottle. Poured a tan golden color. Arom a is a malty sweet. Taste is sweet with a sweet malty finish.

Poured clear golden amber with non-existent head. Aromas of sweet caramel accompanied by wood and ciderlike acidity. Palate shows alot of sweetness upfront, with brown sugar and some honey, before the trademark lambic characters come into play. The sweetness tends to mellow the tartness and earthy funk. Finish is resonably tart with a touch of sweetness.

Bottle from trade.  Would be great except that even a scant 25cl is too cloying to finish comfortably.  Sweet plum juice overly sweetens what I am led to believe is a decent lambic beforehand.  Sugar dances around like an idiot.

Bottle. Clear golden amber with no head. Aroma was interesting, but not terribly appealing: funky, sour, estery with a hint of wood. Medium body with medium carbonation. Flavour is complex and dominated by a sweet sour balance. This balance changes through each mouthfull, but is perhaps a little on the sweet side, but not much. The sweetness has caramel, honey and very ripe fruit (apples?). The sourness is citrusy and perhaps green apples. There are other interesting tastes such as plain yoghurt. Overall an unusual and interesting beer that is very drinkable.

Bottle, Carringtons, Chorlton. Poured a Hazy pale orange colour with a thin white head. Aroma sweet and saccharine. Flavour was similar, lightly tart with apple, lemon and honey notes. Moderately carbonated. Teetering on the edge of cloydom. Some sourness in the finish. Nowt special really.

Primo Faro assaggiato, comperato in una piccola bottega in rue des Abbesses a Montmartre, da assaggiare nel pomeriggio (e così ho fatto, guardicchiando un’idiota trasmissione francese su M6 nella minuscola ma graziosa stanza dell’Hotel Utrillo); mi colpisce l’aroma, decisamente ottimo, degno di un vero lambic. In bocca è dolce e appiccicoso, con sentori di pesca e albicocca, ma una comunque non impercettibile presenza acida che lo nobilita. Somiglia più ad una birra che ad un lambic, in ultima analisi, ma sono giunto a ritenere che non sia un cattivo prodotto; quando assaggerò qualche faro più buono (magari di Cantillon) allora potrò riconsiderare bene la qualità effettiva di questo.

No 384
Rated: 01.05.2008
Bottle green, 375 ml
Appearance: Pours burned orange, peach skin like bosy colour, black breakfast tea like, colour of burned sugar being watered down a bit, body texture is a bit hazy, carbonation of body is lively like a fizzy drink, head is unstable, rathr fizzy to foamy but after a quick initial decrease it becomes very, very small and stable. Head colour is beige. There is quite nice lacing.
Aroma: Front is winy, some powder sugar, caramel and nice burned sugar, some notes of light white table wine, deeper there are some grainy notes, some accidity, creamy, milk, mild and well balanced aroma, ’a bit flowery’, some yeasty notes and wheat with little banana and some spices like clove.
Flavour: Really a very positive experience with my first Lambic. Front is naturally sweet like from the fructose of a very sweet fruit, later on the accidity begins to play a main part in the whole taste, especially just after you swallow the beer, later on there is a strong accidic taste of fresh green apple and natural soft and refreshing citrusy lemon without the shade of bitterness. Rather no hoppy accents playing any significant role here but there is some thin small of bitterness in the deep texture of it and some slight wheaty - malty notes, not that strong to call it bready. Finish duration is long.
Palate: Body is medium, texture is accidic with some sweetness, palate is sticky from burned sugar and perfectly balanced by this stickyness, finish feel is accidic on the one&sweet on the other hand.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2011 Dark brown with a small head. Aroma is sweet, with toasted malt and a faint lambic background. The flavour is cloyingly sweet, especially the finish. crisp with caramel and fruit. The palate is a little too weak
25cl, from Geers Oostakker, not complex sweet brew, clear, good head, nothing special
UPDATED: AUG 14, 2009 375 ml bottle. strange, it has a bottlecap and a cork ?? whats that about ?? nice orange golden colour. off white head. taste is fruity and sweet.

25cl bottle.  Super sweet apple butter and honey in the nose.  Sweet apple cider and pasty honey tasted, very simple overall, sweet, but somewhat artificial tasting.  Under-whelming but that’s pretty much as expected.

25cL bottle, courtesy of acrdz.  Thanks, Mike!  Pours a slightly hazy, golden-orange color; thin white head with solid, glistening fine-bubbled lacing.  Lots of overripe fruits, sugar, and stale chewy malts in the aroma; very overripe, flabby.  Medium mouthfeel: chewy, syrupy overripe fruits and sugar; slightest acidity; flabby mouthfeel: and the slightest tannic red fruit character (barely); basic, syrupy, sweet fruit beer, plenty of apples.  Medium finish: sweet apple juice, sugar, and overripe fruits.

Courtesy of acdz. Hazy pale body with a tiny white head. The nose is sugar, cheese, lemon and yogurt. The flavor is sweet, lightly tart with apples, sugar, lemon and honey. Medium/light body is a bit thin with moderate carbonation.

Hat at Le Poechenellekelder in Brussels on 6/22.  Pours a hazy golden amber color. with a minimal white head.  Aroma of candied apple.  Similar taste, but with a pleasing lightness to it, and a nice sourness in the finish.
Poured a light hazy amber color.  The aroma had a light funk to it and a sweet caramel malt.    The aroma matched the flavor.  Sweet and tart mix in the flavor.

Bottled 25cl. 4.2 ABV. It pours a clear caramel colored beer with a small off white head. The nose is mainly of wood and candy accompanied by a pleasant sourness. The taste is sweet, sour with wood and candy showing up. Nice lacing. Deeply pleasant. A hint of incense. Wonderful dry finish with candy, yeast and wood appearing.

375ml bottle at a cafe in Mornac, France 12/6/08. Chestnut coloured with a big, foamy tan head. Aroma of dark sugar and preserved sweet. Flavour had some dessert wine sweetness with a hint of lambic tartness. Much better than the other bottled faros I have tried.

750ml bottle @Pauls Hoboken#1-pours a disappearing white head and hazy amber color.  Aroma is herbal, hints of sweet medium malt.  Taste is sweet medium malt, light fruit-white grapes, candy sugar, slight herbal, yeast.  Smooth.  Occasional.

Bottle at Theatre de Toone, Brussels. My first faro. Corked bottle. Dark hazy amber color with a head that ringed. Very mild aroma. Seems a bit soapy. Medium body with sharpish yet mild carbonation. Its sweet and sour at the same time. Flavor is light sour, light oak, light raisin. Its certainly balanced. Good drink.
Bottle.  Looks nice. Pours amber purple color.  Beer is loaded with sugar, its every where, some apple, maybe a touch of malt but man this is to sweet.
Pours an amber color with a nice white head and lots of carbonation.  Sharp aroma of berries, maybe some pears.  Very sugary sweet, malty body has a crisp, dry finish.  Tasty.

Bottle. Pours a hazy amber with a bubbly head that quickly subsides. Very sweet on the tongue with sour apple and cherry flavours (also in the aroma). Smooth with a slight carbonation, its incredibly easy to drink. Nice beer.

(0,375 bottle, 4% ABV) Hazy and amber color with lots of bubbles. Thin and thick white, lacy head. Much sour apple and cherry in aroma. Fruity and sweet flavor: cherries etc. Very sweet and sugary taste. Medium-bodied, a bit carbonated palate. A bit mild but refreshing, very easily drikable and quite enjoyable beer.
Bottle, shared by dickinsonbeer.  Amber pour.  Aroma is sweet white sugar over a lightly sour beer.  Same flavor, sweet white sugar up front with tart fruit behind it.  Interesting.

Pours brown with a light, white, fine head. Aroma is grassy, barny, very unique. This isnt all that different from Lindemans Gueze. Mouthfeel is moderate. Flavor is caramel, apple, barn, and pleasantly sweet. Very good beer.
Bottle at beerfestival. This beer mentioned 4% Other sources speaks of 4.5 % and not 4.75 %. A nice tasting faro

Bottle courtesy of thewolf: Poureda hazy orange color lambic with a medium size foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma consists of sweet notes courtesy of the candi sugar with some light sour traces and some light tart notes. Taste is also dominated by some sweet notes with light sour and tart notes. Light filtration with some great carbonation provide an easily enjoyable beer that would be even better in my backyard during a hot summer afternoon.
Red, brown, amber colored brew. Sweet aroma. Fruity, somewhat sour falvor. Malty. Nice.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2016 Bottled. Pours clear and deep amber with an average lacing, creamy, off-white head.  Aroma of caramel, brown sugar and with element of yeast. Sweet flavour that ends up dry. Light to medium bodied, watery to oily texture and averafge carbonation. An OK Faro. 🌟🌟🌟

Huge berry nose, sugar crystals too, copper, a small tan head. Taste is a softer sweetness then the aroma indicated, fruit is less pronounced also. Light bodied,very refreshing. My first Faro! Thanks Brian Morin.

Bottle. The colour is beautiful! It´s redish brown and clear. It has a small white head on top. This is the first time a had a faro. It has a very interesting aroma. It has alot. It´s winous, has rubber, rassin, sweet malt and strawberries. Flavor is very sweet and smooth. It´s almoust like a champagne. Malty. Candy. It workes nice with some chocolat and coffe. Or as an appertif.
Amber with a low head. Sugary and dry aroma and flavour like an Asti with a bit of nuts and wood. The perfect beer for too much summer heat.

37,5 cl bottle Deep copper colour, perfect head which leaves a smooth small bubbled layer til the end. gorgeous smooth vinegar nose. i cant help it, i really like faro lambics, even though i always feel a bit cheated since its just lambic with sugar. But even i am not always in the mood for full on vinegar. But i have to say its not the best, and generally draught versions are a lot better. Still very yummy though xxx
25cl bottle from madsberg - thanks Mads! Best by 290808. Pours like dark apple juice, thin white head. Funky, lightly tart, sweet nose, apple and wood. Flavor follows the nose, rather dry. Nice!

I like this a lot, even though I am not a big fan of lambics. Pours with a small, white, fizzy head that lasts and produces some lacing. Darkish golden body. A nice balanced funk in the nose with apples, wood, some fresh cut grass and spices. Taste is quite sweet, like a ton of sugar was added to lemon juice and cider. A bit of butteryness when it comes to temperature. Dry mouth, like champagne, with delicate bubbles.

250ml bottle 
4.20% ABV 
I tried this beer on February 29, 2008 at The Beer Bistro in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.  The beer poured a translucent dark red with a thin white head.  The aroma was fruity, with very little if any hints of malt or hops.  The mouthfeel was medium-bodied, and very champagne like.  The flavour also had a champagne feel, and was very sweet with some subtle sour hints to balance out the sweetness.
Thanks Immy, 25cl bottle. Pours clear copper color with thin white head. Aroma sweet and fruity. Taste is sweet and like apple cider with dry finsih.

250 ml - the Beer Bistro (Toronto)
Pours an Amber/Ruby hue with a nice rim of champagne bubbles.  From there, it is all sweet - the aroma, the flavor and the thick syrup finish.  One to close the night, as the palate will be affected by this one all night.  There is a nice carnelized (kinda lightly burned sugar) element that is nice to this.

Bottled, alc. 4.2 % (BB 04/2009)
Dark amber color, not much head. Sourish peach nose. Suprisingly peach dominates also flavor. Typical faro - very sugary, but this one has very pleasant acidic finish. Fruity aftertaste. As good as a faro can get!

Bottle at Kulminator. For my first ever faro, I was not sure of what to find. Reddy brown with a thin off-white head. Nose is gueuzey and acetic, fruity and lemony. Strong peach tones. Mouth is sweet, smooth, peachy, gentle. Slightly metallic lingering long sweetness at the end. Little one-dimensional, but very good.

My friend Artem dragged this back from Belgium for me. It pours a thick and murky dirty orange color. Has a small but sticky head. Aroma is orange with sticky sweetness (but not as much most other Faros) with some light spikes and faintly acidic earth (that the lambic part). Taste is sweet but not too strong again, with some granny smith apple skins. Leaves a light sour-orange aftertaste.  Least sweetness of the faros I have tried.


375mL bottle, BB 15/NOV/2009 elongated thin Ommegang 10th Anniversary goblet glass.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: UPDATED: FEB 13, 2009 0,25 l.Nice deep amber color, minimal but delicious head. Aroma like a barnyard, some fine fruity perfumes, candy sugar.. The flavour is very sweet with a minimal tart, the body is complex.

Notes from 12/16/07.  Big thanks to my Secret Santa for the elusive faro style.  375mL bottle, no date.  Hazy caramel orange with a thin off-white head.  Aroma of sweet overripe cherries, some funk, and earth.  fairly sweet with light acidity.  Flavor has a moderate amount of wet paper oxidation--still pretty sweet--, though not as much as other beers from the Lindemans family. Cherries make another appearance as well, but otherwise the same.  Medium body with low carbonation.  Not really sure how to rate it since its my first faro--not too bad of a beer--Im just not sure why someone would bastardize a lambic and dump sugar in it.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Amber with tiny head. Sweet aroma with light sour notes. Sweet flavor with caramel, apple and accidic notes. Goes well with my dessert.

This beer completes my styles. Thank you Maria!  Aroma of barnyard and a hint of vommit. Pour was a nice dark brown with a one finger off white head. Taste was very weird. Tastes like seltzer water with a cup of sugar mixed in. Way too sweet for me. Very good carbonation. This is so sugary that I feel if I bite down I will feel sugar crystals between my teeth. Not bad.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Aroma is sweet syrupy cherry as well as  touch of barnyard funkiness. Light golden color, thick creamy white head. Light earthy and dusty aroma. Flavor is lightly sweet, honeyish and quite earthy with a bit of fruitiness as well. Tartness appears underneath the obvious sweetness. Long Lingering earthy finish.
Bottled. A bit of a disappointment, because its sweet. Mushed, brown apple aroma (!). A bit bitter. Colour shifting from orage to yellow, big white head. Taste sweet apple juice.

Bottle 37,5 cl. Pours light purple with a white head and a rich fruity smell. Flavor is sweet, a bit too sweet but the finish makes up for it. The finish is rich, with sweet, sour and spicey notes. Very good.

Bottle shared by iowaherkeye. My first Faro. Thanks Joey. Poured a hazy orange color with a slight purple tint. The aroma was fruity with plum, cherry, and spiced pear notes. There was also an earthy, almost wood-like accent. Very sweet, like the other Lindemans offerings Ive tried. The flavor, as foreshadowed by the aroma, was also fruit dominated. I tasted mostly cherry and apple. There was also a subdued, but distinct paper-like note that detracted a bit.
37,5 cl bottle, bougth at Ølkonsortiet in Aalborg. Sweet with modearte sourness. Berries. Vinous. A very gentle lambic.

Pours amber with some fizzy bubbles.  Smells moderately funky and lambicy with lots of sweet touches.  Tastes of sugar with some underlying funk and touches of sourness.  Mouthfeel doesnt yield much outside of sugar and some tingly sourness.  A lot better than the Chapeau version.

27/10 0.25 l bottle at Hopdevil. Poured deep reddish brown body with small brownish head. Aroma of vinegar, really sour, more than other lambics Ive tried. Apple, some caramel, too though. Flavor quite light, sour, then it comes to the caramel sweetness which is specially felt in the finish. Not so much carbonation, quite oily texture.
Good beer, Im very surprised with the style, this is the best lambic I had.
Draft at Poechenellekelder, Brussels: Muddy orange with a creamy head. Sweet fruity (peach mainly) & vinous maturted taste. Smooth & soft & very sweet. Low carbonation.

Like gueze mixed with caramel and maple syrup.  Perhaps I just dont like the style, as this is the first example I have tried, but I just thought it was really weird.  Quite sweet.  All around unsettling and unpleasant for me to drink, I thought the strong sugary flavor really clashed against the earthy lambic base.

Bottle in Belgium, best by 2009. Kind of hammy, lightly sugary aroma. A bit of burnt sugar, kind of a bit of pizza smell. Taste has much more sweetness, but is well balanced with slight acidity and has a moderate amount of complexity. Perhaps bottled faro is not the holy grail, but this beer is very drinkable and tasty.

With this bottle, purchased in the Copenhagen airport, at last Ive completed the styles!

For one unaccustomed to the faro style, this is surprisingly sweet (though perhaps not for a Lindemans product, nor unpleasantly so.).

Woody vinegar aroma; flavor light an easy-drinking flemish sour than a challenging gueuze. Tartness is very restrained, as is the barnyard. Woody flavors, lemon, plenty of sugar. Just a nice sweet-sour flavor, almost rather like an enjoyable soda.

Wonderful aroma and very beautiful presentation. Dark brown with beige head. Very fruity aroma, a little acid and sweet. Initial acid bite with fruits, roastyness, chocolate, wood and some sugar. A nica aftertaste adding some hidden bitterness to the aforementioned flavours. 
I really liked this one, but not one to drink too regularly.

Tasted 06/10/2007. Bottle from Regional Wines and Spirits, Wellington. Copper, tending amber. Slightly hazy. Collapsing off-white head. Mostly cherry, wood and sugar on the nose. Quite simple but very polished. In the mouth its sweet and sour - with a nice dry tannic finish. A nice balance between the sugar, cherry, and lambic sourness, with a woody tannic lambic character. Blood red oranges linger on the palate. Lovely.  Not quite what Id call "funky" but certainly very drinkable. A great apertif,or a digestif... or just enjoy it on its own.

Brussels-07. Im not a huge lambic fan, but I can appreciate this beer. Pours reddish-brown with light head. Has a nice fruity nose, and taste is well balanced sweetness with hugh tartness and flavours of peaches, cherries and citrus notes.

Pours reddish copper with a thin, fizzy head.  Aroma is semi sweet tart cherries, lemons, apples, and other berries.  very light aroma.  Full, well carbonated body.  Flavor is lightly sour, berries, sweet malts, peaches, and some light citrus/orange flavors.   I actually really enjoyed this.  Light flavors, the sweet notes werent too overpowering like in some lambics.  Refreshing, and Id like to have it again.

draught. pours orangeish red with white head. nose of apples, cherries, and pears. flavor of sweet green apples, cherries, finishes dry. complex but pretty sweet and fruity. mouthfeel is very watery. carbonation was low. decent.

Draught at the Poechenellekelder, Brussels. Amber color. Sweet, tart and fruity aroma with notes of cloudberry. Sweet and a bit sugary flavor but still quite nicely balanced by acidity and fruitiness. Notes of dark sugar and peaches in the flavor. Dessert wine like beer.
Tasted 2007-07-22. Toffee coloured, hazy, white head. Smells like lemons, peaches, strawberries and hay. Tastes the same. A very drinkable and enjoyable beer.

Flaske. Duft af rørsukker og smag af rørsukker. Farven er brun med et sodavandsskum. Det der gør øllen rigtig god er at den har en god surhed i enden. Og når man nu godt kan lide sukker så er det en god øl.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2012 4.2% 25cl bottle bought in Belgium.
Violent pour to get some head... which disappears in a hurry. Dark red, wood colour with a beautiful glow.
The aroma is salty, bitter-sour wood with hints of lemon. Quite dry. Black pepper and even some fenugreek. Fat overripe cherries and caramel.
Bitter-sweet with the sweetness dominating. The alcohol gives some sourness. The sweetness dies in the palate revealing an orangy, bitter-salty shipyard woodiness. 
A delicious beer for hot, thirsty days.

Bottle, 250 ml. Aber coloration with a white head. Sweet, bitter and dry at the same time. Notes of cinnamon and ginger. Sweet in the begginig and bitter and dry in the final. Very different (and nice) beer.
good faro lambic, sweet enough but not like the candy shit they sell most of the time here.. cant really judge the rest besides caramel and a light ruby color
Extremity flavor of red fruits, perfumed..................................Cor de tamarindo, doce, extremo sabor de frutas vermelhas, muito perfumada. O lúpulo vem em segundo lugar, mas é presente.

25 cL bottle. Pours amber to light brown with no lasting head, a very small crispy head was there when poured. Clear lambic aroma with a distinct cane sugar element layed on top. Very sweet flavour with a slight sour twist towards the end. Nice style of beer a good supplement to the acidic/sour lambics. Note to self: I need to have some of these in stock for guests that dont get the beauty in the dry and sour lambics :)

Bottle The Times Cafe/Bar Ypres 25-07-07. Has a soft sweet nose that whilst lambic is much gentler. Amber in colour with a small white head. The taste is really very good and a fine gentle introduction into this style of beer for those who wish to dive into Lambics. I liked this and whilst it is a bit too sweet it is still immensely enjoyable, and the sourness still offers enough of a diversion to keep one interested until the end.

Bottle. Pours a nice clear golden amber colour with a small but well lasting creamy beige head. Good sticky and creamy lacing. The aroma has sour vinegar with some sweetness and good tostiness.  The flavour has a toasty sweetness along with a pleasant refreshing sourness, good fruitiness and a nice sherry touch in the sour and sweet finish.

Blackfriers. Aroma is sweet vinigar, a sweet and sourness comes across, hints of wood and buckets of dark tart fruit, however way to sweet. Taste is a similar fruity beast, hints of port, woodness in the finisg and age, infact this tastes like the kulminator, like the smell of the kulminator when your having a old loteling brune or something, problem is its too dam sweet. This is an excellent beer its got more hints of a flemish sour ale than a lambic, but if it was half the sweetness this would infact be rated over a 4 for me.

Chestnut brown, thin light tan head.  Nose is meaty malt, lemon, brown sugar, roast ham.  Something odd is going on here.  Flavor is that same hammy malt, bitter lemon pith, caramel.  Bittersweet finish.  This is a trainwreck.

Beverina ma forse troppo dolce per i miei gusti, non ricorda i lambic se non in una lieve sfumatora dellaroma.
appena appena sufficente.

Orange brass color with small white head. Aroma is ripe apple, rubarbe, musty honey, and some malt accents too. Taste is refreshing, it keep a nice balans between honeyed sweetness, oxidized apples, sour stonefruits candi sugar and little drop of lambic. A nice refreshing summer beer.
Cobber of color with a light white head. An aroma which has some sour and sweet notes. Hints of bitter apples. A fresh flavor with notes of sweets, caramel and some sour notes.

375ml bottle: poured clear copper with a small beige head. More carbonation than I thought it would have. Mild cognac aroma with a touch of walnuts. Flavor is somewhat sweet at first followed by a mild sour finish. Just a smidge of cherries. We all know its going to be sweet so just enjoy it for what it is. A nice drink.

Tough aroma on this one.....not something Im enjoying....sweetish yet sour notes abound.  A dark amber color...minimal head.  Flavor is initially sweet..sugary...sourness comes in late and hard.  Meets the style requirements..just not a very enjoyable drink.

Bottle @ Bierbrasserie Cambrinus, Brugge. Big near-white head over a slightly hazed amber body. Sweet aroma of almond and marzipan. Sweet-flavored as well. Starts with candy-sugar and  notes of canned sweet fruits. Ends up with acidic cherries and a refreshing sourness. A bit on  the sweet side,  but a still a good balance of sweet- and sourness though. Enjoyable.

This faro poured a light brown color from a 375ml bottle. Small to no head visible. Aroma is brown sugar ad citrus, very sweet. A medium to full bodied faro. Very sweet. Kind of honeyish with a touch of sour/tart fruit at the finish. Little to no carbonation as well. Sweetness seems to build as you progress. Lots of brown sugar abd honey. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is sweet.

Being my first time with a Faro, how do you rate it? Whats it supposed to taste/smell like? I havent really a clue, so I will just rate on whether or not I liked it. Aroma was sweet, plastic, boozy, fake fruit, and caramel. Flavor is a nice sour/sweet combo with a sugary finish (heavy on the sugary side). Not bad. Dont know how it compares to something better or worse, so for now I will just consider it average.

Pretty mahogany with a medium off white head.  Sour, acrid lemon, grape skins, canned pear, and fruit salad.  Flavors take a back seat to nearly cloying candi sugar.  Slight pear, cherry, doughy yeastiness.  Some new oak, and other damp woody flavors.  Traces of lemony sourness linger in the background in the sweet finish.
bottle.  Clear maple color with white bubbles on the surface.  Sweet, bourbon nose with some fruit and oxydized notes.  fruity and very sweet. Very dry but heavy finish.

Bottle, thanks to after4ever. Pours a cloudy copper with an off-white head supported by streams of carbonation. Lightly sour cherry aroma. Soft, round mouthfeel with surprisingly light carbonation, given the look of my glass. Lightly sweet taste of oxidized apples and cherries. A touch of woody tartness in the finish.

330. Thanks, Maria! Wonderful stuff. Sweet and sour oxidized apple nose, plenty of cherry there as well. Hazy dark amber body with plenty of tan suds. Big mild cherry/apple attack that persists through the mid palate and the finish. Wonderful stuff. I could drink this now and then if it were local.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2007 Bottle at Delirium Cafe, Brussels.  Dark brown-amber with a light head that fades.  Aroma is woodsy - oak, slight lactic and vinegar acid presence, and some yeasty funkiness, as well as some fruity sweetness.  Taste is nice: strong sour upfront fades to an oak and cherry middle that is quite sweet.  Finishes with candy sweetness, bordering on cloying which is the only down point here. Nice high carbonation, quite drinkable. First faro; quite liked it.

Bottle. Small white head. Light hazy amber color. Apple, vinegar, fruit, blackcurrant mixed in with a quit sweet malt profile. Medium bodied because of the moderated sweetness, somewhat sticky texture. Flavor was sweet with light acidic. Finish was sweet with a touch of acidic. Maybe a bit to sweet for a Lambic. Need more balancing acidic, still very drinkable.

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2007 250ml bottle. Lovely golden brown body with some minor sediments. The aroma is not to distinct but delicious, a bit acid with cellar notes but also some fruit. The flavor is sweet like candy sugar but also some notes of acidic. Theres also some apple and orange peels in the flavor. Long lasting finish. Quite refreshing even as sweet it is.   
Re-rated as 750ml [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ lambic festival. Use to appreciate this a lot, but this time I had the chance to compare with a bunch of other lambic based beers. This is still nice and refreshing, but the score has to be modified a bit down when comparing.  My comments are unchanged. (Earlier rating: 8-4-7-3-15).
Draught @ Poechenellekelder, Brussels. Light brown. Caramelised/brown sugar with slight tartness. Could be an uncomplicated thirst quencher but spoiled by excessive sweetness.

Bottle. This is a difficult one. Amber colour with white creamy head ad good carbonation. Aroma is sour mayby a little hops, not nice. Taste sour with a lot of sugar sweetness and lots of carbonation. Too sweet and too sour for my taste.

I doubt that I´ll ever get to like these beers.

375 ml bottle, via Papsoe.  Bottle 3 of a 4 bottle Faro tasting.  Pours an orangish copper colored body with a very fine yeast haze and a one finger white head that left lots of lacing.  Aroma is quite funky with a very earthy musty cork and aged leafy hop note.  A little sweaty feet, and no hint of sugar.  Flavor is quite sugary sweet though  with minimal lambic character.  Finishes a little less sweet with some musty moldy cork notes.  Mouthfeel is thinner in texture with minimal to no sugary stickiness and nice lively carbonation.  The most gueuze-like mouthfeel so far.  This seemed to have more of an aged character to it than the others I had.  The nose was actually pretty decent, but it was a let down with the heavy refined sugar flavor.  Better overall than the Chapeau and St Louis because of the nose and mouthfeel of this one.

The aroma was cork and oak with a strong saccharine characteristic. The aroma was lightly tart with an acidic nature and some estery fruit character. The beer poured into the chalice clear amber with a low white well lasting head. The flavor was sweet, very, very sweet. Along with the sweetness was a  light tartness and a fruity character. The sweetness was forced and unlike a cloying malt sweetness, this was that of saccharine. The finish was sweet, of course, and the body was medium with a fairly low carbonation. I had this in Belgium fresh and found it undrinkable. This bottle was much more pleasurable, but still too sweet for doing anything other than putting on a childs pacifier. 37.5 cl corked and capped bottle, purchased at a Delhaize (Food Lion) in Brussels.
user_location: North of Raleigh, North Carolina, USA

text: Dark brown / ruby colour, slightly sour nose, swee for a lambic and no real depth

Many thanks to JK for carting this home and sharing.  Dark copper color with a thin head.  Strong aroma of caramel and sourness.  Outstanding flavors of oak, caramel and sweet malt.  A moderate sourness towards the finish.  Freakin delicious.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2007 This is good.  Light barnyard aroma with the promise of sour flavor.  There is yeast and sourness in the flavor, but tempered with sugar sweetness.  Brown color and lots of carbonation.  Its a shame faros cant be found in the United States.
Thanks to JK for sharing.  Tart nose on this light brown pour with minimal head.  Sour with a nice fruity sweetness to balance it out.

Thanks to JK for sharing.  Pours a clearish bubbly dirty brown.  Nice apricot sour nose with hints of some other sweetness.  Very nice sour brown like flavor profile.  Nice brown sugar sweetness with a nice sour bite.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: Clear light brown with a small head. Aroma is mainly sour with notes of fresh green acidic fruits/berries. Flavor is a mix of sourness balances with a good chunck of sugar, with a very acidic sidenote and finish. Quite refreshing and very drinkable for a Lambic

Bottle. A sweet, yeasty, fruity aroma (I couldnt put my finger on which fruits were there). Taste has some hop and malt, with an underlying lambic fruit flavour. A sweet, fruity, acidic finish. Not too sweet. Moderate carbonation. Fairly refreshing and easy to drink.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2007 Bottle from Dovetail. Pours a pale amber with quickly dissipating head. Sweet aroma of artificial strawberries. Taste of raw sugar cane with notes of peach, passion fruit and strawberry. Sickly sweet and syrupy. Dry, waxy finish. The acidic edge is neatly disguised by the sugar. Not THAT bad, but far from great.
Bootlegger Paris 10/05. Amber with off-white head. minimal aroma. Very sweet. Not bad but fresh lambics are better.

Bottle. Pours to a deep amber color, with a rocky head that fades, and a moderate carbonation. The nose on this beer is inviting, with good aromas of sweet malt, and estery fruit. The palate is sweet and malty, with lots of good malt flavor, paired with nice candy sugar sweetness, and a back drop of sour fruity flavor. This beer finishes with more good sweet and fruity flavors up front, then ends with some sour fruitness that lingers. Nice beer, very enjoyable, very food friendly. I like the addition of candy sugar in this beer. It gives it a really nice sweet/sour character making it a very enjoyable beer drinking experience.
Shared a bottle of this with my family after Christmas dinner. Pale amber. sugary sweet, with a hint of sourness.  Its always a treat to get a chance to try this style.

Lucky to find this on tap (and on special, 3 Euros) at Clichys Tavern in the Montemarte neighborhood of Paris. Pours a reddish brown with a creamy head. Smells of sour green apples and brown sugar, caramel. Everything about this beer is sweet. Thin bodied. Like spiced cider, with a bit of carbonation and candied prunes. Has some Belgian dusty basement quality too it. Not enjoyable at all, and the only beer from this fine establishment that I did not finish.

Warm amber with a red hue and a creamy, but moderate head. The aroma is slightly sour with notes of candy sugar, caramel and a hint of nuts. The flavour is nicely balanced between acidity and a sweet/sour finish, and the candy sugar never becomes cloying or pushy. Its a really nice faro.
I dont really know what faro is but here goes. Standard fruit beer smell, feel and taste. Flavours are characterised by an earthy, woody, barely note. Sweet, slightly tart finish.

Bottle at home.
Dark amber with a white head. Aroma moderate malty, notes of fruits. Moderate sweet and sour, and when you get used to it, smooth and round. Light body, normal carbonated.

Bottle: Poured a reddish brown amber with a white head. Aroma seemed to have that sour berry fruit smell with a hint of sugar. Nice sweet berry and malt flavor. Kinda diffrent than what I expected from all the ingredients I read.

Bottle from the Oxford CAMRA festival. Dark caramel pour, layer of tan head that settles fairly quickly. Oxidized barleywine sort of smell--dark pit fruit, brown sugar, sherry. Flavor is...really weird. Sort of a lemonade kind of thing--a heavy dose of sweetness, mixed clumsily with a big dose of dark sweetness. So sweet. Gives me the shudders. A bit metallic in the finish.  Grows on me a little as the glass progresses--the harshness of the sweetness wears off a little--but it still just feels like an unusually awkward beer.

[From my Christmas Speech at Ørbæk rådhus]

Wow! Wonderful sweet aperitif Faro. Cannot find any better in this special style!

Courtesy of Papsoe.

Acidic, sweet, lightly funky, unripe green apple aroma.

Pours a ruddy brown with a quickly diminishing bubbly white head.

Sweet, funky and lightly tart in the fore. Very sugary through the middle and finish, but with that faint barnyard funk beneath. Has a sort of apple cider flavor to it...very appley in fact. Hmmm. Its kind of still and lifeless with just a hint of carbonation as you swallow.

Bottled(250ml). Amber coloured, small white head, wine acidic nose. Acidic aroma with notes of fruits and yeast. Also light apple and a way too strong sugary taste. Moderate sweet and acidic finish. There are better Lindemans.

copper colour..some ok head...sour apple-sweet wine smell...has an intresting taste...honey molasses sugar tame wine brown sugar taste...nice creepy bitters...i need more practice on the faro...nice aftertaste.

Slight fizzy beer with a deep yellow to light amber color. The foam disappears quick. The aroma is very nice and apple like. Fruity sourish in the nose with a fine counterbalance of honeyed accents. The beer has a perfect balans between sweet and sour. Very nice to drink lots of it on a warm summer day.

Shared by Sliffy at the last Columbus tasting.  Golden brown pour with a light fruity aroma.  The palate was medium.  Taste was earty, sweet fruit, and a funky aftertaste.  Glad I got to try this style.

Shared by sliffy at CTV3, thanks! Poured orange with an off white head. The aroma held some vinegar like qualities but nothing too over bearing...coupled with some fruitiness. The flavor was ciderish with some sour behind it. Pretty sweet and fruity with a dry finish.

C.T. 3.0- I was apprehensive after the Chapeau Faro, but this was surprisingly tasty. No head, peachy-amber in color, did smell a little musty like mead. Flavor was very sweet, like thin honey and apples. Quite drinkable.

0.33l (I guess) bottle at the Hopdevil in Zagreb Ooooh, how nice, my first Faro :). Glad to have that rare style out of my way. Poured a very dark murky amber body with a tiny white head that went away fast. The nose is pretty much absent... some raisins I guess. The taste is... yes, sugary. Brown sugar... something I cant nail down, cherries, maybe some maltiness, some apple tartness, a bit funky and yeasty and some tiny, blunt dryness. Not all that sour  Of course, sugar dominates all, and everything else lurks in the background. Nothing I would mind having again.

Bottle shared by sliffy at Columbus Tasting 3.0 - Pours dark amber with a slight offwhite head that didnt stay very long.  Aromas of pungent sour, and some barnyard.  Flavor is very sour, apples, cherries, and some candi sugar there.  Sour and fruity at the finish too.  Palate is quite acidic not much carbonation.

Bottle thanks to Madsberg: Peach color with a fizzy white head. Aroma, apricots, sweet pale malts, some sour. Flavor, Apples, cider like, some sourness to it. I kinda liked this one, but its still a weird style.

Cloudy red/copper with a large frothy head. Aroma is quite sour, compost, and very sweet candy. The flavour is equally candy sweet/acid sour with some nice dark fruit and nut flavours too. Sour fruity finish and aftertaste.

Pours murky brown, thin white head. Sweet, woody & slightly acidic aroma. Flavour is sweet, like a soft drink, and retains lambic woodyness, but none of the lambic sourness. Is very sweet in the aftertaste.

(Bottle, best before 23/03/08)  Pours a clear golden body with a moderate beige head.  Aroma of candi sugar and tartness.  Flavor is sweet with a subtle sourness.  Carbonated mouthfeel with a bit of a sticky finish.
Pale red color with a tiny white foam. Sweet and fruity with a bittersweet finish. An interesting,complex lambic.

This was my first  faro, years ago. Bottle. 37,5
Deep golden colour with a thin off-white foam. Sweet, honey, almost orange peel like aroma. Very sweet, light sourness, lightly winy and sherry flavour.

i had this one almost a week ago, but am now getting to it from memory since i did not write down notes. what i remember is that it was really nice tasting, with a sweet fruity taste, even my mother enjoyed it and asked me if it was really beer.
Hazy golden with a frothy head. A fine lambic aroma, sour and earthy, however the taste was cloyingly sweet, and though there were hints of some background tartness, the sugar dominated.

my first thought on this was the awful smell. Luckily it didnt taste how it smelled, it was actually pretty good. A little sour but refreshing. Wouldnt mind drinking more if they were easier to get.

Color is a brown/amber with no real head to speak of.  Aroma is cherry, caramel, crystal malts, barnyard.  Very sweet taste like unripe fruit dipped in sugar with dried fruit, and cherry pie filling.  Very interesting beer that combines sweetness and tartness.

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2006 Style 70/70 Thanks to numenor! Nose was tart, barnyard aroma; appearence was rusty brown with a mere ring of bubbles along the glass sides; Flavor was tart yet sweet with an tiny apple ester, an interesting contrast of flavors, definately not what I expected from the aroma.

(big thanks to the almighty irishboy for hooking this rare style up)brown body with a rusty tinge.aroma is dominated by funk,with a bit of cherries.flavor was surprisingly sweet,with some green apples.actually very nice.
Bottle. Dark amber, brown coloured. Large off-white head. Sour sweet malty aroma with some slight yeasty touches. Nice balanced sweet-sour body. Finish is sweet, little sour and a little sticky.

Ye gads Batman, this was shite!. I remember as I tasted this I was talking to other backpackers in our hostel of the beauty of most Belgian ales and then I took a whiff of this and couldnt hide my cringe. Aroma of bread left to fester for too long with some dank barnyard malt and rusted car bodies. Its got a feint citric acid note and table sugar which mixed together could easily rust a car! Poured a muddy, tawny bronze with a lovely thick head of cream, well supported by the huge flurry of fine carbonation. Bready in the mouth, light toffee malt upfront (?) with phenyl sweetness across the tongue like diet cola minus the cola. Its just lightly tart, acidic in the sweeter side and sugary like an over-primed lemonade. Very feint showing of candied fruit like oranges and lemons. Finish claps out between grapeskin astringency and spoonfuls of sugar. Not one I liked obviously. So, making a point about some grand Belgian ales...... (25cL, 4%, 29/09/07, de Bier Tempel, Brussels)

Dark amber, brown coloured with a large off-white head, and much carbonation. Sour sweet malty aroma with some slight yeasty touches. Nice balanced sweet-sour body.Finish is sweet, very little sour and a little sticky. Average.

750 ml bottle. Thick white head. Light coppery colour. Clear, but with just a little hint of stuff floating around in the beer. Musty raspberry aromas. A little barnyardy notes. Sweetness at first that moves into a more fruity flavour. Notes of candy sugar.

Thanks are due to Numenor for his gracious carting of this all the way across the Atlantic.  He has really contributed to my nabbing of styles.  Ruddy brown colour, clear with an off-white head.  Tart aroma.  Delicious, sweet flavour with salty afternotes.

Alas, my last style. Thanks to Numenor for picking this up in England. Cloudy reddish color with a thin creamy off-white head. Aroma of sour and some sweet fruit. Very sweet fruity flavor, with some sour kick in the end.

Yay... my final style, picked this up at the Beer Ritz in York, England.  Nice golden-brown body with a very thin white head.  Great sourdough-bread aroma, nice and tart.  A very tart and sweet flavor, ending with almost a pure caramel-sugar tang, maybe some sour apple showing up as well.  Basically a normal gueuze with more sugar than normal.

Bottle. Pours an amber colour with longlasting off-white head. Sweet fruity aroma some hints of sourness. Very sweet malty flavor with lots of candy sugar and hints of caramel. Some hints of sourness aswell. Very sweet aftertaste.

Bottle at home alone. Not sad or pathetic, just home alone !! Amber color, a nonlasting white head. Aroma: Honey, a little gooseberry, but mostly sweet. Taste: Very sweet, dry, not very sour. Reminds me of eating a bag of sour candy.
Bottle. Golden brown colour with no head.. Aroma is green apple,orange and yeast. Flavour is sweet,yeast and orange.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2012 1) 08/07/2006. Grape juice sweetness tempered with a winey sourness, and lingering bitterness at the back of the tongue. Clear red with a tetering head that fizzes out quickly. The musty hum of infrequently swept cellars. A touch too sweet for me. 535312=2.8. 
2) 18/01/2012. Underrated it- its become a bit of a house beer since, and a favourite of the missus, my Mum and occasionally me. Sweet, admittedly, but enough dampness, sourness and lambic interest to get away with it.

Bottled, 0.25ltr. Golden, with some sediments and no head. Light aroma with both sourness and sugar. Quite fruity, with apples most pronounced. A good deal of sugar in the flavor, with some acidic astringency and some orange-notes. Sweet, sticky, full-bodied mouthfeel. Refreshing in the summer-heat, with green apples in the finish. (060704)

Offwhite big head of fine lace over deep copper tan body. Light, ripe raspberry aroma with some acidity. Taste is sweet soft raspberry taste. Maybe a bit too sweet to drink much of. Nice, smooth, and soft, though. (0.75l bottle.)

Amber/brown beer with a small head. Smells fruity, woody, dusty and candyish. Tastes sweet, fruity(cherry, strawberries), sourrish(vinegar, lactic acidity), some horseblanket, dark candy and woody. Finishes more sourrish, fruity, woody and long. Somewhat cloying mouthfeel and just enough co2. Rather good faro, with a distinct lambic background.
Pours amber with no head, but bubbles sticking to the glass. Smell is fruit. Taste is very sweet and fresh. No alcohol to speak of. Tastes cidery.
Bottle.  Deep copper, thin beige head.  Fruity and sweet.  Sweet toffee aroma, some cherry/strawberry.  Sweet, cloying.  Really just rather awful

UPDATED: MAY 18, 2012 Bottle. Small head that fades quite fast. Color is dark amber and a wee bit hazy. Taste is caramel and acidic. Good stuff. Original rating March 21st 2006 7/2/7/3/14. Rerated May 16th 2012 7/3/7/3/16.

Maybe its just because I cant get Faro anywhere around my domicile that makes me enjoy this so much.  All right.  Its NOT my favorite Faro, but this is a really nice drink.  Slightly red.  Fast-dissipating head.  Notes of acidity and candi-sugar on the nose.  Caramel notes from the candi-sugar and wonderful lambic tartness in the flavor.  Alas, a little watery in the end and the palate could be bigger.  Very sprtizy.  Try one of these!

Pours with an orange-gold body topped by a thin to medium thick head with some lacing.  Its very sweet and fruity with the slightest bit of bitterness and a hint of sour notes.  light to medium and smooth.

My final beer style! Recieved in a trade with oh6gdx. Poured with a light copper body and a tight white head. The aroma was sweet with lemons apples and cherries. There was also some earthy honey. Hard to pick out barnyard character past the fruit. The taste was sweet honey with apples and a bit of leather in the finish. Better than I had expected.

37,5 cl bottle. Yeast at the bottom. Reddish amber colour with nearly no head. Earty aroma with notes of fruit and wine. Swet and sour flavour with a touch of champagne-like and a lot of oak and wood in it.
Amber, white head. Malty aroma with sourish notes. Sweet flavour dominated by brown sugars and some underlying sourness (acidity). Oak, vanilla.
Pours an amber color with a small head.  Sweet taste, this was surprisingly enjoyable after what Ive heard about the lambics.  Id drink this again.
Bottled. Amber with minor white head. the aroma is sweet and raisin like. The flavour is sweet and fruity.I did ENJOY this beer!

Bottled. Amber colour with small beige head. Aroma is sweet,caramellish and at the same time a bit bitterish. Flavour is sweet caramellish (sugary) as well as some "lambiccy" sourness. Pleasant palate and aftertaste is mainly sweet only.

375 ml bottle, best before August 2007. My first Faro! A good celebratory rating on my 4 year anniversary here at Ratebeer. Deep golden colour with a thin off-white foam. Sweet, honey, almost orange peel like aroma. Very sweet, light sourness, lightly winy and sherry flavour. Medium bodied, a bit syrupy.

(50cl bottle, supermarket) Amber colour, small rocky beige head. Aroma of fruits, sweetness, yeast, earth, sugar, light malts and alcohol. Sweet with light acidic notes taste, wood, fruits. Long dry aftertaste. Medium body.
Bottle. Orange colour with a off-white head. Dry acid, light fruity aroma and taste. Medium body and a sweet dry acid finish.

Bottled.
Clear amber coloured with a small off white head.
Acidic aroma with notes of fruits, apples and wood.
Sweet flavour of wood and fruits with acidic notes.
Dry woody finish.
Golden colour with a small head. lemon aroma and flavour. Acidic finish. did it done it, never doing it again
Bottle fynske øldage 2005. Ok appearence. Powerfull aroma. Very acetic flavour.
On eof the best beers I drank these years !! Sweet taste and a plaesure to see it sparkling in my glass.
Dark golden with a small head. Fresh aroma with lots of lemon, and perhaps some metal? Sweet flavour with some fruity acid underneath. Refreshing, but a little sweet for my tastes.

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2005 [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Brown beerlike colour. Notes of some kind of acid (hydrochloric acid I think). Long, creamy and sweet aftertaste. Perfect on a hot sunny day. Gotta get a few more of these..

My first faro.  37.5 cl bottle.  Light golden colour, thick creamy white head.  Light earthy and dusty aroma.  A touch of barnyard funkiness underneath the sweet syrupy cherry aroma.  Flavour is lightly sweet, honeyish and quite earthy with a bit of fruitiness as well.  Tartness appears underneath the obvious sweetness.  Lingering earthy funk.  Quite nice.

Beer much rare, Hazy amber colour, bittersweet, sugar, cherries in aroma.
Very particular.

Murky copper hue with a creamy white head.  Very musty, overipe fruit, barnyard.  Heavily sweet, lightly acidic flavor.  Moderately sweet, moderately acidic finish.  Very table-sugar sweet with some astringency.  Also kind of medicinal.  Medium-full body, oily texture, average carbonation.  Just not interesting to me.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2006 this was pretty awesome.  aroma of sour cherries, syrup, brown sugar, and white grape juice.  the flavor was pretty complex in my opinion.  hits at first like cherry dimetap, white grapes, and then if you wait between sips, the flavor sticks on the middle of your tongue like a cherry coughdrop.  has a wine-y kind of feel to it.  very very sweet the more you drink.  after the cough drop flavor wears away, i get some apple cider notes.  mmmm...

Odd brownish orange color to it with no head to be seen by these eyes. I get alot of sour grapes and funky cheese in the aroma. Very nice acidic light sour cherry flavor, very smooth, very nice, i dig it.
Hazy amber colour with a small fast disappearing off white head. Yeasty light acidic aroma. Sweet malty flavor, hints of caramel. Light acidic finish.

(Bottle 25 cl) Amber coloured with a rather flat head. Lovely nut-like aroma, initial sophisticated tartness soon relieved by the wonderful sweetness from the candi sugars. Very refreshing swet and sour blend. Faros are a favourite. 270499

This beer has a amber body - hue apperance and a coarse white scum collar. I have drunk the beer from the bottle and it had no carbonic acid. The initial flavor taste is sweet with a light acid tutsh.

2005 Lambic Festival at Deliahs Chicago (sample of a 2002, 33 mL bottle): clear, golden amber with sparse, white bubbles.  Sweet caramel laced aroma with an interesting hint of yeast, must and candied malt.  Overly sweet and lightly carbonated apple juice.  Soft, slightly astringent bitterness in the finish, which was strangely enticing.

Amber body with a thin, fluffy white head.  Sweet sugary aroma with apple juice--the kind the kids drink.  Sort of thin, without as much body as one would expect with the added sugar.  The sweetness was unappealing.  I dont remember the Cantillon Faro being anywhere near this sweet.  I dont know if that was my lack of experience and understanding or if its just a result of the different brewers.  Either way, not my favorite.

The cap left some rust on the bottle. Caramel color, very little head. Low carb, feels "thick". As expected, browned sugar flavor. For you finnish speakers I would descripe the taste as "vappusima". The first time I had this I felt bad taking the last sip because that ment that it would end.

A Mes rate:
It looks sweet as soon as you pour it. Appearance is a slightly cloudy redish brown and the head is as attractive looking as a head can be. Thick, foamy and slightly off white. Leaves some good chunky lacing behind too. The nose is faintly similar to a usual lambic just not quite as full on and you can obviously smell at least a little of the candy sugar. The flavour is quite different. Much fruitier than you would expect from the nose and initially very sweet. I mean sweet. The sweetnes vanishes as soon as you swallow and the finish is just like a lambic but much more gentle. I have not had this in a long time as they changed it and I have to say I really wish they hadnt. It used to be so much better in my opinion but never the less this is a lovely drink. They really should make sweets like this...

Oh My God. Love at first taste, this one. lighty flavour of fruit that seems a mix of pear, apple and peach. Sweet, but not overly so, with a tart edge to it. Makes me angry that I need to go to Belgium to get it.

Light cloudy amber-orange color with small creamy ivory colored head. Nice fruity aroma with touches of raspberries, dried apricots, appletart, cider and brown sugar, also a woody unthertone. The taste is smooth and has a good balance. The taste is sweet and fruity and the acidity is well integrated. Again raspberrie in the taste, hints of sour apple, crumblecake, sweet rubarbe jam, some earthy tones and some wood. A fine faro with a refreshing caracter.
UPDATED: NOV 4, 2006 Bottle.  Sweet musty yeast aroma.  Medium tan with small head - slightly cloudy.  Sweetness is primary flavor - slight sourness and earthy undertones.  A mild Faro - enjoyable.

(bottle) Dark amber colour with a small frothy white head. Acidic aroma of fruits, cider and candy sugar. Sweet flavour turns into a light sweet-sour woody & vinous mouthfeel with a rather dry, slightly bitter-sour finish with a good length.

Pour is wonderful ruby color.  Some cherry funkiness going on, but I know the sweet will dominate from what I expect in a faro.  Slightly tart up front, lots of sweetness midway through and finishes that way.

I had this in Au Trappists in Paris. Really impressive in the glass with its reddish hue and a promise of something different to come. A phenolic nose here but one that is expected from a beer that should be on the funky side. This is a real palate cleanser after a few Belgian ales and would be reat in the summer at the barbecue. The added sugar doesnt cause me any real problems nor does the aparent light hand with hops. This is like a Portuguese style of rose more than a beer with a great refreshing aftertaste and tartness.
user_location: Potts Point, New South Wales, AUSTRALIA

text: Amber red with a small head.  Aromas have the musty sourness of a traditional lambic wth added sweetness (as expected!).  Flavours are sweet and sugary followed by a musty sourness.  It should be too sweet for my hops loving palate but this is very well blended with nice carbonation and more musty sourness to finish.  Quite filling - its a meal in a glass.

Murky amber with a fluffy, small pinkish head.  Nice sugary sour smell.  Sticky sweet flavor at first, changing quite tart as the carbonation hits your mouth.  Very enjoyable but extremely sugary.  Sticky palate due to all of the sugar.  Tartness coats the mouth.  Very fruity.
Lacks aroma, berry and candy floss. Pours light amber/red with a pinky beige head. Sweet candy apple/strawberry in start with a mild tart finish. Aftertaste of berries. Thin though feels right? Ok.
Darkish red with a pink head. Aroma is like a sweeter, darker berry (blueberry?). Taste is both sweet and sour with strawberries, cherries and apple all balanced out.
Red-orange.  Acidic and a bit sour, starts sweet and very acidic, then gets a bit bready.

Poured a copper color with a small off white head that left light lacing on the glass.  Sweet candy apple, doughy, dry cinnamon, straw, though also a vegetable aspect to the aroma.  Taste starts sweet, of sugar cane, then lightly tart and sour, and finishes sweet again.

Of all the geuze I have tasted, this is by far the best. Its probably because they add sugar to the beer before fermentation. Geuze and Lambics tend to be very bitter, but this one is surprisingly well-balanced and pleasantly fizzy. Not much head, amber colour, obvious sweet taste and aftertaste.

(Bottled, 0.375l, 4% ABV) Hazy amber/orange color with small head. Sourish, very fruity (apple)  aroma. Extremely sugary, very sweet, very fruity flavor. Slight acidic sourness in the finish. Sugary aftertaste. Medium-bodied, moderately carbonated, very sugary, oily palate. Half a bottle of lambic, half of sugar. Cant really drink much of this stuff at once!

Bottled (25cL). My bottle says 4% ABV, also. Purchased from Beer Mania in Brussels. Small spritzy cream colored head atop a lush copper body. Nose is sweet-sour with wood and strong sugar. Thorough dousing of sour fruit as well. Taste is very sweet and candyish with strong sugar notes almost subduing everything. Theres some wood with a tobacco hint as well. Body with lively and spritzy with a stickiness coming through in it. Finish is more sugary sweetness than anything. This was essentially a sugar laden lambic.

(on bottle)entering my first faro; I don´t know what to expect. Sent is kind of artiftcial; some cherry-vinegar, but mostly a kind of mintish feel. Very well carbonated and a totally different taste tha aroma. Sweet at first, but broadens out to a more winerous, lip-culing fullness. Still, very sweet.

Bottle from Pitfield Beer Shop, London. 375ml. Served in a Cantillon glass. Pours murky brown, thin white head. Sweet, woody & slightly acidic aroma. Flavour is sweet, like a soft drink, and retains lambic woodyness, but none of the lambic sourness. Quite good, but whats the point really?

Bottled.  A pleasant sour lambic aroma to this brown beer with reddish tints.  There is medium carbonation and a small head.  The taste is very sweet to start with but does seem to mellow through the drink.  My first ever experience of Faro as far as memory allows, should like to try others.
This is one of the more easy drinkable faroes from Belgium. I like it, but it is a bit artificial compared to girardin. Not sour enough and therefore not refreshing enough.
Light copper, cloudy. Cherry cola nose, sweet. Very sweet flavor with cherry, some tangy sourness.

2002 vintage sampled in 2004:  Brownish red, sugary strange nose, somewhat chocolatey thing going on in the nose.  Sweet and one dimensional, no real character, but still enjoyable becuase of its oddness (there is nothing offensive about it).  Seemed watered down.

Bottled: Brown coloured with an orange glow. Clear. Light off white head. Has a nice sourness in the nose with som full fruityness. Very fresh. Fruit (cherries) and sweetness in the flavour. Is sweet in the aftertaste.

Bottled.
Redish amber with an almost creamy head.
Sourish, smoky(?) aroma.
Sourish and sweet with burnt sugar.

Vintage - Expires 2000.Amber orange body with a foamy off-white head. Old aroma of wet wood and wild fermentation. Sweet and sour flavor - wild fermentation, wood and candy sugar. Quite nice but maybe a little over the hill.

The aroma is sweet and sour with notes of wood and (too old?) candy sugar - maybe the fact that it was 4 years past last expiry date caused the "old" aroma. The color is dark amber and poures with a fine head. The flavor is lovely sweet combined with sourness and notes of caramel and hints of the wild fermentation.

good stuff.  lively fresh scent with a clear amber color and a lasting head. refreshingly sweet and acidic flavor with good carbonation.  virtually no aftertaste with a clean finish.  I'd rather drink this in the morning than oj.  what i'd like to know is how old is the faro lindemans.

Head is initially small, frothy, off-white, mostly lasting. Body is hazy medium amber, bottle conditioned. Aroma is lightly yeasty (barnyward, cobwebs), with notes of caramel/candy, and cherry. Flavor is heavily sweet, moderately acidic. Finish is moderately sweet, moderately acidic. Medium body, syrupy texture, lively carbonation.

Nice musty barn smell - hay and horse sweat. Sourness and wild cherries. But underlying is a candy-like sweet smell. Sweet Tarts. Orange-amber clear, brilliant. Small white head dissipates quickly with some lace. Medium heavy watery body with medium carbonation. Sweet and sour to start. A tart cherry-like sourness hits first followed immediately with a syrupy sugary coating. Lactic sourness under the sugar with just a bit of hops finishes out the drink. After is sweet tart and pleasant. Gotta say I don't care as much for this sweeter style as I do plain lambic or fruit lambic.

nice beverage-- it shows how extensive the beer family can be, this scarcely seems like a beer at all-- there are few of the usual signposts indicating much in the way of malt or hops. one would guess this one is a relative only by marriage: brewing yeasts and some vague malt foundation wedded to dark fruits in sweet noble rot. it's a soft orange pour-- between tiger fur and apricot pastel yellow.  there's a nice decoration of ice-white lace like sinuous veins in marble. rich aroma of cherrys, cedar, noga-hide upholstery, and some perfumes common to ladies bath soaps. i searched hard for the "barnyard" aromas, but found only the dried-flower smell of hay--  no horses or goats. extremely sippable, the 25cl bottle is an adequate serving size. is it sweet? duh, yeah, does michael jackson own a bottle opener?  yeah, it's way sweet.  cherries and apples with a very tart cranberry finish. lightly sour, acidic as a car battery, very soft creamy palette. the finish is all cranberry-lemon, which may accord with breakfast fare: pastries and waffles. contains no buzz that i could desern: this is suitable for children, pooh bears and sweat bees-- and perhaps the serious beer hunter searching for the outer boundaries of what we call beer.

Beer 27 Belgium trip.  I had a bottle of this 11 years ago and gave it to a friend as a last minute 21st birthday gift.  I never got to try it, and hadn't seen it since.  So I was happy to snag this bottle when I ran across it.  Medium copper color, OK head.  Smells like sweetened ice tea.  Hint of lemon, horseblanket was muted, and sweet.  Interesting, but not a favorite.

Dark amber, light white head.  The nose is acidic with hints of vinegar, citrus tartness and some barnyard hints.  The body is quite sweet with brown sugar notes at the front.  Turns slightly more acidic in the middle with hints of ?ketchup? and vinegar.  Slightly tart and finishes dry.  A very interesting drinking experience, complex and really quite drinkable and sweet.
Nice and refreshing. Fine, creamy head. Lots of acid, fine acid. Fruit, rasberry.
This beer is a very refresching beer for in the summer. It has nice brown orangy colour, and the taste is more complex than the average refresing beer. A good one, but not excellent.
Bottle, at the Dovetail, London. This reminded me of Palm, with its lucozade colour and barley sugar flavour. This was softer however, and slightly smoother.  Overall the sweetness was a bit much.

Deep red-amber in colour.  Aroma was of sugar, cherries, some caramel.  Flavour was sour at first, then sweet, with some caramel and sugar.  Finishes with a pleasant sweetness.  I am glad that I got to try this.
Amber color. Prickly acetic nose in the beginning; turns to be sweeter and woodier. Quite sweet body, with a wood note. Not impressive, but pleasant sweet drink.
Clear copper coloured beer with a big off white head. Light sour buttery aroma. Sweet soft taste with only a hint of sour old attic. I find this lambic a bit too sweet for my palate.
UPDATED: JAN 22, 2006 Off-white head, gone in seconds. Copper colour. Easy to drink. Sweet start and sour finish. Also notes of wine and overripe fruits. Pleasent.

Faro in a bottle... Contradictio in terminis. Enfin. Clear amber. thick, dense amberish head. sweet nose, like a caramel&chocolat bar ("Snickers",...), and a stiff whiff of "horseblanket". Sweetness has an artificial ring. The sweet + sour taste gives an impression of fruitsugar ("Traubenzucker"). The base is there, and it is real, you just want to get rid of the horrible overlying sweetness. Underneath - 't would just be great. Fruity tones: blue eating grapes, rambutan,... Mouthfeel : a bit sticky, of cours... Faro ought to be drunk, freshly made on the spot with real lambic and honest candi syrup. This can only be a far cry.

Pours a cloudy dark amber about the same color as apple cider (the non-alcoholic kind). Big foamy head is mostly lasting with a bit of intricate lace. Nose is sour like gueuze only much milder with a bready hint. Sweet flavor with just an edge of sourness. Sticky mouthfeel. Very low carbonation. A tasty balance of sweet and tart. Very good. Those who don't like gueuze or fruit lambic might still like this.
Cloudy light orange, big head. Great sour apple flavour with orange / lemon, perhaps a bit too sweet otherwise. Cracking.
Aroma has lemon. mango and cherry. Sweet and sour flavor with lemon, cherry, butter and caramel. Sugary and a bit sticky.
Nose: sour,cherrys, cider. Amber-red colour and head goes down quickly. Sweet and sour, well balanced. Refreshing, with a sweet-sour aftertaste.

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2003 Whip me into a frenzy. With sugar on top. Gone in a flash. More! [3.4]  Re-rate.   Bottle.  Sampled alongside Chapeau Faro. The Chapeau has more flavour, but Lindeman's is much more fun!
Big sour nose with green apple aromas. Dark gold-copper color and a tall, fluffy head with lace. Sweet, syrupy and at times even sugary. Maybe too sweet. Round a lip licking.
Light sour nose, very sweet. Cherries. Amber with a little head leaving legs. I guess it is not my style.
A great flavor. Really sweet, well balanced. Nice sugar taste. I will probably drink a lot more of this one.
Mon premiere example de cette style et jaime beaucoup.  Light amber/copper colour with a creamy beige head. Sweet with a tang.  Beerilicious!

cloudy  tea-like colour. frothy head that did not last long, served in a rather odd looking and chunky tumbler. nose hints at berries and is rarther tart. the taste starts sour but becomes much sweeter -  in the manner of a sugary iced tea.
maintains a good sweet and sour combination of flavours that is very easy to drink.

looks like a cherryless kriek, which i guess it is to all is and ps. flat, red-brown. smells sorta cheesy, tastes pretty tame and sweet with a tiny bit of blood and scabs that mr exp likes. our bottle mightve been an old one - i think yer sposter drink these fresh.
I found this to be balanced, still refreshing and cleansing and very drinkable. Felt like a shandy at first but once I could get a handle on the old beer below it steered me to some happy drinking.

Faro is an interesting style. It sure is very sweet and I am not certain that I could finish a whole bottle myself. However, small amounts of this can be rather pleasant along with the dessert or afterwards.
Fruity aroma, very sweet taste.  I didnt perceived any difference with an kriek-lambic.
drinking flat coke in a train station. prety easy to drink a lot of these. really ripe

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2004 Woody, sweet, bit malty and yeasty aroma. Hazy amber-orange coloured with a lasting head. Looks pretty good. Taste is sugarsweet, malty, yeasty, tart, woody and fruity (citrus and some berries). Siruppy. Lacking balance; it's a bit too sweet.
Cloudy amber color, short lived foam (thnx BeerLimey). Loads of sweet candy sugar, mixed with some cherries. Add a little sourness, and there you go: Lindemans Faro.

Cloudy amber color, short lived foam. Sour apple fruitiness and oakiness in aroma with hints of raspberry. Candy sugar jumps out at front and stays throughout lingering into aftertaste. Sourness detectable in latter half but struggles to fight its way through in the sweetness. Berry candy sweetness in aftertaste is intriguing. Enjoyable, but a little too sweet. Now let me go find another Faro for comparison as I always thought the Lindemans fruities were too sweet too.

Very slightly cloudy orange red-brown colour with small short lasting cream coloured head. Stronger sour citrus-cherries, sweet malty and very faint yeasty 2 day old socks aromas. Smooth, good carbonation, medium to high intensity  cidery/grapey sour - sweet start, moving to a softer primarily sweeter middle and a even softer balanced sweet-sour finish. Very refreshing but a tad too much soft drink like in character for my taste.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2006 Sweet and sour,lacked sufficent carbonation,slightly fruity.6/4/7/3/14
Rerated 3/06  Deep golden in color with a light haze and a small white ehad. Apples,sweet sugar and apple pie aroma. Flavor is sweet with a subdued funk and low acidity.

OK-my ratings are...extremely critical..
Upon pouring, the foam immediately disappears into a complete no-foam status, and the remaining liquid has an amber, tea-like, look to it.
The smell is sour, as would be expected from a faro.
Far-O too sweet taste, a sugar-suspension in a lemonade-like brew (FYG, I drink my tea very sweet, so am not adverse to sugar!).
Sweetness pervades all, and leaves not a chance to the Lambiek element in this beer.  This is a soft drink.  I have tasted other faros which are much much less sweet and have good character...
UPDATED: DEC 7, 2004 Bottle. Very sweet, fairy floss flavour, lightly sticky, with only a hint of sourness.
amber-red colour, few head, cherry and vinegar aroma, hint of black-currant, very very sweet with only a touch of sourness, quite heavy and unbalanced

UPDATED: MAY 11, 2007 Bottled. Very good aroma. Lots of oak in there, wine and candy sugar. Dark amber to brown colored, beige head, few lace. Very sweet but thats according to the style. Nice bitterness, light sour, oak/wood. Sparkling yet sticky and a bit astringent. Sweetened so way easier to drink but thats the idea. I love it.
An interesting beer. Sweet and sour at the same time. The chicks would dig this beer!
This is a beer for the lovers of sweet beers. First you taste something cherry, sweet, then something very bitter and then a bitter-sweet mix.
